choices.text: Posterior interosseous nerve

questions.text: Identify the nerve involved in this test: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Median nerve

 

SPECIAL TESTS FOR MEDIAN NERVE INJURY

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign / Ochsner’s Clasping / Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ulnar nerve. Special tests for ulnar nerve injury are:

 

  • Froment’s sign:
    • Test: The patient is asked to make a strong pinch between the thumb and index finger and grip a flat object such as a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. The examiner then attempts to pull the object out of the patient’s hands.
    • Interpretation: There is weakness of the adductor pollicis innervated by the ulnar nerve which would keep the IP joint relatively straight; instead, the FPL muscle, which is innervated by the median nerve is substituted for the AP and will cause the IP joint to go into a hyperflexed position.

 

 

  • Wartenberg’s sign:
    • Test: The patient’s places wrist in neutral and forearm in full pronation and is instructed to perform full extension of all the fingers. Once digits are extended, patient is asked to fully abduct and then adduct all fingers.
    • Interpretation: A positive sign is indicated with the observation of abduction of the 5th digit, with the inability to adduct the 5th finger when extended.

 

 

  • Egawa’s sign:
    • Test: The patient flexes the middle digit & then alternately deviates the finger radially & ulnarly.
    • Interpretation: If the patient is unable to do this Egawa’s sign, the interossei are affected.

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Musculocutaneous nerve. Check strength of Biceps Brachii, Corocobrachialis and Brachialis muscles. Check sensation on lateral forearm.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The test image shown in the question is the Pen Test, which is done to diagnose median nerve injury.

questions.text: A patient who is a diagnosed case of HNPCC, which of the following is the most common repair associated with it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mismatch repair

 

Explanation:

 

Mismatch Repair (MMR) defect leads to Hereditary Non-Polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC). This mechanism corrects errors that typically occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MMR genes result in microsatellite instability and contribute to the development of various cancers at an early age. In contrast, Homologous Repair (HR) defects are associated with other genetic disorders and cancers, including Bloom syndrome, Werner syndrome, breast cancer, and Ataxia-Telangiectasia like disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nucleotide excision repair: Incorrect for this context as it deals with the repair of bulky helix-distorting lesions caused by UV radiation and chemicals, leading to diseases like Xeroderma pigmentosum.

 

Option C. Base excision repair: Incorrect as it fixes small non-helix-distorting bases caused by spontaneous or induced changes, leading to conditions like MUTYH-associated polyposis when defective.

 

Option D. Homologous recombinant repair: Incorrect for HNPCC. It repairs double-strand breaks or interstrand cross-links in DNA, not typically involved in the pathogenesis of HNPCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 370

choices.text: Stop MDT give thalidomide
Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids
Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids

 

The situation described, where pre-existing lesions worsen during multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, indicates a type 1 lepra reaction. In managing this condition, the recommended approach would be to continue MDT while initiating systemic steroid treatment.

 

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are marked by inflammation of existing skin lesions, leading to symptoms such as edema, redness, and pain. While ulcers are uncommon, the development of new lesions is exceptionally rare. Additionally, acute neuritis may occur, presenting with tenderness and impairment of both motor and sensory functions.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued. NSAIDs and oral steroids can be added to treat pain.
  • Thalidomide is considered the gold standard for treating severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum. However, it is not the Drug of Choice due to its high cost and potential for adverse drug reactions. In type II lepra reactions, patients may experience systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of new skin lesions.

 

Type I & II lepra reactions:

 

(ENL = Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Stop MDT give thalidomide

  • Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug that may be used in certain conditions, like leprosy and its complications.
  • However, stopping MDT is not recommended as it is crucial to continue the treatment of the primary disease. Thalidomide is not used as treatment for Type 1 lepra reaction in leprosy.

 

Option B. Continue MDT, start thalidomide –

While MDT should be continued, thalidomide is not typically used for nerve complications. It's used primarily for severe or recurrent erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) Type 2 Lepra reaction, which is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.

 

Option C. Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids –

  • Stopping MDT is not advised as the antibiotics in MDT are essential for treating the bacterial infection causing the disease.
  • The MDT should be continued to prevent the development of drug resistance and to adequately treat the underlying infection.

 

Option D. Continue MDT, start systemic steroids -

  • This is the correct management for a leprosy patient with nerve damage, which is likely due to an immune reaction called a leprosy reaction. Systemic corticosteroids are used to control the inflammation and prevent further nerve damage.
  • MDT should be continued to treat the underlying infection.
  • The reason for selecting option D is that systemic corticosteroids are effective in treating acute nerve inflammation and can prevent further damage while continuing MDT ensures that the infection is adequately treated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy, the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page no 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

questions.text: A patient with renal insufficiency had very low urine output, pedal edema, headache, and a blood pressure of 160/90. Which antihypertensive medication can be used? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Amlodipine

 

In a patient with renal insufficiency and low urine output, the preferred antihypertensive medication would be one that is safe in renal failure.

 

Amlodipine is a good choice because it is a calcium channel blocker that does not affect renal function. Although it can cause pedal edema in some patients but the pedal edema which is given in the question seems to be due to renal insufficiency itself. The adverse effect of pedal edema does not make it contra-indicated for hypertension.  It also has a long duration of action and is well-tolerated in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aliskiren: Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor that can lead to severe hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with renal insufficiency. Hyperkalemia can exacerbate renal dysfunction and pose serious health risks, making aliskiren an unsuitable choice for this patient.

 

Option B. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic. Thiazide diuretics are typically ineffective in patients with significantly impaired renal function (e.g., low GFR) and can cause electrolyte imbalances, including hypokalemia and hyponatremia. Therefore, chlorthalidone is not recommended for patients with renal insufficiency and low urine output.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Prazosin is an alpha-blocker used to lower blood pressure. However, it is not typically a first-line drug for hypertension due to its side effects, such as postural hypotension. Additionally, prazosin can cause fluid retention, which may worsen renal function in patients with renal insufficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amlodipine is the preferred antihypertensive medication for patients with renal insufficiency, as it effectively lowers blood pressure without negatively impacting renal function.

questions.text: Transparency of corneal endothelium is maintained by: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratan sulphate

 

  • Keratan sulfate is a key glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal endothelium. It plays a significant role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating hydration, contributing to the structural integrity of the cornea, and preventing swelling, which could impair vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the cornea, but its main role is in the basement membrane and Bowman's membrane, rather than the corneal endothelium. It plays a role in supporting the structure but is not the primary factor for endothelial transparency.

 

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan found in the cornea, but its primary role is not related to endothelial transparency. It contributes to the overall structure and function of the cornea but does not play a direct role in maintaining endothelial clarity.

 

Option D. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is essential for regulating hydration within the cornea, but its main role is in the corneal stroma, not the endothelium. It ensures the cornea remains transparent by preventing excessive swelling in the stromal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 602

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with spinal TB; he has a swelling in the left groin with limb attitude is in flexion. Identify what caused it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario of a patient with Pott spine having persistent hip flexion with a history of spinal tuberculosis is suggestive of psoas abscess involving the psoas muscle, marked A in the given coronal CT image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with spinal TB, a psoas abscess is a significant complication that can lead to symptoms such as groin swelling and changes in limb posture due to its location and the effect of the abscess on the surrounding structures, particularly the psoas muscle. Prompt recognition and treatment are crucial to manage symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who engaged in unprotected sexual intercourse develops urethral discharge one week later as shown in the given image below. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhea

 

The given image shows purulent urethral discharge that developed one week after unprotected sexual intercourse is suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhea.

 

Purulent urethral discharge can be seen in gonorrhea caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or lymphogranuloma venerum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

Gonorrhea:

 

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli is involved in this adhesion. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by the third day of infection. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include urethral discharge and dysuria, usually without urinary frequency or urgency. The specific symptoms seen in males and females are as follows:

 

In males:

 

  • ﻿﻿The disease starts as acute urethritis. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis.
  • ﻿﻿Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation.
  • ﻿﻿The infection may spread to the periurethral tissues causing abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

 

In females:

 

  • ﻿﻿The initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes.
  • ﻿﻿The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because the stratified squamous epithelium is resistant to infection by the cocci, and also because of the acidic pH of vaginal secretions.
  • ﻿﻿Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility.
  • ﻿﻿Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome)

 

Lab diagnosis:

 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Treatment: Ceftriaxone (250mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days

 

The image below shows the Gram-stain of a urethral exudate showing typical intracellular gram-negative diplococci and pleomorphic extracellular gram-negative organisms

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Ureaplasma urealyticum is the second most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis next to chlamydia. That is why the initial etiological agent under suspicion always remains gonorrhea.

 

Option C. Herpes Simplex will be associated with vesicular lesions.

 

Option D. Trichomonas vaginalis generally presents with a frothy discharge

 

Educational Objective

 

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a significant cause of sexually transmitted infections, manifesting as acute urethritis with purulent discharge in males. Prompt diagnosis and treatment with appropriate antibiotics, such as a combination of ceftriaxone and azithromycin, are crucial to prevent complications and limit the spread of this highly contagious infection.

 

Non-gonococcal urethritis is caused by:

 

  • ﻿﻿Chlamydia trachomatis
  • ﻿﻿Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium
  • ﻿﻿Trichomonas vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Herpes simplex virus (rare)
  • ﻿﻿Adenovirus
  • ﻿﻿Haemophilus vaginalis
  • ﻿﻿Mycoplasma genitalium

questions.text: A patient presents with a seizure. On evaluation, urine osmolality is 1000 mOsm/Kg and serum osmolality is 270 mOsm/Kg. Which electrolyte abnormality can be expected in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

The patient's laboratory findings show high urine osmolality and low serum osmolality, which are indicative of a condition where the kidneys are concentrating urine despite low blood osmolality. This is characteristic of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) secretion.

 

In SIADH, excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) leads to water retention, dilutional hyponatremia (low serum sodium), and the production of concentrated urine (high urine osmolality). The body retains water, which dilutes the blood sodium levels but the kidneys continue to excrete sodium, resulting in a low serum osmolality.

 

Differential diagnosis - Cerebral Salt Wasting Syndrome (CSWS):

 

  • Fluid Status: Patients are hypovolemic, meaning there is a reduced volume of circulating fluid in the body.
  • Characteristics: It involves the loss of sodium from the body, which exceeds the loss of water, leading to hyponatremia and decreased blood volume. This condition is often associated with neurological disorders such as injuries or diseases affecting the brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia refers to high sodium levels in the blood, which would typically be associated with high serum osmolality. This does not fit the patient's laboratory findings.

 

Option C. Hyperkalemia: Hyperkalemia is an elevated level of potassium in the blood and does not correlate with the osmolality findings presented.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: Hypokalemia is a low potassium level in the blood and, while it can be associated with various conditions, it is not directly indicated by the osmolality findings described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality, SIADH is a likely diagnosis, and the primary electrolyte abnormality to expect is hyponatremia.

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

Lingual Nerve: This is the branch of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It runs close to the submandibular gland and is therefore at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Sensory Distribution: Provides general sensory (pain, temperature, touch) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. (Note: Taste sensation for this region is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, which joins the lingual nerve for a short course.)

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

 

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerve to Mylohyoid: This nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3). It descends on the medial surface of the mandible in the mylohyoid groove.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in the elevation of the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth during swallowing and speech.

 

Option B. Inferior Alveolar Nerve: It's a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It enters the mandibular foramen and runs through the mandibular canal.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Does not directly supply any muscles.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the mandibular teeth, lower lip, and chin.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal Nerve (12th Cranial Nerve): This cranial nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and supplies the muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies almost all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vagus nerve).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Tongue deviation to the side of the lesion due to weakened tongue muscles on that side. If you asked the patient to protrude their tongue, it would point towards the side of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

 

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria, nephritic syndrome, and nephrotic syndrome. Adults have more severe renal manifestations. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura: typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Dengue fever: Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

questions.text: A teenage patient presented with a history of dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. On ultrasonography, a transverse vaginal septum was seen. Which of the following is she likely to have? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis:

 

  • A transverse vaginal septum is a type of Mullerian anomaly, which can be low, mid, or high and can be complete or incomplete.
  • It can present as primary amenorrhea with cyclical abdominal pain if complete.
  • The obstruction to blood flow caused by a transverse vaginal septum can lead to the accumulation of blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and uterus (hematometra), which can subsequently cause retrograde menstruation and result in endometriosis.
  • The chronic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea in this patient are consistent with endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Theca lutein cyst: Theca lutein cysts are often associated with high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and are seen in conditions like molar pregnancy and multiple gestations. They do not cause symptoms related to menstrual obstruction and are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option C. Tubo-ovarian abscess: Tubo-ovarian abscess is typically associated with pelvic inflammatory disease and presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and a tender adnexal mass. It is not directly related to Mullerian anomalies like a transverse vaginal septum.

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors that typically do not cause dysmenorrhea or chronic pelvic pain related to menstrual obstruction. They are not associated with Mullerian anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transverse vaginal septum, a Mullerian anomaly, can cause obstruction to menstrual flow leading to hematocolpos, hematometra, and endometriosis, presenting with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Physiological

 

Physiological:

 

  • The discharge described is white with no pruritus and occurs mid-cycle (ovulatory) with a short duration, which is most likely physiological.
  • Increased physiological discharge is common during:
    • Puberty
    • Ovulation
    • Pregnancy
    • Occasionally during the premenstrual phase
  • It may be cervical or vaginal in origin. A speculum examination of the vagina can distinguish between the two. If the discharge is cervical in origin, an excessive mucoid discharge will be visible at the external os.
  • Normal discharge appears clear or white, without any odor or itching, and has a pH of 3.8-4.2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichomoniasis:

 

  • Presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge with a strong odor.
  • Associated with vaginal itching, burning, and discomfort during intercourse.

 

Option C. Bacterial vaginosis:

 

  • Characterized by a thin, grayish-white, homogenous discharge with a fishy odor, especially noticeable after intercourse.
  • Itching is less common.

 

Option D. Candidiasis:

 

  • Typically presents with white, curdy discharge associated with intense itching and vulvar irritation.
  • The discharge often has a cottage cheese-like appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological vaginal discharge is typically clear or white, without odor or itching, and can occur at ovulation, puberty, pregnancy, or occasionally during the premenstrual phase.

 

 

Ref: Page no 554, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

 

If the height for age of a child is less than -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population, it is most likely due to chronic malnutrition.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Malnutrition (Stunting): Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, occurs when a child does not receive adequate nutrition over a prolonged period, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from conception to the child's second birthday). This results in impaired linear growth, making the child shorter than expected for their age. Height for age is the key indicator used to measure stunting.
  • Acute Malnutrition (Wasting): Acute malnutrition, or wasting, is characterized by a rapid loss of weight relative to height. It is usually the result of a recent illness or severe food shortage. Weight for height is the primary measure of wasting, not height for age.
  • Recent Infection: While a recent infection can temporarily affect a child's weight or growth velocity, it does not typically lead to chronic stunting unless the child experiences recurrent infections over a long period.
  • No Malnutrition: If a child's height for age is within the normal range, it indicates adequate nutrition and growth. However, a height for age < -2SD indicates a significant deviation from the norm due to chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute malnutrition: This condition affects the weight for height parameter, indicating a rapid loss of weight rather than a prolonged deficit in linear growth.

 

Option C. Recent infection: Although a recent infection can cause temporary weight loss or affect growth velocity, it is unlikely to result in stunted growth unless the child has had recurrent infections over an extended period.

 

Option D. No malnutrition: A child with a height for age < -2SD cannot be classified as having no malnutrition, as this deviation indicates chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Crown rump length by USG

 

Explanation:

 

Crown-Rump Length (CRL) by Ultrasound:

 

  • The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is by measuring the Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound. This method is reliable as it directly measures the embryo or fetus and provides a precise gestational age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adding 280 days to the Last Menstrual Period (LMP):

 

  • This method, known as Naegele’s rule, is commonly used but assumes a regular 28-day menstrual cycle and may not be accurate for women with irregular cycles or those using contraceptives.
  • It is less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives, which can alter the regularity of menstrual cycles.

 

Option C. Fundus Examination:

 

  • Palpation of the uterine fundus is a physical examination method to estimate gestational age. However, it is less accurate in the first trimester and typically used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Option D. Adding 256 days to the LMP:

 

  • This method is not standard practice and is less commonly used compared to adding 280 days to the LMP.
  • It would be even less reliable in this patient who has been on oral contraceptives.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate method for determining gestational age in the first trimester is the measurement of Crown-Rump Length (CRL) on ultrasound.

 

Ref: Page no 475, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

 

The given image shows small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with discrete margins that are suggestive of hard exudates, seen in diabetic macular edema.

 

 

COTTON WOOL SPOT vs HARD EXUDATE

 

 

Diabetic retinopathy

 

 

Hypertensive retinopathy

 

 

Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) – Fundoscopy reveals massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins. Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Soft exudate, Hypertension: Soft exudates, also known as cotton wool spots, are whitish fluffy spots with indistinct margins.

 

They occur around infarcted areas and result from swelling of nerve fiber layer axons.

 

Associated with hypertensive retinopathy, toxaemic retinopathy of pregnancy, diabetic retinopathy, anemias, and collagen disorders like discoid lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, and scleroderma.

 

Option C. Flame-shaped hemorrhages, Hypertension: Flame-shaped hemorrhages are superficial retinal hemorrhages that occur due to disruption of the capillaries in the retinal nerve fiber layer.

 

They are seen in diabetic retinopathy, non-ischemic central retinal vein occlusion, traumatic retinopathy, Eale's disease, hypertensive retinopathy, and anemic retinopathy.

 

Option D. Soft exudate, Central retinal vein occlusion: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is characterized by massive engorgement, congestion, and tortuosity of retinal veins.

 

Ischemic CRVO has massive retinal hemorrhages giving a splashed tomato appearance involving the whole fundus.

 

Soft exudates can be seen in CRVO but are not the primary finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

Endometriosis: Endometriosis can occur in patients with uterus didelphys, particularly in the rare variant known as OHVIRA syndrome (Obstructed Hemi Vagina with Ipsilateral Renal Agenesis), where menstrual blood can become trapped, leading to retrograde menstruation and endometriosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preterm labor: Preterm labor is a recognized complication in patients with uterus didelphys. The abnormal structure of the uterus can lead to difficulties in carrying the pregnancy to full term.

 

Option C. Transverse lie: Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more commonly associated with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus, rather than uterus didelphys. Uterus didelphys usually has a better reproductive outcome compared to other uterine anomalies, though it still presents with certain risks.

 

Option D. Abortions: Spontaneous abortion is a potential complication associated with uterus didelphys due to the structural anomaly affecting the uterine environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterus didelphys is associated with complications such as spontaneous abortion, preterm labor, and endometriosis, but it is less likely to cause a transverse lie, which is more common in arcuate or sub-septate uteri.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7231278/

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Live and subcutaneous: While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C. Live and intramuscular: Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D. Killed and subcutaneous: Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms suggestive of unstable angina, given the recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes (left ventricular hypertrophy with ST segment flattening). Despite the negative troponin, which rules out myocardial infarction, the clinical scenario points to a high risk of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

 

For high-risk ACS, especially in a patient already on medications for coronary artery disease (CAD) like aspirin, atorvastatin, and metoprolol, initiating anticoagulation therapy is crucial to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction. Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is recommended at a therapeutic dose of 1 mg/kg subcutaneously twice a day to achieve effective anticoagulation in this setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Add long-acting nitrate: While long-acting nitrates can help with angina symptoms, they are not the primary treatment for acute management in this scenario. The priority is to stabilize the patient and prevent further thrombotic events.

 

Option B. Increase metoprolol dose to 100mg BID: Increasing the dose of metoprolol may help with angina control, but it does not address the underlying risk of thrombus formation and is not the immediate next step in managing high-risk unstable angina.

 

Option C. Add clopidogrel 75mg OD: Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet agent that is beneficial in ACS, but in this acute setting, starting anticoagulation with enoxaparin takes precedence to prevent thrombus formation. Clopidogrel can be added as part of dual antiplatelet therapy later on.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

choices.text: Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

questions.text: What is the cause of the condition given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immersion in water for more than 36 hours

 

The above image shows washerwoman's feet/ washerwoman's skin. It is seen in a case of immersion in water (both antemortem as well as postmortem drowning). It denotes skin maceration or swelling and wrinkling of the skin due to water absorption. Following changes are seen in washerwoman skin:

 

  • Wrinkling: After 3 hrs of immersion
  • Soddening (filled with water): After 12 hrs of immersion
  • Bleaching (whitening): After 36 hrs of immersion
  • Peeling: after 72 hrs of immersion

 

In the image, bleaching can be seen

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic neuropathy: Diabetic neuropathy typically presents with sensory deficits, pain, or ulcers but does not cause the skin changes seen in the image.

 

Option B. Hanging: Hanging does not cause the specific wrinkling and bleaching of the skin seen in the image.

 

Option D. Burns of foot: Burns would result in charring, blistering, and other thermal injuries, not the wrinkling and bleaching seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Washerwoman's feet (or skin) is characterized by swelling, wrinkling, and bleaching due to prolonged immersion in water, typically observed after more than 36 hours.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contrast enhanced CT scan

 

  • The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a fall is suggestive of blunt renal trauma.
  • Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross hematuria, shock in combination with microscopic hematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.
  • A CECT is the investigation of choice for blunt renal trauma in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Contrast enhanced CT scan (CECT):  Correct. In cases of trauma, especially from a fall, a CECT scan provides detailed imaging of the abdomen, allowing the visualization of internal organs, blood vessels, and tissues. When there's a suspicion of renal trauma due to tenderness in the left lumbar region (location of the kidney), CECT can identify the presence and extent of the injury. In a hemodynamically stable patient (as indicated by the child's stable vital signs), CECT is the preferred diagnostic modality for blunt renal trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retrograde urethrogram: This is a radiographic study of the posterior urethra using a contrast agent. It's primarily used when there's a suspicion of urethral injury, typically indicated by symptoms like blood at the urethral meatus or an inability to urinate.

 

Option C. Wait and watch: This approach implies observation without immediate intervention or imaging. While "wait and watch" can be appropriate in some cases, the potential seriousness of blunt renal trauma (especially in a child) warrants a more proactive approach to accurately diagnose and manage the injury.

 

Option D. Emergency laparotomy: It's indicated in situations where there's significant internal injury, and immediate surgical intervention is required. While it's a possibility in cases of trauma, the child's stable vital signs suggest a more conservative diagnostic approach, like a CECT scan, should be performed first to determine the extent of injury before jumping to surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

questions.text: Leading questions are permitted during which kind of examination in court? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross examination 

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by an attorney, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Examination-in-chief: Leading questions are generally not allowed during examination-in-chief to prevent the lawyer from influencing the witness's testimony.

 

Option B. Direct examination: Similar to examination-in-chief, direct examination aims to elicit the witness's own account without leading questions.

 

Option D. Re-direct examination: Leading questions are also not allowed in re-direct examination, as the purpose is to clarify or rebut points raised during cross-examination.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in: 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in: 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes this?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Niacin

 

This is Casal’s necklace shown in picture, which occurs in Vitamin B3/ Niacin deficiency. Niacin can be formed in the body from amino acid tryptophan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine is an essential B-vitamin that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism. It helps the body convert food (carbohydrates) into energy (ATP). Thiamine is important for the proper functioning of nerves and muscles. Deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, which affect the nervous system.

 

Option C. Zinc: Zinc is a trace mineral that is crucial for the immune system, wound healing, and DNA synthesis. It also plays a role in maintaining a sense of taste and smell. Zinc deficiency can lead to impaired immune function, delayed wound healing, and other health issues. It is an essential nutrient for overall health.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Pyridoxine is another B-vitamin that is involved in various metabolic processes, including amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter synthesis. It plays a role in maintaining brain health and proper nerve function. Pyridoxine deficiency can lead to symptoms like anemia, nerve damage, and skin issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Niacin is another B-vitamin that is essential for various bodily functions. It plays a role in converting nutrients into energy, creating cholesterol and fats, repairing DNA, and acting as an antioxidant. Niacin is important for overall metabolic health. Severe niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which can have serious effects on the skin, digestive system, and nervous system.

 

Niacin deficiency can be caused by:

  • Dietary deficiency of tryptophan
  • Dietary deficiency Vitamin B2 and B6 deficiency
  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Hartnup’s disease

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

 

The hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and intact basement membrane are all suggestive of dysplasia.

 

Dysplasia is characterized by the loss in the uniformity of the individual cells and their architectural orientation.

 

The features of dysplasia include:

 

  • Pleomorphism
  • Hyperchromatic nuclei
  • High nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio
  • Increased mitotic figures

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carcinoma: In carcinoma, there is the invasion of the basement membrane.

 

Option C. Metaplasia: It refers to the replacement of one cell type with another type. It is almost always associated with tissue damage, repair, and regeneration. The most common epithelial metaplasia is columnar to squamous.

 

Option D. Hyperplasia: It refers to the increase in the number of cells in a tissue or organ. It can be physiologic or pathological. Enlargement of the female breast during pregnancy is physiologic hyperplasia. Endometrial hyperplasia is an example of pathological hyperplasia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

choices.text: Check shunt patency by nuclear study
Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap
Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture

questions.text: A young child with congenital hydrocephalus was treated with a successful ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt. Four months post surgical repair, the child presented with fever, nuchal rigidity, and irritability. You suspect meningitis. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blood culture and take CSF sample from shunt tap

 

The most appropriate next step for a child with a VP shunt who presents with symptoms suspicious for meningitis is to obtain blood cultures and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples from the shunt tap and/or lumbar puncture. It is important to diagnose and treat meningitis quickly in patients with VP shunts, as untreated meningitis can cause shunt malfunction and other complications.

 

The diagnosis of meningitis in a child with a VP shunt requires obtaining blood cultures and CSF samples. Blood cultures are needed to identify the causative organism, while CSF samples are used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the infection. CSF can be obtained either through a shunt tap or a lumbar puncture, depending on the child's clinical status and the availability of the appropriate resources.

 

VP shunt fluid is usually obtained from a reservoir that is easily accessible subcutaneously. After sterile preparation, the reservoir should be punctured with a 25-gauge needle. The risk of introducing infection is also low (4.1%).

 

 

Ventriculoperitoneal shunt:

 

 

A ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt is used to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CS) due to an obstruction in the normal outflow or there is a decreased absorption of the fluid.

 

Complications of the shunting procedure include the following:

 

  • Infection due to skin flora entering the shunt, usually from Staphylococcus epidermidis
  • Intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage
  • Shunt over drainage (slit ventricles)
  • Shunt nephritis
  • Shunt disconnection
  • Shunt obstruction
  • Inguinal hernia

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and watch: as the patient is showing features of complication, wait and watch will not be the appropriate answer.

 

Option B. Check shunt patency by nuclear study: we should check the patency of the shunt but as the patient is showing signs of meningitis we should do a CSF analysis by shunt tap.

 

Option C. Blood culture and take CSF sample by lumbar puncture: the main source of infection is from the shunt, so taking CSF sample from there is best.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best step for a child with a VP shunt showing signs of meningitis is to perform a blood culture and obtain a CSF sample from the shunt tap.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Medication overuse headache

 

Medication overuse headache (MOH) occurs in individuals who frequently use headache medications. The patient in this case has been experiencing headaches for six months and has been regularly using analgesics. The key indicator of MOH is the worsening of headaches with continued use of medication and improvement upon stopping the medication. This aligns with the patient's experience of increased headache severity for three days, which reduced once the analgesics were stopped.

 

MOH develops as a result of the brain becoming sensitized to the medication, leading to a rebound effect. This is a well-recognized phenomenon where the headache itself is caused by the frequent use of headache relief medication, leading to a cycle of medication use and headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension headache: Tension headaches are typically relieved by analgesics, not worsened. These headaches are often characterized by a feeling of a tight band around the head and can be managed effectively with over-the-counter pain relief medications. 

 

  • Acute Treatment: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or paracetamol are used to relieve pain.
  • Chronic Treatment: Tricyclic antidepressants, such as amitriptyline, are employed to manage chronic symptoms and reduce the recurrence of headaches.

 

Option C. Chronic migraine: Chronic migraines are managed with both acute treatments for individual attacks and preventive treatments to reduce the frequency and severity of the headaches. While chronic migraines can be debilitating, they generally improve with proper prophylaxis and do not worsen with the use of analgesics.

 

  • Treatment options include propranolol, topiramate, valproate, and monoclonal antibodies against CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide), such as erenumab. These are used to reduce the frequency and severity of migraine attacks.

 

Option D. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are severe, unilateral headaches that are treated with high-flow oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan during acute attacks. Preventive treatments include medications like verapamil. Analgesics are not typically the first-line treatment for cluster headaches and their use does not generally lead to worsening of the condition.

 

  • Acute Treatment: High-flow 100% oxygen inhalation or subcutaneous sumatriptan injections are recommended to alleviate the intense pain of acute cluster headache attacks.
  • Chronic Treatment: Verapamil is used for long-term management to prevent the frequency and intensity of cluster headache episodes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medication overuse headache is characterized by the worsening of headaches due to frequent use of headache medications, and improvement upon cessation of the medication. This phenomenon highlights the importance of managing headache disorders with appropriate treatments and avoiding overuse of analgesics.

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. What is the nature of the causative virus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped ss RNA

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of measles. Measles virus is a Paramyxovirus which is an enveloped, single-stranded RNA (S RNA) virus.

 

The onset of rashes after the development of Koplik spots that are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the inner aspect of the cheek at the level of premolars, with associated features of coryza, and conjunctivitis is suggestive of measles.

 

Measles: The virus has an incubation period of 8-12 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots. This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present. Patients can transmit infection 3 days before and 4-6 days after the onset of rash.

 

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are pathognomonic of measles. These are multinucleated giant cells formed by the fusion of infected cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Naked ss RNA: Incorrect because the measles virus is enveloped.

 

Option C. Naked ds RNA: No human viruses are known with a naked dsRNA genome.

 

Option D. Enveloped ds RNA: This combination does not apply to human pathogens in the context given (measles virus is ssRNA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles virus is characterized as an enveloped single-stranded RNA virus, notable for the unique clinical presentation of Koplik's spots, which precede the characteristic maculopapular rash. This distinguishing feature is essential for the clinical diagnosis of measles.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

 

Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

 

  • Indications for myomectomy in a woman with infertility and fibroid uterus include:
    • Submucous fibroids of any size/location as they interfere with fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
    • Intramural fibroids that:
      • Distort the endometrial cavity.
      • Are larger than 5 cm in size.
  • In this case, the patient has significant intramural fibroids (7x5 cm and 5x3 cm), making laparoscopic myomectomy the appropriate management to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GnRH analogues: GnRH analogues are not suitable for this patient as she is eager to conceive. These are typically used for temporary symptom relief or to shrink fibroids preoperatively, but not as a primary treatment for infertility in this scenario.

 

Option C. Artificial reproductive techniques: While ART could be considered in cases of bilateral tubal block, myomectomy should be done prior to potentially relieve the tubal block, improve ART outcomes, and enhance pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. Uterine artery embolization: This procedure is not indicated for women who wish to conceive as it can compromise uterine function and future fertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain that had been ongoing for the past 24 hours. He reported that he had been consuming alcohol heavily for the past few weeks. The physical examination revealed tenderness in the upper abdomen with no visible signs of jaundice. Pancreatitis was suspected, and a CT scan was performed, which revealed lesions with fluid collected near the body of the pancreas. The patient was started on appropriate treatment, and blood tests were ordered to help diagnose the condition. Which enzyme is most likely to be elevated in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serum lipase

 

  • An alcoholic patient with acute pancreatitis is most likely to have elevated serum lipase levels.
  •  Clinical findings and elevated pancreatic enzymes in the plasma are used to diagnose acute pancreatitis.
  • Lipase is a more sensitive and specific marker of acute pancreatitis than amylase, which can be elevated in other conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum GGT : GGT (Gamma-glutamyltransferase) is an enzyme primarily found in the liver. It is an important marker for liver disease, especially conditions associated with bile duct obstruction. Elevated GGT would not specifically indicate pancreatitis.

 

Option B. CEA : CEA (Carcinoembryonic antigen) is a tumor marker, primarily used to monitor certain types of cancers, particularly colorectal cancer. It can be elevated in some pancreatic cancers as well, but it's not specifically used to diagnose or monitor acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Serum bilirubin: Bilirubin is a product of red blood cell breakdown and is processed by the liver. Elevated serum bilirubin levels can indicate liver disease or a blockage of the bile duct, which can be due to a stone, tumor, or other causes. In the context of pancreatitis, elevated bilirubin can be seen in biliary pancreatitis when a gallstone obstructs the common bile duct, but it's not a specific marker for pancreatitis itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serum lipase is the most specific enzyme for diagnosing acute pancreatitis, especially in cases related to alcohol consumption.
  •  It rises within 12 to 24 hours of pancreatic injury and remains elevated for 7-14 days, making it a crucial diagnostic marker for this condition.

questions.text: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody (ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Systemic sclerosis

 

Systemic sclerosis, also known as scleroderma, is characterized by fibrosis and tightening of the skin, particularly on the face and extremities. The presence of numbness in the fingertips is often due to Raynaud's phenomenon, which is common in systemic sclerosis and results from vasospasm and ischemia.

 

The positive ANA test with a nucleolar pattern is highly suggestive of systemic sclerosis. This pattern is seen in more than 95% of patients with scleroderma. Specific antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis include anti-centromere antibodies (often found in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis) and anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies (associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sjogren's syndrome: Sjogren's syndrome primarily affects exocrine glands, leading to dry eyes and mouth. It can also present with positive ANA, but the nucleolar pattern is not typically associated with Sjogren's. The physical findings of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not characteristic of Sjogren's syndrome.

 

Option C. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can present with a wide range of symptoms and often includes positive ANA. However, the nucleolar pattern is less common in SLE. The characteristic features of SLE include malar rash, arthritis, and serositis, which are not described in this case.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, causing chronic inflammatory polyarthritis. While ANA can be positive in rheumatoid arthritis, the nucleolar pattern and symptoms of skin tightening and fingertip numbness are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Systemic sclerosis (scleroderma) is associated with positive ANA with a nucleolar pattern, skin tightening, and symptoms like Raynaud's phenomenon. This combination of clinical findings and specific antibody patterns helps in diagnosing systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal hemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Takayasu arteritis

 

Takayasu arteritis, also known as "pulseless disease," is a large vessel vasculitis that primarily affects the aorta and its major branches. It is more common in young Asian females under 40 years old. The clinical presentation includes claudication (typically in the upper limbs due to subclavian artery involvement), weak pulses (particularly in the extremities), and symptoms resulting from ischemia in various organs (e.g., transient loss of vision due to carotid or vertebral artery involvement, abdominal pain due to mesenteric artery involvement).

 

The combination of weak femoral pulses, claudication in the forearm, and retinal hemorrhages is characteristic of Takayasu arteritis. This condition can lead to narrowing or occlusion of major arteries, causing diminished blood flow to the affected regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a medium vessel vasculitis that can cause abdominal pain, claudication, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically affect the large vessels and therefore would not explain the weak femoral pulses. PAN is often associated with hepatitis B infection.

 

Option B. Thromboangiitis obliterans: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) typically affects young male smokers and primarily involves the small and medium arteries of the extremities. It can cause claudication and ischemic symptoms in the limbs but does not typically cause weak femoral pulses or retinal hemorrhages.

 

Option D. Microscopic polyangiitis: Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) is a small vessel vasculitis that often presents with symptoms related to kidney and lung involvement (e.g., rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage). It does not typically present with claudication or weak pulses in the large vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takayasu arteritis should be considered in young women presenting with symptoms of large vessel occlusion, such as claudication, weak pulses, and ischemic symptoms in various organs. It is characterized by the involvement of the aorta and its major branches, and the diagnosis can be confirmed with imaging studies like CT angiogram or conventional angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following can be prescribed in case of an open angle glaucoma with bronchial asthma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Latanoprost is a Prostaglandin, PGF2α analog, that acts in glaucoma by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor and is used as a first line drug in patients with open angle glaucoma. It can be safely used in bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker that can cause bronchospasm as a systemic side effect. Therefore, it is not recommended for patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option B. Gemeprost: Gemeprost is a prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) analog used for the termination of pregnancy. It is not relevant for the treatment of glaucoma.

 

Option D. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma, not open-angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin F2α analog, is safe and effective for the treatment of open-angle glaucoma in patients with bronchial asthma, as it does not cause bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall from height. The patient reports no pain or injury, but on examination, there is blood at the tip of the urethral meatus. The patient is hemodynamically stable with no other injuries. The next step in management would be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ascending urethrogram

 

  • The clinical scenario suggests a suspected urethral injury with blood at the urethral meatus, which is commonly caused by external trauma or instrumentation.
  •  To confirm urethral rupture, the next step would be an ascending urethrogram.
  • Ascending urethrogram: Correct. In a patient who is hemodynamically stable and without symptoms of a full bladder, retrograde urethrography will help determine the extent of the injury and decide on the next appropriate steps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheterization: In the setting of suspected urethral injury, as evidenced by the presence of blood at the tip of the urethral meatus, inserting a Foley catheter can be harmful. It could potentially exacerbate the injury or convert a partial tear into a complete one. Hence, this is contraindicated without first confirming the integrity of the urethra.

 

Option C. Nephrogram: A nephrogram is an imaging study of the kidneys and their function. While it can give details about the upper urinary tract, it's not typically used for evaluating urethral injuries.

 

Option D. Suprapubic cystostomy: Suprapubic cystostomy, or suprapubic catheter placement, involves inserting a catheter directly into the bladder through the abdominal wall. It's done to divert urine when urethral catheterization is not possible or contraindicated, such as in the setting of a known or suspected urethral injury. This will be attempted after an urethrogram confirms a rupture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To confirm urethral rupture in a patient with suspected urethral injury, an ascending urethrogram is the next step in management.
  • Foley's catheterization should be avoided as it may exacerbate the injury.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is undergoing evaluation for successive recurrent pregnancy losses. On ultrasound, a Mullerian anomaly is suspected. What is the BEST way to confirm this? (NEET PF 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy

 

Explanation:

 

Hysteroscopy + laparoscopy:

 

  • Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy is considered the best invasive method to confirm the diagnosis of Mullerian anomalies. This approach allows direct visualization of both the internal and external contours of the uterus.
  • During the procedure, hysteroscopy can evaluate the endometrial cavity, while laparoscopy can assess the external uterine surface and other pelvic structures.
  • This combination not only confirms the diagnosis but also allows for simultaneous corrective surgery, if necessary (e.g., resecting a uterine septum).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hysterosalpingography: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is a useful imaging technique for evaluating the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. However, it may not provide detailed information about the external contour of the uterus or distinguish between certain types of Mullerian anomalies.

 

Option C. Laparoscopy: While laparoscopy alone can provide information about the external structure of the uterus and other pelvic organs, it does not allow for direct visualization of the endometrial cavity. Combining it with hysteroscopy gives a more comprehensive assessment.

 

Option D. Transvaginal sonography: Transvaginal sonography (TVS) is a non-invasive imaging technique that can detect many uterine anomalies. However, it may not be as definitive as hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, especially for complex anomalies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The best way to confirm a suspected Mullerian anomaly is through hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy, which allows for a comprehensive assessment and potential simultaneous treatment.

 

Ref: Page no 32, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Countertransference

 

Countertransference refers to the therapist's emotional reactions, both conscious and unconscious, towards a patient, often influenced by the therapist's own past.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transference: Transference is when the patient unconsciously redirects feelings experienced in an earlier relationship to the therapist.

 

Option C. Dissociation: Dissociation is a disconnection and lack of continuity between thoughts, memories, surroundings, actions, and identity.

 

Option D. Dissociation: Preoccupation is being absorbed in thought, typically about something particular.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Transference refers to the redirection of a patient's feelings and attitudes from past experiences or individuals onto the therapist, typically operating on an unconscious level. Countertransference represents the therapist's emotional reactions to a patient, both conscious and unconscious. These reactions may be influenced by the therapist's own personal history, unresolved conflicts, or reactions to the patient's transference.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 1069

questions.text: A bubonic outbreak has occurred within the community. What is the responsible vector for this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Xenopsylla cheopis

 

Xenopsylla cheopis, commonly known as a rat flea, serves as the carrier for the bubonic plague. This particular flea species can be recognized by its distinctive conical-shaped head, along with a thorax, abdomen, and three sets of legs.


 

  • Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis.
  • The reservoir of infections is wild rodents.
  • Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague.
  • Human plague mainly presents as:

 

 

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. There is fever along with painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes.

 

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague.

 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to blood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Species Phlebotomus argentipes: belongs to the group of sand fly. It transmits kala azar. Other diseases transmitted by sand flies are sandfly fever and oriental sore.

 

Option C. Ixodes Tick: transmits Lyme’s disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito transmits malaria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xenopsylla cheopis (rat flea) is the primary vector responsible for transmitting the bubonic plague, caused by Yersinia pestis. Understanding the vector and transmission routes is crucial for controlling and preventing outbreaks.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

 

The scenario describes a case of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), which can occur after the administration of local anesthetics like bupivacaine. LAST can cause severe cardiovascular and central nervous system toxicity, leading to symptoms such as seizures, coma, and cardiovascular collapse, as seen in this patient.

 

The management of LAST involves:

 

  1. Immediate initiation of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) if the patient is unresponsive and pulseless.
