  2. Administration of 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid). This treatment, known as lipid rescue or lipid emulsion therapy, acts by creating a "lipid sink" that absorbs the local anesthetic from the tissues and blood, reducing its toxic effects on the heart and brain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CPR & Calcium gluconate: Calcium gluconate is not the primary treatment for local anesthetic toxicity. It is used in cases of hyperkalemia or calcium channel blocker overdose.

 

Option C. CPR & Start Dobutamine infusion: While dobutamine can support cardiac function, it is not specific for treating local anesthetic toxicity and does not address the underlying cause.

 

Option D. CPR & Start NaHCO3 infusion: Sodium bicarbonate is used to treat metabolic acidosis and certain poisonings, such as tricyclic antidepressant overdose, but it is not specific for local anesthetic toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

questions.text: What is the active principle of the poison shown in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bhilawanol

 

  • The above image shows the seeds of Semicarpus anacardium
  • Identification: Black, heart-shaped seeds with a rough projection at the base
  • Active principles: bhilawanol and semicarpol.
  • Common name: Marking nut
  • Uses of the juice:
    • To produce an artificial bruise.
    • Juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ricin: Ricin is a highly toxic protein found in the seeds of the castor oil plant (Ricinus communis).

 

Option C. Abrin: Abrin is a toxic protein found in the seeds of the rosary pea (Abrus precatorius).

 

Option D. Calotropin: Calotropin is a cardiac glycoside found in the milkweed plant (Calotropis gigantea).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The active principle of the marking nut (Semicarpus anacardium) is Bhilawanol, used in traditional practices for its staining and toxic properties.

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

 

Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1

 

  • SGLT-1 is a transporter protein located in the small intestine. It plays a crucial role in the absorption of glucose and sodium from the gut lumen into the enterocytes (intestinal cells). In the context of ORS, SGLT-1 facilitates the absorption of glucose, which helps in the rehydration process by increasing fluid absorption.

 

Glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell via secondary active transport using sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT-1). On the other hand, the glucose from the intestine cell in to blood at basolateral membrane is transported via passive transporter GLUT-2 (see fig)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-2 (Sodium-Glucose Transporter 2): SGLT-2 is primarily found in the proximal renal tubules of the kidney and is responsible for the reabsorption of glucose from the urine. It is not involved in the absorption of glucose from the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. GLUT-4 (Glucose Transporter 4): GLUT-4 is a glucose transporter primarily found in muscle and adipose tissue. It is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into these tissues and is not related to glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. GLUT-2 (Glucose Transporter 2): GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter found in the liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the basolateral membrane of enterocytes. It is involved in glucose uptake by the liver and pancreas and is not the primary transporter for glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-1 is the key transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose in the gastrointestinal tract. This mechanism is crucial in the management of conditions like diarrhea, where ORS containing glucose can help rehydrate the body by enhancing fluid absorption.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 538

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inj. methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option B. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option C. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

 

Reference: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884912/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

questions.text: Identify the type of injury from the picture given below: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incised looking lacerated wound

 

The image shows a lacerated wound which looks like incised wound. This is also called “Incised looking lacerated wound”. They occur at bony sites where there is thin subcutaneous tissue like Scalp, forehead, Zygoma, Iliac crest, Shin etc.

 

They can be differentiated from incised wounds by following:

 

  1. Due to blunt force, there is usually associated abrasions and contusions in the margins
  2. Depth of the wound presents bridges of irregularly torn tissue, blood vessels and nerves, etc.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Laceration: Irregular tear-like wounds caused by blunt trauma. They often have jagged edges and may have tissue bridges at the base. The wound in the image appears cleaner and more linear, resembling an incised wound, making it an incised looking lacerated wound.

 

Option B. Incised wound: Clean, straight cuts typically caused by sharp instruments such as knives or glass. The wound in the image is caused by blunt force and has characteristics of a laceration, despite its appearance.

 

Option C. Lacerated looking incised wound:  In areas where skin folds are loose, like in axilla, scrotum etc, the shapes are zigzag type. So, although it is produced by sharp weapon but it looks like lacerated wound. Such wounds are sometimes called as lacerated looking incised wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An incised looking lacerated wound is caused by blunt force trauma but appears similar to an incised wound due to its location and the characteristics of the tissue involved.

choices.text: History of similar illness in the past

questions.text: A man from Chhattisgarh presented with a gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms in his legs. Upon examination, he exhibited a specific loss of motor function. What inquiries should be made to gather the most relevant medical history from this patient? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) History of diet

 

  • The clinical presentation suggests that the patient may have neurolathyrism, which is caused by the excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal.
  • To confirm the diagnosis, it is important to obtain the patient's dietary history.
  • Neurolathyrism is a paralytic condition caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus or Khesari dal, which is common in certain regions of India such as Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, and Bihar.
  • The disease mainly affects the nervous system, causing gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs. It primarily affects males between the ages of 15 and 45 years and progresses through several stages.
  • The toxin responsible for the disease is BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine), which is water-soluble and can be removed from the pulses by soaking them in hot water and discarding the water.
  • Large-scale detoxification can be achieved by parboiling the crop, or by overnight soaking in lime water followed by boiling.
  • Vitamin C in doses of 500-1000mg can help prevent and treat lathyrism.
  • In India, the Prevention of Food Adulteration Act prohibits the use of Lathyrus sativus in any form (whole/split/flour).

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intermediate filaments

 

The clinical scenario given here describes alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments.

 

i) Hepatocellular necrosis:

 

ii) Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline:

 

These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions found in swollen and ballooned hepatocytes. They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin). They are best seen with connective tissue stains such as Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, as well as immunoperoxidase methods.

 

Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis, as they can be found in a variety of other conditions, including primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

iii) Inflammatory response: primarily polymorphs with some scattered mononuclear cells.

 

iv) Fibrosis: Pericellular and perivenular fibrosis that appears web-like or chickenwire-like. This is also termed as creeping collagenosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Actin: Actin is a type of microfilament found in the cytoskeleton of cells, but it is not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option C. Microtubules: Microtubules are another component of the cytoskeleton, but they are not the primary component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Option  D. Fibronectin: Fibronectin is a high-molecular-weight glycoprotein of the extracellular matrix that binds to membrane-spanning receptor proteins such as integrins. It is not a component of Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In chronic alcoholic patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Mallory-Denk bodies are a characteristic histopathological finding. These intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions consist of aggregated cytoskeletal intermediate filaments, specifically prekeratin.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child complains of mild painful swelling over the scalp for 3 months as shown in the image below. He also has a pet dog at his home. What is the diagnosis of the given condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Kerion

 

  • The case of a young boy coming into contact with a zoophilic organism and displaying symptoms of a boggy inflammatory mass, accompanied by thick crusting and matting of hair, indicates a possible diagnosis of kerion.
  • Kerion is an intense inflammatory form of tinea capitis, caused by dermatophytes that have an affinity for animals (pet dog clue).

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: Boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms - T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount

 

Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum à Griseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton à Terbinafine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furuncle:

  • Description: Also known as a boil, a furuncle is a deep folliculitis, an infection of the hair follicle.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Furuncles are typically more localized and painful and would not be described as "boggy." Also, they don’t have a direct association with having a pet dog.

 

Option B. Epidermoid cyst:

  • Description: These are benign cysts originating from the epidermis. They are filled with keratin and have a characteristic central punctum as seen in the image below.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Epidermoid cysts are typically non-painful unless infected. They do not usually present as boggy swellings and are not related to having a pet.

 

Option D. Folliculitis:

  • Description: Folliculitis is the inflammation or infection of one or more hair follicles.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: Folliculitis on the scalp would typically present as multiple small, itchy, and red pustules. It wouldn't create a boggy swelling as described in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kerion is a boggy, tender scalp swelling associated with hair loss and potentially linked to animal exposure, indicative of a fungal infection rather than a bacterial cause like furuncle or folliculitis, or a benign lesion such as an epidermoid cyst.

 

Reference: 

 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 26.22, 26.23-26.24, 32.38, 32.39, 32.40, 90.27, 108.11

questions.text: A child presented with pharyngitis. A swab was taken from his throat and sent for culture testing. After using the swab, which color-coded bin should it be disposed into? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Yellow

 

Used throat swabs are considered soiled waste, which typically includes items contaminated with blood, body fluids, secretions, and excretions. According to biomedical waste management protocols, such items should be disposed of in yellow bins.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent nephrectomy. Which of the following can be administered as a postoperative analgesic in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acetaminophen

 

In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD), nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like naproxen, indomethacin, and diclofenac are generally avoided due to their potential to worsen renal function. These medications inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which can lead to renal vasoconstriction and further decline in kidney function.

 

Acetaminophen (paracetamol), on the other hand, is generally considered safer for patients with CKD when used at appropriate doses. It has a different mechanism of action (inhibit COX3) and does not significantly affect renal hemodynamics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naproxen: Naproxen is an NSAID that can significantly impair renal function, especially in patients with pre-existing kidney disease. It should be avoided in this population due to the risk of worsening kidney function and potential for causing renal failure.

 

Option B. Indomethacin: Indomethacin is another NSAID with similar risks to naproxen. Its use can lead to decreased renal perfusion and exacerbate renal impairment, making it unsuitable for patients with CKD.

 

Option C. Diclofenac: Diclofenac, like other NSAIDs, poses a significant risk to kidney function in patients with CKD. It can reduce prostaglandin synthesis, leading to renal vasoconstriction and further renal impairment, and should be avoided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetaminophen is the preferred postoperative analgesic for patients with chronic kidney disease, as it does not significantly affect renal function and is safer than NSAIDs in this population.

questions.text: A man running a 40-kilometre marathon on a hot summer afternoon suddenly collapsed before completing his race. On examination, his body temperature was 104 degrees, but there were no physical signs of dehydration. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sweating

 

The case scenario is suggestive of a heatstroke in this patient. Heatstroke / heat exhaustion occurs when the body can no longer control its temperature. The body's temperature rises rapidly, the sweating mechanism fails, and the body is unable to cool down. When heat stroke occurs, the body temperature can rise to 106°F or higher within 10 to 15 minutes.

 

In this case it is due to prolonged exposure to the sun during running.

 

Management - Rapidly cooling the body with cold blankets till temperature falls below 102 degrees Celsius.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hot skin: Likely to be present due to the high body temperature in heatstroke.

 

Option B. Hypotension: Can be seen due to vasodilation and possible dehydration.

 

Option D. Disorientation: Likely due to neurological dysfunction caused by the extreme heat affecting the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Name the parasite whose microfilaria have a sheath with no nuclei at the tail end. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wuchereria bancrofti

 

A sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti.

 

Wuchereria bancrofti causes lymphatic filariasis and most cases are seen in India.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Massive eosinophilia
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Pulmonary manifestations like dry nocturnal cough, asthmatic wheezing, and dyspnea
  • It can also cause arthritis, glomerulonephritis, thrombophlebitis, etc
  • The classical features seen in lvmphatic filariasis are usually absent.
  • Elephantiasis - It refers to the painful swelling of the legs and genital organs seen in late-stage disease.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brugia malayi and Option C. Brugia timori: Also cause lymphatic filariasis but have different morphological features in their microfilariae.

 

Option D. Mansonella perstans: Causes a different form of filariasis and has microfilariae that also have different characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microfilariae of Wuchereria bancrofti are identified by their sheathed structure and the absence of nuclei at the tail end, crucial for the specific diagnosis of lymphatic filariasis caused by this parasite. This detail is significant for medical students and professionals working in endemic areas to recognize and diagnose the infection accurately.

questions.text: A 6-months-old child presented with cyanosis and fatigue. His chest X ray is shown below. What is the most likely sign and diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Snowman sign, Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Explanation:

 

The given X-ray shows a case of total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation (TAPVC) with figure of 8 or snowman or cottage-loaf appearance.

 

TAPVC:

 

  • TAPVC is a condition in which pulmonary veins drain directly or indirectly into the right atrium rather than the left atrium. As a result, pulmonary venous blood flow drains abnormally into the systemic venous circulation.
  • It is a cyanotic heart disease with congestive heart failure symptoms. The patients are irritable and failure to thrive.

 

The following types are seen:

 

I. Supra cardiac – Most common type

II. Cardiac

III. Infra cardiac – Most common type for obstruction (worst prognosis)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cottage loaf, truncus arteriosus: Truncus arteriosus involves a single arterial trunk coming from the heart, not typically showing a snowman sign.

 

Option C. Egg on side, TGA (Transposition of the Great Arteries): This condition typically shows an "egg on a string" appearance due to the abnormal positioning of the great arteries.

 

Option D. Boot shaped heart, TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot): Characterized by a boot-shaped heart on X-ray due to right ventricular hypertrophy; not the pattern observed in this image.'

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "snowman sign" on a chest X-ray in a child presenting with cyanosis and fatigue is highly suggestive of Supracardiac TAPVC.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with complaints of progressive loss of vision in the right halves of both eyes. Where is the lesion located in the optic pathway? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left optic tract

 

The patient presenting with progressive visual loss in the right halves of both eyes is suggestive of right homonymous hemianopia. The site of the lesion in this case is the left optic tract.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right visual cortex: Lesions in the right visual cortex would cause left homonymous hemianopia, not right. The visual cortex processes information from the contralateral visual field.

 

Option C. Optic chiasma: Lesions in the optic chiasma typically cause bitemporal hemianopia, which is the loss of the outer (temporal) visual fields in both eyes. This is due to the crossing fibers from the nasal retinas.

 

Option D. Right optic nerve: A lesion in the right optic nerve would cause vision loss in the right eye only, not in both eyes. It would not result in a homonymous visual field defect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Right homonymous hemianopia, characterized by loss of the right visual field in both eyes, is caused by a lesion in the left optic tract.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with pain in the right thigh during walking. Investigation reveals a finding as shown below. What will be the most appropriate surgical management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aortofemoral bypass

 

  • Pain in the thigh while walking and MR angiography showing right common iliac artery non-visualisation suggest peripheral obstructive vascular disease with right common iliac obstruction.
  •  As the disease progresses, rest pain, ulceration, and gangrene may occur.
  • Aortofemoral bypass surgery is a procedure to create a new route for blood flow to the lower extremities by bypassing the blocked segment of the aorta and/or the common iliac arteries.
  • A graft (DACRON), which is typically made from a synthetic material, is used to create this new route.
  •  The graft is sutured proximally to the aorta and distally to the femoral arteries.
  •  Given the scenario where there is obstruction of the common iliac artery and the patient is experiencing pain in the thigh during walking, which is suggestive of claudication due to iliac disease, the aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PTA with stenting: PTA (Percutaneous Transluminal Angioplasty) involves the insertion of a catheter through the skin and into the obstructed artery. The catheter has a tiny balloon at its tip which, once in place, is inflated to widen the artery and restore blood flow. A stent (a tiny mesh tube) is then placed in the newly opened artery to help keep it open. This minimally invasive procedure is ideal for certain short segment and localized obstructions, but might not be the first choice for larger (as seen in the image) or more complicated obstructions.

 

Option B. Femoro-iliac bypass: This surgical procedure reroutes blood flow around a blocked or narrowed iliac artery by creating a bypass using a graft that connects the femoral artery to the iliac artery. It's more localized than an aortofemoral bypass, focusing on the connection between the femoral and iliac arteries in external iliac blocks.

 

Option D. Femoro-popliteal bypass: This procedure is done for distal femoral blocks, which is not the issue described in this patient's case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aortofemoral bypass is the most appropriate surgical intervention for peripheral obstructive vascular disease involving the common iliac artery, particularly when the obstruction is significant and causing symptoms such as claudication.
  •  This procedure helps to restore adequate blood flow to the lower extremities.

questions.text: A contact lens user presents with the following clinical picture. He has had watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in the eye for the past 2 months. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Giant papillary conjunctivitis

 

  • The clinical history of watering, redness, and foreign body sensation in a contact lens user, along with the image showing giant papillae in the conjunctiva, suggests a probable diagnosis of giant papillary conjunctivitis.
  • Giant papillary conjunctivitis is the inflammation of conjunctiva with formation of very large sized papillae.
  • Etiology - It is a localized allergic response to a physically rough or deposited surface (contact lens, prosthesis, left out nylon sutures).
  • Symptoms - Itching, stringy discharge and reduced wearing time of contact lens or prosthetic shell.
  • Signs - Papillary hypertrophy (1 mm in diameter) of the upper tarsal conjunctiva with hyperemia. Focal apical ulceration and whitish scarring may develop on larger papillae. Papillae are reddish, flat-topped, raised areas that give a red and velvety appearance to the tarsal conjunctiva.
  • Treatment:
    1. The offending cause should be removed. After discontinuation of contact lens or artificial eye or removal of nylon sutures, the papillae resolve over a period of one month.
    2. Disodium cromoglycate is known to relieve the symptoms and enhance the rate of resolution.
    3. Steroids are not of much use in this condition.

 

Other Options:

                                        

Option A. In acute trachoma, sago-like follicles are characteristically seen. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The SAFE strategy is used in the management of trachoma.

 

The image below shows sago-like follicles in trachoma.

 

 

Option B. It is an acute catarrhal conjunctivitis associated with marked follicular hyperplasia especially of the lower fornix and lower palpebral conjunctiva. Follicles are greyish-white raised areas on fornices and palpebral conjunctiva. These are formed due to the localized aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. It is most commonly caused by herpes and adenoviruses.

 

The image shows follicles.

 

 

Option D. Spring catarrh is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to some exogenous allergen, such as grass pollens. It is more common during summer. Cobblestone appearance (which is a papillary reaction in the palpebral conjunctiva), ropy discharge, and Maxwell-Lyon sign are present. Horner-Trantas spots that are discrete, whitish, raised dots along the limbus can also be seen.

 

The image below shows Horner-Trantas spots.

 

 

Pseudogerontoxon - Pseudogerontoxon is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis or gerontoxon and is seen in many individuals with limbal vernal or atopic keratoconjunctivitis. It is an important clinical finding because pseudogerontoxon is often times the only clinical evidence of previous allergic eye disease.

 

 

Shield Ulcer- Localized oval or pentagonal lesion in upper cornea.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Giant papillary conjunctivitis is characterized by the presence of large papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, often due to a localized allergic response to contact lenses or other foreign bodies.

questions.text: Which vaccine is administered as part of the immunization program to a 10-year-old school child? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) TT/Td

 

  • Based on the situation provided, a ten-year-old student is recommended to receive the TT/Td vaccine as per the National Immunization Schedule.
  • The Td vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria vaccines, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen, and is recommended for older children and adults.
  • The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MoHFW) advises the use of Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is injected into the upper arm muscle. This vaccine is given at the age of 10 and 16.
  • For pregnant women, Td-1 is given early in pregnancy and Td-2 is given 4 weeks after Td-1. A Td booster shot is recommended if a pregnancy occurs within 3 years of the last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were previously received.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NEW National Immunization Schedule (NIS) 2023-24

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G2P1

 

2 formulas

 

1. G __ P __ L __ A ___

 

  • Gravida (G): The number of times a woman has conceived including the present pregnancy irrespective of the gestational age or the outcome.
  • Para (P): The number of times a pregnancy has crossed the period of viability (taken as 28 weeks for all practical purposes) EXCLUDING the present pregnancy.
  • Living (L): The total number of living children the woman has.
  • Abortion (A): The total number of times the pregnancy has resulted in an abortion/ pregnancy has not crossed the period of viability.

 

IMPORTANT: A Twin pregnancy which has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1 NOT Para 2. If it results in 2 living children, it will be Live 2.

 

2. P A-B-C-D (A: term; B: preterm; C: abortions; D: Living)

 

  • This is another way to write the formula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. G2P2: Incorrect because the woman has had only one previous pregnancy that reached viability, not two.

 

Option C. G3P1: Incorrect because this implies three pregnancies, but she is currently in her second pregnancy.

 

Option D. G3P2: Incorrect because this implies she has had three pregnancies and two have reached viability, which is not the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A twin pregnancy that has crossed the period of viability is considered as Para 1, not Para 2. If it results in two living children, it will be Live 2.

 

Ref: Page no 469, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with slowly progressive motor weakness, nuchal rigidity, and difficulty in swallowing and carrying out day-to-day activities. A provisional diagnosis of multiple sclerosis is suspected. Which of the following cells are affected in multiple sclerosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Oligodendrocytes

 

Explanation

 

Oligodendrocytes are affected in multiple sclerosis.

 

In multiple sclerosis (MS), myelin-forming oligodendrocytes (OLGs) are the targets of inflammatory and immune attacks. OLG death by apoptosis or necrosis causes the cell loss seen in MS plaques, and leads to loss of conduction or delayed conduction in the demyelinated axons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Microglia. are the primary immune cells of the central nervous system, similar to peripheral macrophages.

 

Option C. Astrocytes. also known collectively as astroglia, are characteristic star-shaped glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. They perform many functions, including biochemical control of endothelial cells that form the blood–brain barrier.

 

Option D. Ependymal cells. are ciliated-epithelial glial cells that develop from radial glia along the surface of the ventricles of the brain and the spinal canal. They play a critical role in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) homeostasis, brain metabolism, and the clearance of waste from the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In multiple sclerosis, the primary pathological change occurs in oligodendrocytes, the cells responsible for myelinating neurons in the CNS. This leads to widespread neurological impairment due to the loss of myelin, affecting the efficiency of nerve signal transmission.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start LMWH.
Stop warfarin and start heparin.
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy 4mg/ day. What is the appropriate next step in management. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH.

 

Explanation:

 

Stop warfarin and start LMWH: Warfarin is teratogenic and has a significant risk of causing warfarin embryopathy, particularly in doses greater than 5mg per day. In pregnancy, it is recommended to change warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) in the first trimester, especially if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/day. After 13 weeks, it can be switched back to warfarin until delivery. Near delivery, warfarin should again be replaced by LMWH or UFH to manage the risk of bleeding complications during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: This option is partially correct as it aligns with the practice of switching from warfarin to a safer anticoagulant near delivery. However, the preferred anticoagulant in this situation is LMWH due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and ease of administration.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: This is incorrect because continuing warfarin at 36 weeks of gestation poses significant risks of fetal hemorrhage and warfarin embryopathy. It is essential to switch to a safer anticoagulant like LMWH or UFH close to delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: While this option includes stopping warfarin and starting LMWH, which is correct, the addition of aspirin is only indicated in women who are at a very high risk of thrombosis. The general recommendation does not include aspirin unless there is a specific high-risk indication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin should be replaced by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) near delivery to manage the risks associated with its teratogenic effects and potential complications during delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 2404, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is diagnosed with pure red cell aplasia and a mediastinal mass. Which of the following can be the likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thymoma

 

Thymoma is the most likely diagnosis for the clinical presentation of a mediastinal mass with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Pure red cell aplasia (PRCA) is a rare syndrome characterized by a selective failure of erythroid element production in the bone marrow but normal granulopoiesis and megakaryocytopoiesis.

 

The patients have normocytic normochromic anemia, with normal granulocyte and platelet counts. Reticulocytes are significantly reduced or absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin lymphoma:

 

Association: While lymphomas can present as mediastinal masses and may cause cytopenias, they are not specifically associated with pure red cell aplasia.

 

Option C. Bronchogenic Carcinoma:

 

Association: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with respiratory symptoms and does not have a known association with PRCA.

 

Option D. Germ cell tumor:

 

Association: Germ cell tumors can present as mediastinal masses but are not specifically linked to PRCA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thymoma is the most likely cause of a mediastinal mass in a patient with pure red cell aplasia. PRCA is characterized by a selective deficiency of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to severe anemia with normal granulocyte and platelet counts, and is often associated with thymoma.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. What is the enrichment medium used to isolate the organism from the stool sample? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Selenite F broth

 

The given clinical vignette of dysentery (bloody stools) and abdominal pain in a child is suggestive of bacillary dysentery most likely caused due to Shigella. Selenite F broth is used as an enrichment media for dysentery-causing bacteria like Shigella/ Salmonella.

 

Enrichment media:

 

It is used to suppress commensal bacteria while allowing the pathogen to remain viable and grow. Common examples include:

 

  • Tetrathionate broth - It inhibits coliforms and allows typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli to grow.
  • Selenite F broth - used for dysentery causing bacteria.
  • Alkaline peptone water (Option-B) - used for vibrio cholera causing watery diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Robertson cooked meat broth: This medium is primarily used for the cultivation of anaerobic bacteria, not typically involved in cases of dysentery.

 

Option B. Alkaline peptone water: This is used for the enrichment of Vibrio species, particularly in cases suspected of cholera, which typically presents with watery diarrhea rather than bloody stools.

 

Option D. Brain heart infusion broth: It is an enriched media. It is used for the cultivation of fastidious organisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Selenite F broth is specifically used as an enrichment medium for isolating Shigella from stool samples in cases presenting with symptoms of dysentery, characterized by blood in the stools. This selective medium helps in the effective recovery of pathogens responsible for dysentery, aiding in accurate diagnosis and appropriate treatment.

 

Dysentery/Shigellosis is a type of food poisoning caused by infection with the Shigella species. It is spread through faeco-oral transmission. They are catalase-negative, non-lactose-fermenting, gram-negative rods, and are non-motile. It acts by inactivating the 60s ribosomal subunit thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. It causes acute onset of symptoms (fever, abdominal cramps) with dysentery and tenesmus. It also gives a positive Sereny test.

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukemia

 

Benzene exposure at work increases the risk of developing leukemia. The clinical history of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening temperature rise with benzene exposure points to leukemia.

 

Hepatic CYP2E1 converts benzene to an epoxide. The epoxide and other metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, resulting in marrow aplasia and acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), multiple myeloma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma have all been linked to benzene exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung Cancer: Exposure to arsenic and its compounds, asbestos, beryllium and its compounds, chromium compounds, nickel compounds, radon, and its decay products can cause lung cancer.

 

Option C. Bladder Cancer: Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-naphthylamine and related compounds, cyclophosphamide, cigarette smoking, irradiation can cause bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Skin Cancer: Exposure to UV rays, arsenic, and its compounds can cause skin cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: A patient presents incidentally with the following findings as shown below. He does not report any discomfort. According to the CEAP classification, what will be the C stage in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C2A

 

  • Given the scenario showing asymptomatic varicose veins, it corresponds to C2a in the CEAP classification system.
  • C2A: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are asymptomatic (suffix A).
  • The CEAP classification system is used to categorize varicose veins based on their clinical characteristics.
  • The acronym stands for Clinical, Etiologic, Anatomic, and Pathophysiologic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C2S: Represents varicose veins (C2) that are symptomatic (suffix S), meaning the patient would experience symptoms like pain, aching, swelling, or other discomforts. Since the patient reports no discomfort, this is not the correct classification.

 

Option C. C4a: This stage represents more advanced skin changes, such as pigmentation or eczema, due to chronic venous disease. The patient only has varicose veins without skin changes, so this classification is incorrect.

 

Option D. C1: Represents telangiectasia or reticular veins, which are smaller than varicose veins. The image and clinical description indicate larger varicose veins, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CEAP classification system is essential for categorizing the severity and characteristics of venous disease.
  •  For asymptomatic varicose veins, the appropriate classification is C2a, distinguishing them from symptomatic cases and those with more advanced skin changes.

questions.text: A patient was treated with repeated doses of IV anti-emetic for severe vomiting. The patient now does not have vomiting but developed abnormal movements. What is the most appropriate treatment? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Benzhexol

 

The patient likely received intravenous metoclopramide, a common anti-emetic, which can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as dystonia. Dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by involuntary muscle contractions, leading to repetitive movements or abnormal postures. This condition can be painful and distressing.

 

The treatment of choice for drug-induced dystonia is an anticholinergic medication. Benzhexol (also known as trihexyphenidyl) is an anticholinergic drug that can effectively relieve dystonic reactions by blocking acetylcholine receptors in the central nervous system, thereby restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyoscine: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is primarily used to treat motion sickness and postoperative nausea. It is not effective for treating dystonia induced by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option C. Levodopa: Levodopa is used to treat Parkinson's disease by increasing dopamine levels in the brain. It is not appropriate for treating acute dystonic reactions caused by anti-emetic medications.

 

Option D. Cyproheptadine: Cyproheptadine is an antihistamine with antiserotonergic and anticholinergic properties. While it can be used for some dystonic reactions, it is not the first-line treatment in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients who develop dystonic reactions after receiving anti-emetic medications like metoclopramide, the most appropriate treatment is an anticholinergic drug such as benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl). This helps alleviate the abnormal movements by restoring the balance between dopamine and acetylcholine in the central nervous system.

choices.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L
pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L
pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg
pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

 

The patient with chronic renal failure presenting with sudden collapse and labored breathing is indicative of a severe acid-base disturbance, most likely metabolic acidosis. The tall tented T waves on the ECG suggest hyperkalemia, a common finding in metabolic acidosis and renal failure.

 

Patients with chronic renal failure often have a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of uremic toxins. The lab values in pH - 7.14, pCO2 - 20 mm Hg, HCO3 - 5 mEq/L indicate a severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. The low bicarbonate level confirms metabolic acidosis, and the low pCO2 indicates compensatory hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L: This combination is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis because the bicarbonate level is high, which would not be seen in metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg: This represents metabolic alkalosis or compensated respiratory acidosis, neither of which are consistent with the clinical picture of chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg: This reflects a normal pH, which would not be seen in the acute setting described, especially with the presence of severe symptoms and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Internal iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery- External iliac artery
Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery
Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery

questions.text: A patient developed atonic postpartum hemorrhage after a normal vaginal delivery. She was shifted to the OT and the obstetrician planned ligation of vessels to arrest the bleeding. What is the order of ligation of the blood vessels supplying the uterus? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Uterine artery – Ovarian artery – Internal iliac artery

 

  • Stepwise devascularization in the management of atonic postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) involves:
    1. Ligation of the uterine arteries:
      • The ascending branch of the uterine artery is ligated at the lateral border between the upper and lower uterine segments.
    2. Ligation of the ovarian and uterine artery anastomoses:
      • Done just below the ovarian ligament.
      • Sometimes, temporary occlusion of the ovarian vessels may be achieved using rubber sleeved clamps.
    3. Ligation of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery:
      • This step reduces blood flow by decreasing the pulse pressure by 85%.
      • Ligation can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - External iliac artery: The external iliac artery is not typically involved in the stepwise devascularization for managing atonic PPH.

 

Option C. Uterine artery - Ovarian artery - Vaginal artery: Ligation of the vaginal artery is not part of the typical sequence in managing atonic PPH.

 

Option D. Uterine artery - pudendal artery - Vaginal artery: The pudendal artery and vaginal artery are not typically targeted in the stepwise devascularization for atonic PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stepwise devascularization approach for managing atonic postpartum hemorrhage includes ligation of the uterine arteries, ovarian arteries, and anterior division of the internal iliac arteries in that specific order.

 

Ref: Page no 2023, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman who had an abdominal hysterectomy two years ago and is now experiencing abdominal pain, vomiting bile, high-pitched bowel sounds during examination. The presence of air within the biliary tree is seen on diagnostic tests. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of intestinal obstruction. Though adhesions could be the reason, the presence of air in biliary tree makes a diagnosis of gallstone ileus more likely.

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis, occurring due to the impaction of gallstones in the gastrointestinal tract. This occurs due to chronic gall bladder inflammation and formation of cholecysto-duodenal fistula (GB to duodenum). Through the communication, a gall stone may pass into the duodenum and then into small bowel.
  • Small gallstones may pass through the intestines spontaneously, but larger stones (2-5 cm) are more likely to cause obstruction, usually at the terminal ileum or ileocecal valve.
  • Symptoms may include acute, intermittent, or chronic episodes of gastrointestinal obstruction, abdominal distension and tenderness, high-pitched bowel sounds, and obstructive jaundice.
  • Diagnosis is typically made with a plain abdominal radiograph, which may show signs of obstruction, Pneumobilia (air within the biliary tree), and a gallstone in the intestines (RIGLER’S TRIAD).
  • Treatment involves surgical intervention, with a longitudinal incision made on the antimesenteric border to remove the gallstone.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option B. Adhesive intestinal obstruction: This results from the formation of adhesions (bands of scar tissue) that can develop after surgery, which then bind the intestines together. These adhesions can pull the intestines out of place or create a kink or twist. The patient's history of an abdominal hysterectomy is suggestive of this, as post-surgical adhesions are a common cause of intestinal obstruction. However, the presence of air in the biliary tree does not fit with this diagnosis.

 

Option C. Ischemic enterocolitis: Refers to inflammation of the intestine due to reduced blood supply, often caused by blockage or constriction of the blood vessels that serve the intestines. Symptoms typically include sudden abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. While ischemic processes can cause pain and altered bowel sounds, the presence of pneumobilia on imaging is not consistent with ischemic enterocolitis.

 

Option D. Diverticulitis: Diverticulitis is the inflammation of one or more diverticula, which are small pouches that can form in the walls of the colon. Symptoms include lower left-sided abdominal pain, fever, and changes in bowel habits. While diverticulitis can lead to complications like abscesses, fistulas, or bowel obstructions, the specific presentation of vomiting bile and air within the biliary tree on imaging is not consistent with a primary diagnosis of diverticulitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gallstone ileus is a rare complication of cholelithiasis characterized by the presence of air within the biliary tree, obstructive symptoms, and the formation of a cholecysto-duodenal fistula.
  • It typically presents with signs of gastrointestinal obstruction and is diagnosed through imaging, revealing pneumobilia and a gallstone in the intestines.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

 

The presence of eosinophilia in an immunosuppressed patient with respiratory symptoms and BAL revealing rhabditiform larvae is suggestive of disseminated strongyloidiasis caused by Strongyloides stercoralis.

 

Strongyloidiasis:

 

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

 

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

 

 

It is generally a benign and asymptomatic condition. In some cases, there may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms.

 

The term larva currens (meaning 'racing larvae') has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

 

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route.

 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

 

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

 

  • ﻿﻿Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
  • ﻿﻿Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
  • ﻿﻿Stool culture and serological tests are also done

 

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Ancylostoma canium presents with creeping eruption. Cutaneous larva migrans or creeping eruption is caused by nematode larvae that infect by skin penetration.

 

Option B. Capillaria phillipinesis can also cause auto-infection. It commonly presents with severe diarrhea.

 

Option D. Enterobius vermicularis or pinworm infection presents as itching (pruritus) and restless sleep (due to nocturnal perianal or perineal pruritus)

 

Educational Objective

 

In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.

 

Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)

 

  1. Cryptosporidium parvum
  2. H. nana larva
  3. Enterobius vermicularis
  4. Strongyloides
  5. Taenia solium

choices.text: Intracellular fluid
Extracellular fluid

questions.text: A body fluid sample is being studied and has Na: 10 mEq/L, K: 140 mEq/L, CI: 4 mE/L. Identify the compartment from which the sample has been obtained? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intracellular fluid

 

Explanation

 

The electrolyte composition in the sample obtained has high concentration of potassium, suggests that it is intracellular fluid (IC) compartment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial and Option C. Extracellular Fluid generally have higher sodium and chloride concentrations and much lower potassium concentrations.

 

Option D. Plasma, part of the extracellular fluid, would similarly show higher sodium and chloride but lower potassium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The composition of potassium, sodium, and chloride in the sample aligns with that typically found in intracellular fluid, reflecting its origin from within cells, where potassium is the major cation, unlike extracellular compartments dominated by sodium and chloride.

choices.text: Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception
Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h
Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets

questions.text: Reema Devi, A 28y newly married woman presents to your sub center for contraceptive advice. She is started on Oral Contraceptive Pills. She presents after 2 weeks with a history of missing 4 tablets on different days in the first 2 weeks of the cycle. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Take the next pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give Emergency Pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 h

 

 

Missing a pill increases the risk of pregnancy.

 

Management of Missed Pill

 

 

** In this question, she has missed 4 pills in the 1st 2 weeks Hence, she should take the last missed pill, use additional contraception, use emergency contraception, and continue the remaining pack

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discontinue the packet and start an alternate method of contraception: Discontinuing the packet is not advised as it can lead to hormonal imbalance and irregular cycles. An alternate method of contraception can be considered only if the patient prefers to switch, but it is not an immediate solution for the current cycle's missed pills.

 

Option B. Take 4 tablets the next day, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception (condom) and give emergency pill if h/o intercourse in the last 72 hours: Taking 4 tablets the next day is excessive and unnecessary. The correct approach is to take the last missed pill and continue as usual.

 

Option D. Take the next pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining tablets: This option neglects the need for additional contraception and emergency contraception, which are crucial to prevent pregnancy in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

If a woman misses multiple oral contraceptive pills, she should take the last missed pill as soon as possible, continue the remaining packet, use additional contraception, and consider emergency contraception if she had intercourse in the last 72 hours.

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATPs were produced. Later a compound was added, and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What’s that compound? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oligomycin

 

  • Oligomycin is an antibiotic that inhibits ATP synthase, a key enzyme complex in oxidative phosphorylation. It blocks the flow of protons (H+) through ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis. As a result, adding oligomycin would indeed decrease oxidative phosphorylation, leading to a reduction in ATP production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 2,4-dinitrophenol (DNP): 2,4-dinitrophenol is a chemical uncoupler of oxidative phosphorylation. It disrupts the proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane, making it leaky to protons. This uncoupling reduces the efficiency of ATP production but doesn't directly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Option C. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from ubiquinone to cytochrome c, disrupting the electron flow in the chain.

 

Option D. Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I in the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone, disrupting electron flow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oligomycin specifically targets ATP synthase and inhibits ATP synthesis in oxidative phosphorylation. Therefore, the compound that was added to the isolated mitochondria, leading to a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 123

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

questions.text: What is the most important assessment based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management in a health care facility? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Process

 

Evaluation of "process" can assess a health care facility based on the treatment given to the patient and their clinical management.

 

The process of evaluation involves several steps, such as

 

  • Determining what needs to be evaluated
  • Establishing standards and criteria
  • Planning the methodology
  • Gathering information
  • Analyzing the results
  • Taking action
  • Re-evaluating

 

There are three types of evaluation: structure evaluation, process evaluation, and outcome evaluation.

 

  1. Evaluation of "structure": This is evaluation of whether facilities, equipment, manpower and organization meet a standard accepted by experts as good.
  2. Evaluation of "process": The process of medical care includes the problems of recognition, diagnostic procedures, treatment and clinical management, care and prevention. The way in which the various activities of the programme is carried out is evaluated by comparing with a predetermined standard. An objective and systematic way of evaluating the physician (or nurse) performance is known as "Medical (or nursing) Audit"
  3. Evaluation of "outcome": This is concerned with the end results, that is, whether persons using health services experience measurable benefits such as improved survival or reduced disability. The traditional outcome components are the "5 Ds" of ill-health, viz. disease, discomfort, dissatisfaction, disability and death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Outcome: Focuses on the end results of healthcare, such as improved health status and reduced disease and disability.

 

  • Not Correct: It measures the results of care, not the processes used to deliver it.

 

Option C. Structure: Examines the physical and organizational infrastructure, like facilities, equipment, and staffing.

 

  • Not Correct: It evaluates resources and infrastructure, not the actual delivery of care.

 

Option D. Input: Assesses resources required for healthcare, such as funding, manpower, and materials.

 

  • Not Correct: It looks at the resources used, not how care is delivered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "process" evaluation is the most relevant assessment for determining the quality of treatment and clinical management provided to patients in a healthcare facility. It focuses on the procedures and methods used in patient care, ensuring adherence to established standards and guidelines.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatigability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12 - 14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very less fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9gm/dl and MCV 120 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient's anemia? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Folic acid deficiency

 

The given laboratory values showing anemia and increased MC are suggestive of megaloblastic anemia.

 

This could be due to a lack of cyanocobalamin or folic acid. The lack of fruits and vegetables in the past suggests folic acid deficiency. (folic acid word derived from foliage-green leafy vegetables)

 

Animal products such as meat, fish, milk, and eggs are good sources of vitamin B12.

 

Green vegetables like lettuce, spinach, asparagus, and broccoli are high in folic acid.

 

In megaloblastic anemia, peripheral blood examination reveals oval macrocytes with anisocytosis and poikilocytosis. MCV is typically greater than 100 fL. (normal value: 80-100 fL). The MCHC is not elevated because most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and appear hyperchromic. The number of reticulocytes is low. Neutrophils are larger than normal and have five or more nuclear lobules, indicating nuclear hyper segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cyanocobalamin deficiency: Although vitamin B12 deficiency also causes megaloblastic anemia, the dietary history here suggests folic acid deficiency as the primary cause, given the lack of fruits and vegetables.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with microcytic (low MCV), hypochromic anemia, not macrocytic anemia as indicated by the elevated MCV.

 

Option D. Hereditary spherocytosis: This is a hemolytic anemia characterized by the presence of spherocytes (spherical red blood cells) and usually presents with a normal or slightly decreased MCV, not the significantly elevated MCV seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of anemia in this patient, given the elevated MCV and dietary habits lacking in fruits and vegetables, is folic acid deficiency. Megaloblastic anemia due to folic acid deficiency presents with macrocytic red blood cells and can be confirmed by dietary history and characteristic blood smear findings.

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sandfly

 

From the given clinical features, the most likely disease is visceral leishmaniasis or Kala azar caused by Leishmania donovani, and the vector is sandfly. A patient from Uttar Pradesh presenting with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly with a smear examination showing pancytopenia and macrophages containing organisms with kinetoplasts point towards the diagnosis.

 

 

Leishmaniasis is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

The parasite exists in 2 forms:

 

  • Amastigote form (also called LD bodies)- It is seen within macrophages and contains a kinetoplast.
  • Promastigote form- It is the infective form in the sandfly. The kinetoplast is seen at the anterior end.

 

Kinetoplast are non-nuclear DNA present in addition to nucleus. They consist of blepharoplast and parabasal body. Flagellum originates near the kinetoplast.

 

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tse-Tse fly: Transmits trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Triatomine bug: Known for spreading Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis).

 

Option D. Female Anopheles mosquito: Vector for malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: What is the most common complication associated with the following abnormality? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Exposure keratopathy

 

  • The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. The most common complication associated with this condition is exposure keratopathy since the defect leaves the cornea exposed. If left untreated, it can lead to corneal ulceration.

 

CONGENITAL EYELID COLOBOMA

 

  • Can be unilateral or bilateral, involving one or all four lids.
