  • The defect may vary from a small marginal notch to a full-thickness absence of the entire eyelid margin involving one-third to half of the eyelid.
  • The upper eyelid is commonly affected.
  • The most common site is the junction between the medial and middle third of the upper eyelid.
  • Eyelid colobomas represent an incomplete form of cryptophthalmos. Cryptophthalmos is a congenital condition in which there is a failure of differentiation of eyelid structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Restricted eye movements: This is not a primary complication of eyelid coloboma. Restricted eye movements are more associated with orbital or extraocular muscle issues.

 

Option C. Diplopia: Diplopia, or double vision, is not a common complication of eyelid coloboma. It usually arises from misalignment of the eyes or neurological conditions.

 

Option D. Amblyopia: Amblyopia, or lazy eye, can occur due to vision deprivation in severe cases of eyelid abnormalities, but it is not the most common complication of eyelid coloboma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eyelid colobomas can be an isolated finding or can be associated with various syndromes mentioned below:

choices.text: Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center
Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

questions.text: A 16-month-old boy is found to weigh 8kg. A WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) is provided below. Plot the growth chart for this child. What is the most appropriate advice based on the plotted graph? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate malnutrition - teach the mother on how to feed

 

The WHO growth chart (weight-for-height) shows that the weight of 8 kg for a 16-month-old boy falls between -2 standard deviations (SD) and -3 SD, indicating moderate malnutrition. This suggests that the child is not receiving adequate nutrition and is at risk for growth and developmental delays.

 

In such cases, it is important to educate the mother on proper feeding practices to ensure the child receives a balanced diet with adequate nutrients. This can involve guidance on meal frequency, food variety, and portion sizes to improve the child's nutritional status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No malnutrition - Assure the mother: This option is incorrect because the child’s weight for height falls between -2SD and -3SD on the growth chart, indicating moderate malnutrition rather than no malnutrition.

 

Option B. Mild malnutrition - home treatment: This option is incorrect as mild malnutrition is indicated when the weight-for-height is between -1SD and -2SD. The child’s weight falls between -2SD and -3SD, indicating moderate malnutrition.

 

Option C. Severe malnutrition - refer to nutrition rehabilitation center: This option is incorrect because severe malnutrition is diagnosed when the weight-for-height is less than -3SD. The child’s weight does not fall into this category.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moderate malnutrition in children is indicated by a weight-for-height between -2SD and -3SD on the WHO growth chart, necessitating education on proper feeding practices.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is undergoing chronic medication therapy for a long-term condition. The healthcare team wants to maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug. What formula should be used to calculate the maintenance dose rate of the drug for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clearance x Plasma concentration

 

The formula for the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is generally expressed as:

 

Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL) × Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp) 

 

This formula aims to achieve a steady-state concentration of the drug in the bloodstream. By multiplying the clearance rate by the desired plasma concentration, you get the rate at which the drug should be administered to maintain that desired concentration.

 

Note –

 

The loading dose is designed to quickly achieve the desired therapeutic level, whereas the maintenance dose sustains that level over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The formula for calculating the maintenance dose rate (MD) of a drug is:

 

Maintenance Dose Rate (MD) = Clearance (CL)×Desired Plasma Concentration (Cp)

 

This formula is used to achieve and maintain a specific steady-state plasma concentration of the drug

questions.text: Which one of the provided thermometers is employed for measuring low air velocity as opposed to the cooling potency of the air? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Kata thermometer 

 

Kata thermometer is used to measure low air velocity rather than the cooling power of the air. It works by measuring the temperature difference between two thin wires heated to different temperatures in a moving air stream. The faster the air moves, the greater the temperature difference between the two wires, allowing the Kata thermometer to measure air velocity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globe Thermometer: Measures mean radiant temperature, which is the average temperature of all the surfaces surrounding a particular point. This is useful in assessing thermal comfort in environments.

 

Option C. Wet Globe Thermometer: Used to measure heat stress by taking into account temperature, humidity, wind speed, and solar radiation. It is commonly used in the Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (WBGT) index.

 

Option D. Dial Thermometer: Measures air temperature using a dial indicator. It is a general-purpose thermometer and not specifically designed for measuring air velocity.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy
It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

questions.text: A 67 yrs. old male patient visits the emergency department due to rapidly worsening pain and swelling in the genital and perianal regions, with signs of necrotizing infection as shown below upon examination, the patient has a history of alcohol abuse and poorly controlled diabetes, and laboratory tests reveal leukocytosis and elevated blood glucose levels. What is the accurate statement about the condition presented by the patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. It is a mixed flora aerobic and anaerobic infection

 

  • The image and clinical scenario suggest Fournier's gangrene, which is a mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection and a surgical emergency.
  • Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive infection of the genitalia and perineum caused by mixed bacterial flora, often associated with diabetes, cancer, malnutrition, recent urogenital or colorectal instrumentation, or trauma.
  • Symptoms of Fournier's gangrene include erythema, swelling, pain, and blister formation with ultimately foul-smelling necrotic lesions.
  • Correct. Fournier's gangrene involves a mixed infection with both aerobic (oxygen-using) and anaerobic (not oxygen-using) bacteria. The presence of multiple bacterial types contributes to the rapid progression and severity of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient must be started on anti-gas gangrene serum therapy: Incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is typically used for the treatment of gas gangrene caused by the bacterium Clostridium perfringens. While C. perfringens can sometimes be a part of the mixed bacterial flora in Fournier's gangrene, the condition itself is not specifically gas gangrene, and thus anti-gas gangrene serum therapy is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Bilateral orchidectomy is generally performed: Incorrect. A bilateral orchidectomy, or the removal of both testes, is not a standard treatment for Fournier's gangrene. Testes are typically spared in Fournier’s gangrene.

 

Option D. Compulsory urinary diversion is performed: Incorrect. While urinary diversion might be considered in some cases where the urethra is compromised or if there's significant involvement of the urogenital structures, it's not a compulsory or routine part of the management of Fournier's gangrene.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fournier's gangrene is a surgical emergency characterized by a mixed aerobic and anaerobic bacterial infection of the genital and perianal regions, often associated with underlying conditions like diabetes and malnutrition.
  • It requires prompt surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: A child with infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis has multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities is likely to be seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is a condition where there is constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet due to hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus. This results in persistent vomiting, which leads to the loss of hydrogen and chloride ions in the gastric acid and potassium ions in the gastric mucus. As a consequence, the multiple episodes of non-bilious vomiting in IHPS can cause hypochloremia and hypokalemia, leading to alkalosis.

 

Cause of metabolic alkalosis: The hydrogen ions that normally reach the duodenum are now lost due to vomiting. Hence, the bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas is decreased, thereby increasing the bicarbonate levels in the serum.

 

Causes of hypokalemia:

 

  • Because of alkalosis, the hydrogen ions exit from the cells in exchange for potassium leading to hypokalemia.
  • Loss of fluid due to excessive vomiting activates the RAAS pathway. This worsens hypokalemia as the aldosterone causes active reabsorption of sodium in exchange for the secretion of K* and H* ions into the urine. The loss of H* ions in urine lowers the urinary pH, resulting in paradoxical aciduria

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis leads to hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis due to persistent vomiting and loss of gastric acid.

choices.text: Anterior dislocation of hip
Posterior dislocation of hip
Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur
Fracture neck of femur

questions.text: A patient fell down riding a bicycle. He started having pain around hip. There was shortening of limb, and the attitude of limb was Flexion, Adduction and Internal rotation. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior dislocation of hip

 

POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF HIP

 

  • It is more common (90%)
  • Mechanism of injury:
    • Dashboard injury: occur with axial load applied on a flexed knee placed in adduction - seen as one sits in the front seat of the car.
       
  • The typical attitude of the lower limb would be a flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR).

 

 

  • Complications: AVN of femoral head, sciatic nerve injury, associated fractures of femoral head and acetabulum and also associated knee injuries.
  • Imaging Findings:
    • Dislocation is usually seen on AP view; in a few cases, lateral view may be needed to establish the diagnosis.

 

 

  • CT scan is the best investigation to judge dislocation.
     
  • Treatment:
    • More the deformity is a sign that probably there is no associated fracture of acetabulum or femoral head/neck. These cases can undergo closed reduction under some sedation.
    • Reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Anterior Dislocation of Hip. It is less common than posterior dislocation. It is of 2 types. Type I: Pubic (femoral head lies superiorly) and Type II: Obturator (femoral head lies inferiorly). Patient assumes externally rotated, abducted and slightly flexed posture (FABER) at the affected hip, with restriction of movement. Head of femur is often felt either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type). Dislocation is usually seen on AP view. Treatment is reduction under general anesthesia (GA).

 

 

 

Option C. Inter-trochanteric fracture of femur. The patients suffering from intertrochanteric femoral fractures are mainly of elder age group (> 60 years of age) with poor health condition & comorbidities. It is seen more commonly in males. The patient presents with severe pain, swelling & ecchymosis. There is tenderness present over the greater trochanter. The hip is externally rotated to > 45° (lateral border of foot touches the couch). There is > 1 inch of shortening in the affected limb. Broadening of greater trochanter is seen. The patient is unable to walk and SLR is also not possible.

 

 

Option D. Fracture neck of femur. Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. They are associated with low energy falls in the elderly. In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. Risk factors include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density. Displaced fractures put the blood supply at risk, usually tearing the ascending cervical branches. This may compromise the healing of the fracture, inevitably causing non-union or osteonecrosis. Non-operative management for these fractures is rarely the treatment course. Young patients with femoral neck fractures will require treatment with emergent open reduction internal fixation. Non-displaced fractures are treated typically with percutaneous cannulated screws or a sliding hip screw. With displaced fractures in less active elderly patients, the treatment is given by hemiarthroplasty and with more active individuals, total hip arthroplasty is done.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The limb position of flexion, adduction and internal rotation (FADIR) is specific of posterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A child presents with generalized edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urinalysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrotic syndrome

 

The clinical presentation of a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome, which is a glomerular disease characterized by heavy proteinuria. The diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome is based on the triad of hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL) in addition to proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2.

 

Causes of Nephrotic Syndrome:

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Nephritic syndrome: Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

 

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

 

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis

 

Option C. Goodpasture syndrome: Goodpasture syndrome also referred to as anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) disease, is an autoimmune disease that affects both the kidneys and lungs by the formation of autoantibodies that attack their basement membranes. Plasmapheresis is recommended in patients with pauci-immune crescentic GN and Goodpasture syndrome.

 

Option D. IgA nephropathy: IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a kidney disorder that occurs when immunoglobulin A (IgA), a protein that helps the body fight infections, settles in the kidneys. This can cause inflammation that, over time, can affect the kidneys' ability to filter waste from the blood. IgA nephropathy is one of the most common glomerulonephritis, a type of kidney disease that affects the glomeruli, the tiny filters within the kidneys that filter waste and excess fluids from the blood.

 

Some common features of IgA nephropathy include:

 

  1. Hematuria: The most common symptom is the presence of blood in the urine (hematuria), which can make the urine appear pink or cola-colored.
  2. Proteinuria: Protein in the urine (proteinuria) may also occur but is typically less significant than in other kidney diseases.
  3. High Blood Pressure: Some individuals may develop high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies in urinalysis

questions.text: A patient on aspirin presented with occult blood in the stool. This is due to inhibition of_____ by aspirin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thromboxane Synthesis

 

Thromboxane A2 is a substance that promotes platelet aggregation and also causes vasoconstriction. Aspirin inhibits the enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX), which is crucial for the synthesis of thromboxane A2. By inhibiting thromboxane synthesis, aspirin reduces platelet aggregation, which can increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, manifesting as occult blood in the stool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phospholipase A2: This enzyme is involved in the initial step of arachidonic acid release from cell membranes, but it is not directly inhibited by aspirin. The effect of aspirin is more downstream in the arachidonic acid pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Phospholipase C is involved in intracellular signaling but is not inhibited by aspirin. It does not play a direct role in the mechanism by which aspirin may cause occult blood in the stool.

 

Option D. Phospholipase D: Similar to Phospholipase C, Phospholipase D is not inhibited by aspirin and is not involved in the mechanism leading to gastrointestinal bleeding from aspirin use.

 

Therefore, in this patient, the occult blood in the stool is most likely due to the inhibition of thromboxane synthesis by aspirin, making option B the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin inhibits thromboxane synthesis by irreversibly inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes (COX-1 and COX-2), leading to reduced platelet aggregation and an increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing for 4 weeks. Absolute eosinophil count > 5000/μL. Chest X-ray shows a miliary pattern. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia (TPE) is a condition caused by the presence of microfilariae in the pulmonary circulation, leading to a severe immune response characterized by significant eosinophilia. The clinical presentation includes fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, and wheezing, which are symptoms consistent with TPE. The absolute eosinophil count greater than 5000/μL further supports this diagnosis.

 

The chest X-ray finding of a miliary pattern, though more commonly associated with tuberculosis, can also be seen in TPE due to the diffuse infiltration of eosinophils in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Asthma can present with wheezing and nocturnal symptoms but is not typically associated with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray or such a high level of eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Miliary tuberculosis: Miliary tuberculosis can present with a miliary pattern on chest X-ray but is not associated with a significantly elevated eosinophil count. Miliary TB usually presents with systemic symptoms like weight loss, night sweats, and widespread dissemination in the body.

 

Option D. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis: This condition can cause pulmonary symptoms and may present with a miliary pattern on imaging. However, it is usually a type III hypersensitivity reaction (immune complex-mediated) and does not typically lead to such high levels of eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia is characterized by symptoms like fever, nocturnal cough, breathlessness, wheezing, significant eosinophilia, and a miliary pattern on chest X-ray. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these clinical findings, especially in endemic regions. The treatment of choice for TPE is diethylcarbamazine (DEC).

questions.text: A man exposes his genitalia to a female passerby on the road. This method of deriving sexual gratification by observing the people that look at him nude is best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exhibitionism

 

The given history is suggestive of exhibitionism. Exhibitionism is a condition where an individual derives sexual gratification by exposing their genitalia to unsuspecting people and observing their reactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voyeurism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification by watching others, typically women, engaged in sexual activity or in a state of undress. The person engaging in this behavior is known as a "peeping tom."
  • Punishment: Punishable under Section 354(C) IPC.

 

Option B. Fetishism

 

  • Definition: Sexual arousal and gratification are achieved through objects or specific body parts, such as footwear, undergarments, etc., often belonging to the opposite sex.

 

Option D. Masochism

 

  • Definition: Sexual gratification is obtained through experiencing pain or humiliation inflicted upon oneself.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented to the outpatient department with gum bleeding and fever for the past 2 months. General examination showed pallor and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed Hb level- 3 gm/dI, TLC-1500/microL, platelet count - 15000/microL. Peripheral smear shows macrocytes and the reticulocyte count is 0.5. Bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes but no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis? (Hb- Hemoglobin, TLC- Total leucocyte count)? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia

 

The given clinical scenario showing a young male with gum bleeding, fever, pancytopenia, and a low reticulocyte count with bone marrow showing fatty streaks and no immature cells is suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Key Diagnostic Features of Aplastic Anemia:

 

  • Pancytopenia (low Hb, WBC, and platelets)
  • Hypocellular (fatty) bone marrow
  • No immature/blast cells
  • Low reticulocyte count (indicates bone marrow failure)
  • Macrocytes due to ineffective hematopoiesis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is characterized by hemolysis, hemoglobinuria (especially in the morning), and thrombosis. The presentation of pancytopenia with bone marrow aplasia is more suggestive of idiopathic acquired aplastic anemia.

 

Option C. Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS): MDS are a diverse group of hematopoietic clonal stem cell disorders characterized by abnormal development of various marrow elements (i.e., dysmyelopoiesis), cytopenias, cellular marrow, and ineffective blood cell formation.

 

Option D. Tuberculosis: Tuberculosis can cause pancytopenia if the bone marrow is involved, but the bone marrow would show granulomas rather than the fatty streaks and absence of immature cells seen in aplastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of pancytopenia

 

I. Aplastic anemia

 

II. Pancytopenia with normal or increased marrow cellularity

 

e.g.

 

  1.  Myelodysplastic syndromes
  2. Hypersplenism
  3.  Megaloblastic anemia

 

III. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

 

IV. Bone marrow infiltrations

 

e.g:

 

  1. Hematologic malignancies (leukemias, lymphomas, myeloma)
  2. Non-hematologic metastatic malignancies
  3. Storage diseases
  4. Osteopetrosis
  5. Myelofibrosis

questions.text: What is the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.

 

  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.
  • This maneuver involves tilting the patient's head backward by gently lifting the chin upward.
  • It is used to open the airway and clear any potential obstruction in the upper part of the throat.
  • This is a basic technique used in CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation) to help with ventilation.

 

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: The jaw thrust maneuver is used to open the airway in a patient with a suspected cervical spine injury. Instead of tilting the head backward, the anesthesiologist uses their fingers to push the patient's jaw forward. This technique avoids movement of the neck and is often used when spinal injury is a concern.

 

 

Option C. Head extension: Head extension involves simply tilting the patient's head backward to open the airway. It is similar to the head tilt, chin lift maneuver, but it focuses more on extending the neck to clear the airway.

 

 

Option D. In line manual stabilization: This technique is used to stabilize the cervical spine, especially in cases of suspected neck injuries. It involves maintaining the head and neck in a neutral, aligned position to prevent further injury during maneuvers like intubation. This is typically done by an assistant while another healthcare provider performs airway management.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The maneuver being performed in the given image is that of head-tilt chin-lift.
  • It is an airway management technique to open up the collapsed airway.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

 

Explanation:

 

Chickenpox in Pregnancy:

 

  • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes:
    • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
    • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.

 

Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.

 

Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.

 

Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of cholecystectomy 4 years back for gallstones presents with symptoms of obstructive jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a stone in the common bile duct. What is the most probable type of stone causing this obstruction? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary  

 

The classification of common bile duct (CBD) stones helps determine the probable type and origin of the stones.

 

  • Primary bile duct stones, also known as primary choledocholithiasis, form directly within the bile duct. They are distinct from gallbladder stones.
  • Their formation is typically associated with bile stasis, infection, or parasitic infestation of the bile ducts, particularly the liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis, which is endemic in some parts of Asia.
  •  These stones are often pigmented.
  •  The fact that this patient developed a stone in the common bile duct following a cholecystectomy >2 years back suggests the stone might be a primary stone, forming due to some underlying bile duct pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary: Secondary bile duct stones, or secondary choledocholithiasis, refer to gallstones that formed in the gallbladder and then migrated into the bile duct. This is the most common cause of bile duct stones in patients who still have their gallbladders. Secondary stones are typically cholesterol stones, being yellowish and softer than primary stones.

 

Option C. Tertiary: Tertiary stones are essentially advanced secondary stones. They are stones that have resided in the ductal system for a long time after migrating from the gallbladder, and over time, they might undergo changes due to recurrent bouts of cholangitis or prolonged bile stasis.

 

Option D. Retained: Retained stones refer to stones that were overlooked or missed during an initial procedure, like a cholecystectomy. They should be diagnosed within 2 years of cholecystectomy. They remain in the bile duct and can later cause symptoms. These stones were originally in the gallbladder or bile duct at the time of surgery and were not adequately removed or were missed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary bile duct stones form directly within the bile ducts and are associated with underlying bile duct pathology.
  • They are different from secondary stones, which form in the gallbladder and migrate into the bile duct, and retained stones, which are missed during the initial surgery.

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Motility of the most likely causative organism can be detected by which of the following microscopes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscope

 

The clinical vignette of a painless, indurated genital ulcer in a truck driver is most likely suggestive of syphilitic chancre / hard chancre caused by Treponema pallidum. The motility of the organism can be demonstrated by dark ground/ field microscopy.

 

Dark ground microscopy can be used to diagnose syphilis when an active chancre or condyloma lata is present to visualize Treponema pallium. Dark-field microscopy images have a dark background with a refractile organism. The dark ground microscope has an optical system that enhances the contrast of unstained bodies. It is generally less sensitive.

 

Various types of Spirochetes and their appearances under a dark ground microscope:

 

  • Treponemes generally are short, slender with regular and sharp spirals.
  • Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends.
  • Borrelia is large with irregular and wide open coils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Electron microscope: While capable of revealing detailed structures of microorganisms, it is not typically used in clinical settings for diagnosing infections due to its complexity and cost.

 

Option C. Light microscope: Standard light microscopy, typically used with staining techniques, does not easily allow for the visualization of live motility or very thin bacteria like Treponema pallidum.

 

Option D. Fluorescent microscope: Although it can be used to detect specific pathogens if fluorescent-tagged antibodies are available, it is not the standard method for observing motility or diagnosing syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is essential for observing the motility of Treponema pallidum directly from lesions such as a syphilitic chancre. This diagnostic tool is critical in early stages of syphilis when direct visualization of the pathogen can confirm infection before serological tests become positive.

questions.text: A patient presented with headache, vomiting, and fever. Meningitis was suspected. While performing a lumbar puncture, which is the last structure you will pierce just before entering the lumbar cistern? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Arachnoid mater

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure you will pierce while performing a lumbar puncture.

 

Layers pierced while performing lumbar puncture/spinal anesthesia (subarachnoid space) from outside to inside are:

 

  • Skin
  • Subcutaneous tissue
  • Supraspinous ligament
  • Interspinous ligament
  • Ligamentum flavum
  • Dura mater
  • Arachnoid mater

 

Upon piercing the arachnoid mater, you enter the subarachnoid space (lumbar cistern), where cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected during a lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligamentum flavum: The ligamentum flavum is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is pierced before the dura mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option B. Dura mater: The dura mater is a tough outer meningeal layer that is pierced before the arachnoid mater during a lumbar puncture.

 

Option D. Pia mater: The pia mater is the innermost meningeal layer that directly covers the spinal cord. It is not pierced during a lumbar puncture.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The arachnoid mater is the last structure pierced before entering the lumbar cistern during a lumbar puncture.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G4A3 woman had a history of miscarriage at 8 weeks, the second miscarriage at 11 weeks with no cardiac activity, and the third pregnancy loss at 24 weeks with preterm delivery due to early-onset preeclampsia. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:

 

  • The patient's history of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL) and a pregnancy complicated by early-onset preeclampsia is highly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA).
  • APLA is diagnosed based on clinical and laboratory criteria. The clinical criteria include obstetric complications such as unexplained fetal death, severe preeclampsia necessitating early delivery, and recurrent early pregnancy losses. Vascular thrombosis is also a clinical criterion.
  • Laboratory criteria include the presence of lupus anticoagulant, medium to high titers of anticardiolipin antibodies, and anti-β2 glycoprotein antibodies. These must be present on two or more occasions at least 12 weeks apart.
  • The Sapporo Criteria for diagnosing APLA require at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion to be present.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Syphilis: Although syphilis can cause adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage and stillbirth, it is less likely than APLA to cause the combination of early pregnancy loss and early-onset preeclampsia described in this case.

 

Option C. TORCH infections: TORCH infections (Toxoplasmosis, Other agents, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus, and Herpes simplex virus) can lead to congenital anomalies, intrauterine growth restriction, and pregnancy loss. However, recurrent pregnancy loss due to TORCH infections is rare.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) typically affects pregnancies later in gestation and is associated with macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, and other complications, but it is not commonly associated with recurrent pregnancy loss or early-onset preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss and complications such as early-onset preeclampsia, necessitating early delivery. Diagnosis is based on the presence of clinical and laboratory criteria according to the Sapporo Criteria.

 

Ref: Page no 2550, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: CRP has no association with risk of MI/stroke
Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke
Increase in CRP decreases the risk of Ml/stroke
In group 1, there is no risk of MI/stroke

questions.text:
A researcher is investigating whether a correlation exists between CRP values and the likelihood of experiencing myocardial infarction or stroke. The participants in the study were split into five groups and the following table is formed based on the study results. Among the provided options, which statement accurately reflects the connection between CRP levels and the risk of myocardial infarction/stroke? [NEET PG 2021]

(CRP à C-reactive protein)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Increase in CRP leads to increased risk of MI/Stroke  

 

The given study results show Relative risk values which are > 1 in majority of the groups.

 

Also, with the increase in CRP levels, relative risk is also showing an uprise. Hence, it can be implied that CRP levels have a positive association with risk of MI/Stroke.

 

Among the given options, the best answer will be option B.

 

 

Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b)]/ c/(c+d)] where,

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased CRP levels are positively associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction (MI) and stroke. As CRP levels rise, the relative risk of these conditions also increases.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What can be done to prevent future thrombotic events? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Oral warfarin

 

The patient is diagnosed with mitral stenosis and has an irregularly irregular pulse, indicating atrial fibrillation (AF). Atrial fibrillation is a common complication in patients with mitral stenosis and significantly increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

 

Long-term anticoagulation therapy is essential in such patients to prevent these events. The presence of mitral stenosis, particularly moderate to severe, mandates the use of oral anticoagulants. Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant in this scenario because it is the only approved medication for patients with mitral stenosis and those with mechanical prosthetic heart valves.

 

Other anticoagulants, such as Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs), are not recommended in patients with valvular atrial fibrillation (AF associated with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves).

 

Additional Information –

 

CHA2DS2-VASc score to guide anticoagulation therapy in patients without mitral stenosis or a prosthetic valve.

 

  • C - Congestive heart failure: 1 point
  • H - Hypertension: 1 point
  • A - Age 65 to 74: 1 point, Age 75 and above: 2 points
  • D - Diabetes Mellitus: 1 point
  • S2 - Prior stroke or TIA: 2 points
  • Sex category (Female): 1 point
  • Vascular diseases (such as coronary artery disease or peripheral artery disease): 1 point

 

Scoring and Treatment Recommendations

 

  • Total Points: Ranges from 0 to 9.
  • Score of 2 or more: Strongly indicates the need for long-term anticoagulation (DOAC > warfarin).

 

Direct Oral Anticoagulants (DOACs) such as Dabigatran, Apixaban, Rivaroxaban, or Edoxaban are preferred unless the patient has conditions like mitral stenosis or mechanical prosthetic valves, in which case Warfarin might be more appropriate.

 

  • Score less than 2: Anticoagulation may be considered but is less mandatory.

 

This scoring system is crucial for making informed decisions about anticoagulation therapy to prevent stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation, tailoring treatment based on individual risk profiles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dabigatran: Dabigatran is a DOAC that is not recommended for patients with mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves. It is suitable for non-valvular atrial fibrillation but not for valvular AF.

 

Option B. Aspirin 150mg: Aspirin is not sufficient as an anticoagulant in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially those with mitral stenosis. It does not provide the necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events in such high-risk patients.

 

Option D. Aspirin + Clopidogrel: This combination is also inadequate for anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation, particularly in patients with mitral stenosis. While it can prevent platelet aggregation, it does not provide the anticoagulation required to prevent thrombus formation in atrial fibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with atrial fibrillation associated with mitral stenosis, oral warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant to prevent thromboembolic events.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigability, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anthracotic pigment

 

The black pigment in the resected bronchoscopic specimen's hilar lymph node is most likely an anthracotic pigment.

 

The black colour is caused by carbon particle deposition. Carbon particles inhaled are engulfed by lung macrophages and transported to the hilar lymph nodes. This builds up and causes anthracosis, or blackening of the lung tissues.

 

 

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high levels of carbon particle pollution, such as coal mines. It is also the most common exogenous pigment found in humans as a result of urban air pollution. The aggregates of the carbon dust may induce fibroblastic reaction or emphysema that may lead to a condition called coal worker's pneumoconiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Melanin: Melanin is a natural pigment found in the skin, hair, and eyes. It is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Lipochrome: Lipochrome (also known as lipofuscin) is a yellow-brown pigment that accumulates with age in various tissues, but it does not present as black and is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Hemosiderin: Hemosiderin is an iron-storage complex and presents as a golden-brown pigment. It is associated with hemorrhage and iron metabolism but does not appear as black.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anthracotic pigment, resulting from the deposition of carbon particles, is the most likely cause of the black pigment observed in the hilar lymph node of a patient with squamous cell carcinoma. This is common in individuals exposed to high levels of environmental pollution or occupational hazards involving carbon particles.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with migratory arthritis and examination revealed a pan-systolic murmur. An echocardiography was performed which was suggestive of mitral regurgitation. A biopsy specimen was obtained and the image is provided below. What is the most likely lesion shown in the histopathology slide? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aschoff’s bodies

 

Acute rheumatic fever is suggested by the clinical findings of migratory arthritis, pan-systolic murmur, and mitral regurgitation. Aschoff's bodies are the most likely lesion in the histopathological slide.

 

Acute RF causes focal inflammatory lesions in a variety of tissues. Aschoff bodies are distinct lesions in the heart that consist of foci of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells (pathognomonic for RF). These macrophages have a lot of cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin in a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the name "caterpillar cells"), and they can get multinucleated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Epithelioid granuloma: Epithelioid granulomas are associated with chronic inflammatory conditions such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis. They do not have the characteristic Anitschkow cells seen in Aschoff bodies.

 

Option  C. Granulomatous vasculitis: Granulomatous vasculitis is characterized by granulomas in the walls of blood vessels, which is seen in conditions like granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It does not match the histological description of Aschoff bodies.

 

Option D. Granuloma inguinale: Granuloma inguinale, caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, presents with genital ulcers and Donovan bodies on histology, which is unrelated to the cardiac findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aschoff bodies, which consist of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and characteristic Anitschkow cells, are the hallmark histological feature of acute rheumatic fever, a condition that can lead to significant cardiac involvement, including mitral regurgitation.

questions.text: A patient was suspected to have acute brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came out to be negative initially but after serial dilutions of the serum sample, the test turned out to be positive. Which of the following is responsible for the initial negative test? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prozone phenomenon

 

The initial negative test is explained by the prozone phenomenon. The standard agglutination test is a tube agglutination test that mainly identifies IgM antibodies. It is used in establishing a diagnosis of acute brucellosis.

 

Prozone phenomenon refers to the failure of a visible precipitation reaction due to inhibition of lattice formation by the presence of excessive antibodies. This gives rise to a false-negative test. This excess in antibodies can be overcome by diluting the serum sample, leading to an increase in LATTICE FORMATION where the antigen-antibody interactions are equal, eventually giving rise to a positive result.

 

Lattice hypothesis: The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is greatly influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. The point where the antigen and the antibody are in the same amount , best interaction takes place in this zone called as the zone of equivalence. 

 

  • Prozone phenomenon: Caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. (weak/absent precipitation-false-negative test)
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigens and antibodies are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs.
  • Post-zone phenomenon: Due to the presence of excessive antigen in the test system. (weaker/absent precipitation)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incomplete antibodies: These are not typically responsible for the phenomenon described. Incomplete antibodies generally do not cause agglutination but can bind antigens.

 

Option B. Complement inactivation: This would not typically result in the observed test pattern and is more relevant in tests involving complement fixation.

 

Option D. Post-zone phenomenon: Occurs when there is an excess of antigen, not antibodies, leading to a lack of visible agglutination due to insufficient cross-linking by antibodies.

 

Educational Objective

 

The prozone phenomenon, responsible for initial false-negative results in serological tests like the standard agglutination test for brucellosis, occurs due to excessive antibodies preventing visible agglutination. This can be corrected by diluting the serum, which highlights the importance of considering antibody concentration in diagnostic testing.

questions.text: A 56-year-old multipara woman presented with grade II/III uterine prolapse with cystocele. She complains of passing urine on coughing and sneezing. What is the type of urinary incontinence seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stress incontinence

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by the involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure, such as during coughing, sneezing, or physical exertion. It is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse, where the support structures of the pelvic floor are weakened, leading to bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Overflow incontinence: Overflow incontinence occurs when the bladder cannot empty properly, leading to frequent or constant dribbling of urine. It is usually secondary to an obstruction, such as an enlarged prostate in men or severe prolapse in women causing a kink in the urethra. This condition does not typically present with leakage during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option B. Urge incontinence: Urge incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine accompanied by or immediately preceded by a sudden, intense urge to urinate. This type of incontinence can be due to overactive bladder syndrome, where there is involuntary contraction of the bladder muscles.

 

Option D. Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder refers to a dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to a central or peripheral nervous system pathology. This can result in various types of incontinence, including both overflow and urge incontinence, depending on the nature of the neurological impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stress urinary incontinence is characterized by involuntary leakage of urine due to increased intra-abdominal pressure and is commonly seen in women with utero-vaginal prolapse.

 

Ref: Page no 597, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with seizures. His past history is significant for an episode of fever with rash at 1 year of age which resolved spontaneously. What is the most helpful investigation to diagnose his condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgG measles in CSF

 

This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), also known as Dawson disease, which is caused by infection with the measles virus. The CSF anti-measles antibodies - IgG antibodies will be elevated and hence, it is the most helpful investigation to diagnose this condition.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis: Mesial temporal lobe sclerosis is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy, not SSPE. It involves scarring in the temporal lobe but is not typically seen in SSPE.

 

Option C. IgM measles in CSF: IgM antibodies indicate a recent infection. In SSPE, the infection occurred years earlier, so IgG antibodies, not IgM, would be elevated in the CSF.

 

Option D. D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF: D C1Q4 antibodies are not relevant to the diagnosis of SSPE. These antibodies are associated with complement component 1q deficiency, which is linked to autoimmune conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), elevated CSF anti-measles IgG antibodies are key for diagnosis.

questions.text: The mother of a 12-year-old girl was worried that her daughter is shorter when compared with her classmates. On examination, the child had a webbed neck, low hairline, and shield chest. A provisional diagnosis of Turner's syndrome was made. Which of the following is a likely finding to be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bilateral small streak ovaries

 

The likely finding seen in a patient with Turner syndrome is bilateral small streak ovaries.

 

Turner syndrome results from complete or partial monosomy of the X chromosome. It is characterized by hypogonadism in phenotypic females. It is the most common sex chromosome abnormality in females. Three types of karyotypic abnormalities are seen

 

  • Missing an entire X chromosome - this results in a 45X0 karyotype.
  • Structural abnormalities of the X chromosomes
  • Mosaics - they will have 45X along with one or more karyotypically normal or abnormal cell types. Examples are 45X/46XX, 45X/46XY, 45X/47XXX, 45×/46X, ¡(X)(q10).

 

Important features associated with Turner's syndrome:

 

 

  • Short stature
  • Webbing of neck
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Cubitus valgus
  • Streak ovaries
  • Infertility, amenorrhea
  • Peripheral lymphedema at birth
  • Low posterior hairline
  • Broad chest and widely spaced nipples
  • Pigmented nevi
  • Coarctation of aorta

 

Normal secondary sex characteristics do not develop during puberty. The genitalia remain infantile, breast development is inadequate, and pubic hair is scarce. In adults, short stature and amenorrhea are especially important in establishing the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic dissection: While Turner syndrome is associated with cardiovascular abnormalities, such as coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, aortic dissection is less common in children and typically occurs in adults with significant aortic disease.

 

Option B. Subluxation of lens: Subluxation of the lens is a feature of Marfan syndrome, not Turner syndrome.

 

Option C. Mitral valve prolapse: Mitral valve prolapse is more commonly associated with connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. Turner syndrome is more characteristically associated with left-sided heart defects like coarctation of the aorta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, shield chest, and streak ovaries, leading to primary ovarian insufficiency, infertility, and amenorrhea. The diagnosis is confirmed by karyotyping, and the most likely finding in Turner syndrome patients is bilateral small streak ovaries.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with dark urine, which further blackens on exposure to air. What’s the enzyme defect in this case?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Di Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase

 

This is a case of alkaptonuria which is an inborn error in catabolism of tyrosine and phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase or Di-Hydroxy Phenyl Acetate Dioxygenase. The IUPAC name of homogentisate is 2,5-Dihydroxy Phenyl Acetate. The older name of this enzyme was Homogentisate oxidase. (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase:

  • Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase is an enzyme involved in the breakdown of tyrosine, an amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Tyrosinemia Type I. However, Tyrosinemia Type I does not cause darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Option C. Homogentisate Dehydrogenase

  • Homogentisate oxidase, (not Homogentisate Dehydrogenase) is the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of homogentisic acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Alkaptonuria. In Alkaptonuria, homogentisic acid accumulates and causes the urine to turn black upon exposure to air. This is due to the oxidation of homogentisic acid.
     

 

Option D. Phenylalanine hydroxylase:

  • Phenylalanine hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the metabolism of phenylalanine, another amino acid. Deficiency of this enzyme leads to Phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU does not directly lead to darkening of urine upon exposure to air.

 

Educational objective:

 

In alkaptonuria patients, fresh urine is normal in color, but on standing it turns black due to oxidation of excess homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. For complete list of phenyalanine and tyrosine catabolism defects, refer to topic aromatic amino acids.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 286

questions.text: A 35-year-old chronic hypertensive woman visits the outpatient department for pre-conceptional counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensive should she discontinue? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

 

These medications are contraindicated during pregnancy because they are associated with fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Therefore, women who are planning to conceive should discontinue these medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labetalol: Labetalol is generally safe for use during pregnancy and is a treatment option for hypertension in pregnant women. It is not necessary to discontinue this medication.

 

Option B. Calcium channel blockers: Calcium channel blockers like nifedipine are also generally considered safe during pregnancy and are often used to manage hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Option D. Alpha methyldopa: Alpha methyldopa is also considered safe during pregnancy and is commonly used for managing hypertension in this population.

 

Given the woman's intention to conceive, discontinuing Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors would be the most appropriate course of action to protect both her health and that of her future child.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors should be discontinued in women who are planning to conceive due to their associated risks of fetal renal dysplasia, oligohydramnios, and other congenital anomalies. Alternative antihypertensive medications that are safer during pregnancy include labetalol, calcium channel blockers, and alpha methyldopa.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.

 

The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal centre B cells.

 

A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions: (1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells); and (2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.

 

Immunophenotyping - The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt Lymphoma: Typically presents with a high-grade lymphoma and a starry sky pattern on histology. It is associated with c-MYC translocation and does not usually express BCL2.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides: A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents with skin lesions and does not typically show CD10 or BCL2 positivity.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) and presents with marked leukocytosis and often splenomegaly, not with lymphadenopathy and histological findings as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia all of the following is increased except? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transferrin saturation

 

Transferrin Saturation: This is the percentage of transferrin (the protein that transports iron in the blood) that is saturated with iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the transferrin saturation is decreased because there is less iron available to bind to transferrin.

 

It is important to note that in a patient with iron deficiency anemia, there is increased TIBC as well as increased RBC Protoporphyrin levels and the number of serum transferrin receptors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RBC protoporphyrin: This is a precursor in the heme synthesis pathway. In iron deficiency anemia, the lack of iron means that protoporphyrin accumulates, as it cannot be converted into heme. Therefore, RBC protoporphyrin levels are increased.

 

Option C. Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): This is a measure of the total capacity of the blood to bind iron with transferrin. In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is increased as the body produces more transferrin in an attempt to capture more iron from the diet and the body’s stores.

 

Option D. Serum transferrin receptors: These receptors are present on the surface of cells and are involved in the uptake of transferrin-bound iron. In iron deficiency anemia, the number of these receptors increases as the body tries to increase iron uptake from the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida is in labor. She has a repeated urge to pass urine and has premature bearing down. On examination there is infra-umbilical flattening, and the fetal heart is heard on the lateral side. What is the most likely presentation/ position? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occipito-posterior

 

Explanation:

 

Occipito-posterior:

 

  • History:
    • Early rupture of membranes.
    • Frequent filling of bladder.
    • Premature bearing down.
  • Abdominal Examination:
    • Inspection: Infra-umbilical flattening, which indicates that the fetus is not positioned centrally in the uterus.
    • Grips: The fetal head is un-engaged, which is often the case with occipito-posterior positions.
    • Auscultation: Fetal heart sounds (FHS) are heard on the flanks, suggesting that the fetus is lying posteriorly.
  • Vaginal Examination:
    • An elongated bag of membranes.
    • The posterior fontanelle is near the sacro-iliac joint.
    • The anterior fontanelle is more easily felt due to deflexion of the fetal head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knee: A knee presentation is a form of breech presentation where the knees are the presenting part. It is rare and would not cause infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option C. Brow: The brow presentation involves partial extension of the fetal head. The presenting diameter is larger, leading to a more difficult labor. However, this would not typically present with infra-umbilical flattening or lateral fetal heart sounds.

 

Option D. Right dorso-anterior: This position involves the fetus's back being to the mother's right and anterior. It would not cause infra-umbilical flattening and lateral fetal heart sounds like the occipito-posterior position does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occipito-posterior position in labor is characterized by infra-umbilical flattening, frequent filling of the bladder, premature bearing down, and fetal heart sounds heard on the lateral side.

 

 

Ref: Page no 302, Textbook of Obstetrics by JB Sharma, 3rd edition

questions.text: In a case of tinea capitis, white powdery colonies were isolated from the hair specimen. The hair perforation test was positive on the isolate. Which of the following is the likely etiology? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichophyton mentagrophytes

 

The identification of Trichophyton mentagrophytes as the causative agent in this case of tinea capitis is confirmed by the positive hair perforation test. This test is particularly valuable for differentiating between species of Trichophyton, as it assesses the fungus's ability to penetrate and degrade hair keratin.

 

  • Hair Perforation Test: This diagnostic tool is used to differentiate Trichophyton mentagrophytes from Trichophyton rubrum, as T. mentagrophytes demonstrates the ability to perforate hair, causing surface erosion which gives a wedge-shaped appearance to the hair shaft. This is a key characteristic that helps in identifying the fungal species responsible for the infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermophyton floccosum: Does not typically infect hair, more commonly associated with skin and nail infections.

 

Option B. Microsporum audouinii: Causes tinea capitis but does not show a positive result on the hair perforation test.

 

Option D. Microsporum gypseum: Another cause of tinea capitis but also does not typically show a positive hair perforation test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of tinea capitis, a positive hair perforation test indicative of surface erosion and wedge-shaped appearance of the hair shaft confirms the presence of Trichophyton mentagrophytes. This test is crucial for distinguishing it from other dermatophytes, specifically Trichophyton rubrum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is not responding well to conventional treatment. Her rheumatologist is considering adding tocilizumab to her treatment regimen. Which of the following interleukins (IL) is primarily targeted by tocilizumab? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IL-6

 

  • Tocilizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and inhibits the interleukin-6 (IL-6) receptor. By blocking the IL-6 receptor, tocilizumab interrupts the signaling pathway of IL-6, a cytokine involved in the inflammatory response. This is particularly beneficial in conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, where elevated levels of IL-6 contribute to the inflammatory process.
  • Tocilizumab has also been used in COVID-19 for cytokine release syndrome.
  • It is avoided in patients with liver disease, immunosuppression, having a high risk of GIT perforation, Absolute Neutrophil Count <500 cell/µl and Platelet count <50000 cells/µl.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IL-2: Drugs like basiliximab or daclizumab are used to target IL-2 receptors.

 

Option C. IL-4: Dupilumab is an example of a medication that targets IL-4.

 

Option D. IL-5: Mepolizumab and reslizumab are examples of medications that target IL-5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tocilizumab targets the IL-6 receptor, making it effective for managing rheumatoid arthritis and certain other inflammatory conditions by inhibiting the IL-6 signaling pathway.

questions.text: Which of these is not a symptom of cocaine poisoning? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bradycardia

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate (tachycardia) and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Signs of Cocaine intoxication:

 

 

Other options

 

Option A. Myocardial ischemia: Cocaine can induce myocardial ischemia due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties on coronary arteries.

 

Option C. Hyperthermia: Hyperthermia is a common symptom of cocaine intoxication due to increased metabolic activity and muscle activity.

 

Option D. Agitation: Agitation is a well-known effect of cocaine's stimulant properties on the central nervous system.

 

Educational Objective

 

Cocaine poisoning typically causes increased heart rate (tachycardia) rather than bradycardia, along with other symptoms like myocardial ischemia, hyperthermia, and agitation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules.
