Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: A child with acute lymphoblastic leukemia undergoes prophylactic irradiation prior to autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Which of the following will be the least affected? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Neurons

 

Explanation:

 

Neurons (Central nervous system) are the least affected by irradiation among the options given, due to their highly differentiated and non-dividing nature.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Spermatogonia: These are germ cells that continually divide and are highly sensitive to radiation, which can lead to infertility.

 

Option. B. Intestinal epithelial cells: These cells have a high turnover rate, making them very sensitive to radiation, which can result in gastrointestinal toxicity.

 

Option. D. Bone marrow/erythroid precursor cells: These cells are among the most sensitive to radiation due to their role in rapidly producing new blood cells, leading to potential marrow suppression.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Derailment

 

Formal thought disorders refer to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought, rather than the content of thought.

 

Here, the association between two successive thoughts is disturbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obsession: It refers to recurrent, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts. It's more related to possession than the form of thought.

 

Option C. Delusion: It is a false belief that is unshakeable and cannot be explained on the basis of a person's social and cultural background.It is a disorder of thought content.

 

Option D. Thought insertion: It is the belief that certain of one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather are inserted into one's mind. This is also a possession of thought, not its form.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Formal thought disorders pertain to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought. Derailment, loose associations, neologisms are examples of a formal thought disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 10

questions.text: After abstaining from alcohol for three days, a patient presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. In this case, what is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium tremens

 

The described clinical picture is consistent with Delirium tremens (DT). DT is a severe and potentially life-threatening complication of alcohol withdrawal. It typically appears 48 to 72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by agitation, disorientation, paranoid delusions, tremors, autonomic hyperactivity (such as tachycardia and hypertension), and visual or tactile hallucinations. It can be fatal if not treated promptly and properly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's encephalopathy: It is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, often seen in chronic alcoholics. Symptoms include ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis: It is a chronic neurologic sequelae of alcoholism resulting from prolonged thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by amnesia, confabulation, and lack of insight.

 

Option D. Alcohol-induced psychosis: It is a rare complication where patients present with hallucinations after heavy, prolonged alcohol consumption but without other features of withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277.

choices.text: Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On examination, he is noted to have subcutaneous emphysema and decreased breath sounds on the right side. His vital signs are unstable. What is the immediate management for this patient?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insertion of wide bore needle in the 5th intercostal space (ICS)

 

  • The clinical scenario of no air entry on the right side and unstable vitals suggests tension pneumothorax.
  • Tension pneumothorax is a life-threatening condition where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, leading to increased intrathoracic pressure.
  •  This pressure can shift the mediastinum, compromise venous return to the heart, and result in hypotension or shock.
  • Immediate needle decompression or needle thoracostomy is necessary, which involves inserting a wide-bore needle in the 5th ICS anterior to the mid-axillary line to relieve the trapped air and stabilize the patient.
  • The definitive management is tube thoracostomy or chest tube insertion in the 5th ICS in the triangle of safety.
  • The clinical findings suggest a tension pneumothorax. An immediate decompression is needed to prevent circulatory collapse by allowing trapped air to escape, which can stabilize the patient until a chest tube can be placed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV fluids for resuscitation: While fluid resuscitation is vital in the management of trauma patients, the priority in this scenario, given the clinical findings suggestive of tension pneumothorax, is to relieve the trapped air. While IV fluids can support the circulatory system, they won't address the primary problem, which is the tension pneumothorax. The priority in trauma management follows the Airway -> Breathing -> Circulation (ABC) protocol.

 

Option C. Intubation and positive pressure ventilation: Intubation and positive pressure ventilation can be dangerous in a patient with tension pneumothorax. Positive pressure ventilation can exacerbate the tension pneumothorax by forcing more air into the pleural space, which can lead to rapid cardiovascular collapse. Addressing the tension pneumothorax with needle decompression or chest tube insertion should be prioritized before considering intubation.

 

Option D. e-FAST (extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma): While e-FAST is a valuable tool in the trauma setting to quickly evaluate for the presence of free fluid (e.g., blood) in the peritoneal, pericardial, or pleural spaces, it may not be the immediate choice when a patient presents with clear signs and symptoms of a tension pneumothorax and is hemodynamically unstable. Immediate intervention to relieve the tension is essential, and while ultrasound can confirm the presence of pneumothorax, in an unstable patient, clinical judgment and prompt action are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression in the 5th intercostal space is the priority to relieve trapped air and stabilize the patient before further interventions.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for a patient who has paronychia on their index finger and is also showing a reddish streak on their forearm, as depicted in the image? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amoxiclav

 

  • The above image depicts paronychia associated with a reddish erythematous streak-like lesion on the hand suggestive of paronychia associated with lymphangitis, which is managed by elevating the affected extremity and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • A broad-spectrum antibiotic like Amoxiclav is appropriate for covering both the pathogens commonly responsible for the initial localized infection and the secondary systemic spread.

 

Acute paronychia:

 

It is infection of the nail fold which is characterized by inflammation, swelling and abscess formation.

Most common causative organism - Staphylococcus aureus
 

Diagnosis - Clinical

 

Management - Systemic antibiotics may be needed for deep infections.

 

Treatment of Acute paronychia -

 

  • Abscesses - Incised and drained (Abscess is often opened by pushing the nail fold away from the nail plate).
     
  • Antibiotics - Semisynthetic penicillin/cephalosporin with excellent anti-staphylococcal orally.

 

Complications - Osteitis and amputation.

 

Lymphangitis: represents acute inflammation elicited by the spread of bacterial infections into lymphatics with group A beta haemolytic streptococci being the most common causative agent.

 

Clinical features: Lymphangitis manifests as red painful subcutaneous streaks & painful enlargement of the draining lymph nodes (lymphadenitis). It is managed by elevating the affected extremity & broad spectrum antibiotics.

 

Chronic paronychia:

 

  • Most common causative organism - Candida albicans.
  • Candidal paronychia is most common in individuals who have their hands in water for a great deal of time.
  • Given recent evidence that Candida colonization may play a secondary role in chronic paronychia, with the primary insult being skin barrier breakdown resulting from wet work and possible contact dermatitis, a role for topical corticosteroids has been demonstrated.
  • Treatment - Topical antifungals & Topical corticosteroids.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metronidazole: Primarily effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain protozoa. While useful in skin and soft tissue infections involving anaerobes, it is not the first-line treatment for paronychia or lymphangitis which typically involve aerobic gram-positive cocci.

 

Option C. Amikacin: A powerful aminoglycoside antibiotic used primarily for severe, hospital-acquired infections with multi-drug resistant bacteria. It is not typically used for initial treatment of common skin infections due to its potential for causing significant side effects, including nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

 

Option D. Norfloxacin: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used primarily for gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections. While it has broad-spectrum activity, it is generally not the first choice for skin infections and is less effective against gram-positive organisms commonly causing skin infections.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Combination antibiotic Amoxiclav is indicated for the treatment of paronychia complicated by lymphangitis due to its broad-spectrum activity against both Gram-positive and resistant bacteria.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male patient presents with abdominal distension, reduced urine output, and pedal edema. His serum creatinine was 1.6 mg/dL. What is the next line of management in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Terlipressin plus albumin

 

The patient described has cirrhosis with signs of renal dysfunction, which suggests the possibility of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) (Remember - HRS is the diagnosis of exclusion)

 

HRS is a type of renal failure that occurs in patients with advanced liver disease and is characterized by functional renal failure due to reduced renal blood flow.

 

The initial management for suspected HRS involves stopping all diuretics, as they can exacerbate renal dysfunction.

 

The mainstay of treatment includes the administration of albumin to expand plasma volume and vasoconstrictors to improve renal blood flow. Terlipressin is a vasoconstrictor that is commonly used in combination with albumin to manage HRS. This combination helps to improve renal function by counteracting the splanchnic vasodilation that occurs in cirrhosis, thereby increasing effective arterial blood volume and renal perfusion.

 

Doses – The prescribed dose of albumin is 1 gram per kilogram of body weight per day. The maximum dose should not exceed 100 grams per day. Albumin should be administered for at least 48 hours, equivalent to 2 days.

 

It's important to avoid using normal saline or lactated solutions concurrently because they contain sodium, which could be contraindicated or undesirable in the treatment circumstances requiring albumin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methylprednisolone: Methylprednisolone is a corticosteroid and is not indicated in the treatment of hepatorenal syndrome. It is used for conditions such as autoimmune hepatitis or severe alcoholic hepatitis, but it does not address the pathophysiology of HRS.

 

Option B. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant and is not appropriate in this setting due to the increased risk of bleeding in patients with cirrhosis. It is used for preventing or treating thrombotic conditions but does not play a role in managing HRS.

 

Option C. Torsemide: Torsemide is a loop diuretic and should be discontinued in patients with HRS. Diuretics can worsen renal function in these patients by further decreasing renal perfusion and exacerbating the underlying problem of splanchnic vasodilation and renal vasoconstriction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with cirrhosis and suspected hepatorenal syndrome, the appropriate management includes the use of albumin combined with vasoconstrictors like terlipressin to improve renal function and address the underlying hemodynamic changes associated with HRS.

questions.text: A patient admitted with 50% burns develops an infection at the burn site. The swab was cultured, the isolate is a strict aerobe and the test that is shown in the image is positive. What is the likely etiology of the burn infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most common cause of infection in the case of a burn. The given image shows a positive oxidase test. Psuedomonas aeruginosa is a strict aerobe and shows a positive oxidase reaction.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility. They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

 

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa include-

 

  • ﻿﻿Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • ﻿﻿Pneumonia and sepsis in cystic fibrosis
  • ﻿﻿Wound infection and sepsis in burns
  • ﻿﻿Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis/ Jacuzzi syndrome is a type of folliculitis, occurring after hot tub exposure
  • ﻿﻿Shanghai fever is a febrile illness that manifests as severe enteric disease, sepsis with invasive disease.
  • ﻿﻿Ecthyma gangrenosum

 

Pathogenesis - It is an obligate aerobe that exerts its pathogenicity by the production of diphtheria-like exotoxin A and a slime layer

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa growth in a nutrient agar showing green coloured colonies are shown in the image below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Klebsiella: While also a common hospital-acquired pathogen, it is typically associated with respiratory and urinary tract infections, not specifically burns.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: Commonly causes gastrointestinal and urinary infections but is not typically associated with burn infections.

 

Option D. Salmonella: Known for causing gastrointestinal infections, not burn wound infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a burn wound infection is crucial due to its potential for rapid spread and resistance to treatment. Early detection and aggressive management are key to preventing severe complications such as sepsis or further tissue damage.

 

Oxidase test can be used to distinguish organisms by detecting the presence or absence of a respiratory enzyme, cytochrome oxidase. Cytochrome oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of reduced cytochrome by oxygen. Enterobacteriacee (Klebsiella, E. coli, Salmonella) are oxidase negative.

 

Oxidase positive organisms:

 

  • ﻿﻿Pseudomonas
  • ﻿﻿Vibrio
  • ﻿﻿Helicobacter
  • ﻿﻿Campylobacter
  • ﻿﻿Pasteurella
  • ﻿﻿Legionella
  • ﻿﻿Neisseria
  • ﻿﻿Brucella
  • ﻿﻿Moraxella
  • ﻿Burkholderia

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of fatigue persisting for the past year, accompanied by massive splenomegaly. A comprehensive blood workup has been performed, revealing several notable findings. The patient exhibits anemia and a significantly elevated total leukocyte count of 50,000/microL. Further analysis of the peripheral blood smear shows the presence of neutrophils (60%), basophils (4%), eosinophils, and myoblasts, myelocytes, and metamyelocytes. Additionally, the myeloid to erythroid ratio is found to be 18:1. Which investigation would be the most sensitive for further evaluation in this case: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) FISH and PCR

 

The clinical picture of fatigue, splenomegaly, and peripheral blood smear findings suggest chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests are used to detect the BCR-ABL gene, which is specific for CML.

 

Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative disorder that most commonly affects people in their fifth to sixth decade of life. A reciprocal (9;22) (g34;g11) translocation results in the creation of the chimeric BC-ABL gene (Philadelphia chromosome). This BCR-ABL gene differentiates ML from other myeloproliferative disorders and can be detected using fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH) or polymerase chain reaction (PCR) .

 

Clinical characteristics:

 

Mild to moderate anemia and hypermetabolism, fatigability, weakness, weight loss, and anorexia. Dragging sensation in the abdomen caused by splenomegaly, or the acute onset of left upper quadrant pain due to splenic infarction. The spleen is often greatly enlarged as a result of extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis.

 

Extramedullary hematopoiesis can also produce mild hepatomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

 

Peripheral blood:

 

  • Severe leukocytosis with a leukocyte count that frequently exceeds 100,000 cells/mm, primarily composed of neutrophils, band forms, metamyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils, and basophils.
  • Moderate normocytic normochromic anemia - Rising basophilia indicates impending blastic transformation.
  • The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • Blastic phase or blast crisis in CML satisfies the definition of acute leukemia by having more than 20% blood or marrow blasts.
  • Anemia of moderate severity - A rising basophilia is indicative of impending blastic transformation. - The accelerated phase is defined as an increasing degree of anaemia, a blast count in blood or marrow of 10-20%, a marrow basophil count of 20% or more, and a platelet count of less than 100,000/l.
  • A blast phase or blast crisis in CML meets the definition of acute leukemia by having blood or marrow blasts of more than 20%.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immunophenotyping: Used for the diagnosis of various hematologic malignancies, particularly lymphoid neoplasms. It is less specific for CML.

 

Option  B. LAP score (Leukocyte Alkaline Phosphatase): The LAP score is typically low in CML, but this test is less specific and has largely been replaced by molecular diagnostic techniques like FISH and PCR.

 

Option D. Flow cytometry: Useful for identifying and classifying hematologic malignancies based on cell surface markers but is not the most specific test for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) are the most sensitive investigations for detecting the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the hallmark of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML). These tests are crucial for accurate diagnosis and monitoring of CML.

choices.text: Adenylyl cyclase
Guanylyl cyclase
Phospholipase C

questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/ hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenylyl cyclase

 

Explanation

 

Beta 2 receptor action leading to hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia is mediated by adenylyl cyclase.

 

Catecholamines act through beta 2 receptors and they use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system to stimulate the target tissues.

 

Cyclic AMP is synthesized from ATP by the action of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase.

 

  • Binding of the hormone to its receptor activates a G protein which, in turn, activates adenylyl cyclase
  • The resulting rise in cAMP turns on the appropriate response in the cell by either (or both):
    • Changing the molecular activities in the cytosol, often using Protein Kinase A (PKA) — a cAMP-dependent protein kinase that phosphorylates target proteins
    • Turning on a new pattern of gene transcription

 

Cyclic AMP produces one or more of the following responses:

 

  1. Contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
  2. Alteration in the permeability of cell membrane
  3. Synthesis of substances inside the cell
  4. Secretion or release of substances by target cell
  5. Other physiological activities of the target cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guanylyl cyclase: Incorrect. While guanylyl cyclase also produces a cyclic nucleotide (cGMP) that acts as a second messenger, it is not involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Incorrect. Phospholipase C is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, not Gs-coupled receptors like the beta-2 receptors. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which are involved in calcium signaling.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: Incorrect. This enzyme liberates arachidonic acid from phospholipids, leading to the production of eicosanoids (like prostaglandins and leukotrienes). It is not directly involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other hormones that use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system are:

 

  • ACTH
  • Angiotensin II
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • Glucagon
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • HCG
  • Luteinizing hormone
  • Parathyroid hormone
  • Secretin
  • Somatostatin
  • TSH
  • Vasopressin

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

The patient's symptoms of overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination are indicative of a manic episode. Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomania: Similar to mania but the symptoms are milder, last for at least 4 days, and don't significantly impair social or occupational functioning.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: A mood disorder characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that don't meet the full criteria for a manic or major depressive episode.

 

Option D. Schizomania: This term is not standard in psychiatric diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365

questions.text: Following total thyroidectomy, a patient started having difficulty in breathing, and repeated attempts to extubate were unsuccessful. The most probable cause is: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury

 

The clinical picture is suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.

 

Bilateral recurrent laryngeal injury is commonly seen in total thyroidectomy.

 

  • Injury to both RLNs results in paralysis of intrinsic muscles of the larynx. The vocal cords cannot be abducted and thus come to lie in a median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid. This results in compromised laryngeal airway causing respiratory distress and stridor.
  • Tracheostomy is done as an emergency procedure to secure the airway.
  • Widening the respiratory airway without a permanent tracheostomy can be achieved by:
    1. Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
    2. Partial arytenoidectomy
    3. Reinnervation procedures - these are used to innervate paralyzed posterior cricoarytenoid muscle by implanting a nerve-muscle pedicle of sternohyoid or omohyoid muscle with its nerve supply from ansa hypoglossi.
    4.  Thyroplasty type II – lateralisation of vocal cords

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Superior laryngeal nerve injury - This would primarily affect voice pitch and not typically cause significant breathing difficulty.

 

Option B. Unilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury - Would lead to hoarseness but not usually severe breathing issues as one vocal cord would still function.

 

Option D. Hematoma - Although it can cause acute respiratory distress if it compresses the trachea, it does not typically lead to issues with extubation unless it is very severe.

 

Educational Objective:


Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve injury after thyroidectomy is a serious complication that can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. Immediate recognition and management are crucial to ensure the safety and recovery of the patient.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 339

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia.
  • Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and are located medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • The appropriate surgical method for the management of a direct hernia is the Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • The Lichtenstein mesh repair is a tension-free technique that uses a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weakened area of the abdominal wall.
  •  It is the preferred method for direct hernias due to its lower recurrence rates and faster recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct hernia and Bassini repair: While the Bassini repair is a traditional method of hernia repair, it involves suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament without using a mesh. This technique is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis but has a high recurrence rate compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option C. Indirect hernia and Bassini repair: Incorrect. Indirect hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and are managed differently. The Bassini repair, as mentioned, is less commonly used today due to its higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair: Incorrect. While the Lichtenstein mesh repair can also be used for indirect hernias, the scenario describes a direct hernia based on its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is characterized by its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery, and the Lichtenstein mesh repair is the recommended surgical approach due to its efficacy and lower recurrence rates.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An abdominal X-ray was done, as shown below. Identify the bowel segment involved? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Jejunum

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario and X-ray are suggestive of intestinal obstruction where the involved segment is the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are centrally located and have valvulae conniventes (complete mucosal folds), indicating jejunal involvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. B. Ileum: Typically, ileal loops are located more peripherally and may show less prominent valvulae conniventes.

 

Option. C. Duodenum: Not usually seen as prominently distended in obstructions due to its fixed retroperitoneal location and smaller length.

 

Option. D. Transverse colon: Would generally show haustrations (sacculations) rather than valvulae conniventes, and distension would be more peripherally located.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Give antibiotics and send the patient home
Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation
Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a cough with yellowish sputum. Auscultation revealed bronchial breath sounds. He is hemodynamically stable and not confused. On examination, his respiratory rate is 20/min and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Lab reports show urea levels of 44 mg/dL. What is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Consider admission in a non-ICU setting

 

The patient's presentation suggests a lower respiratory tract infection, likely pneumonia, given the cough with yellow sputum and bronchial breath sounds on auscultation. The management decision can be guided by the CURB-65 score, which helps determine the severity of pneumonia and the need for hospitalization.

 

The CURB-65 score components are:

 

  • Confusion: No
  • Urea > 7 mmol/L (19 mg/dL): Yes (urea is 44 mg/dL)
  • Respiratory rate ≥ 30/min: No (respiratory rate is 20/min)
  • Blood pressure (systolic < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg): No (BP is 110/70 mmHg)
  • Age ≥ 65 years: Yes (patient is 68 years old)

 

The patient has two points (urea > 19 mg/dL and age ≥ 65 years).

 

Based on the CURB-65 score:

 

  • 0 points: Outpatient treatment
  • 1 point: Consider outpatient treatment or short inpatient stay
  • 2 points: Inpatient treatment
  • 3-5 points: Consider ICU admission

 

The patient scores 2 points, indicating the need for inpatient treatment but not necessarily in the ICU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give antibiotics and send the patient home: This would be appropriate for a patient with a CURB-65 score of 0 or possibly 1, but not for a score of 2, which indicates a higher risk that necessitates closer monitoring in an inpatient setting.

 

Option B. Admit to ICU without mechanical ventilation: ICU admission is generally reserved for patients with a CURB-65 score of 3 or higher, indicating severe pneumonia. This patient's condition does not meet those criteria.

 

Option C. Admit to ICU with invasive mechanical ventilation: This is appropriate for patients with very severe pneumonia (CURB-65 score of 4-5) or those in respiratory distress, neither of which applies to this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with pneumonia, the CURB-65 score is a useful tool for determining the appropriate level of care. A score of 2 typically indicates the need for inpatient treatment in a non-ICU setting.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with fever and massive splenomegaly. On palpation, the spleen was 15 cm and directed obliquely when measured from the right iliac fossa. Which of the following structures prevent the vertical and downward descent of the spleen? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Phrenicocolic ligament

 

  • The downward movement of the spleen is naturally prevented by the phrenicocolic ligament, which does not attach to the spleen itself but supports its anterior end.
  • This ligament is a horizontal fold of peritoneum that extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, opposite of the 11th rib in the midaxillary line. The phrenicocolic ligament also limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.
  • In cases where the spleen becomes enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament and splenic flexure of the colon restrict its downward displacement. This enlargement typically occurs towards the right iliac fossa, causing the spleen to be directed obliquely.
  • By supporting the anterior end of the spleen, the phrenicocolic ligament plays an important role in preventing its excessive movement and displacement within the abdominal cavity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lienorenal ligament: This ligament connects the hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney and contains the tail of the pancreas and vessels that supply the spleen. It helps to hold the spleen in its anatomical position, preventing it from moving medially.

 

Option B. Gastrosplenic ligament: This is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. It contains the short gastric vessels and contributes to the attachment of the spleen to the stomach. It prevents the spleen from moving too far posteriorly.

 

Option D. Lienophrenic ligament: The term "lienophrenic ligament" isn't a standard anatomical term. The spleen does have ligamentous connections with the diaphragm, but these are typically referred to as part of the lienorenal and gastrosplenic ligaments. Therefore, this option might be a misnomer or less commonly used terminology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phrenicocolic ligament extends from the left colic (splenic) flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. It's positioned to the left side of the abdomen and is an important anatomical landmark. It acts as a supportive structure, supporting the left colic flexure and acting as a barrier. Importantly, it prevents the downward and medial displacement of the spleen, especially when the spleen enlarges, as in cases of splenomegaly.

 

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

questions.text: A child with a history of night-blindness presented to you with the following findings. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Phrynoderma

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a child with night blindness and multiple hyperkeratotic papules on the elbows, as depicted in the image, raises suspicion of a diagnosis called phrynoderma or toad-skin. This condition is often linked to a deficiency of vitamin A (VAD).
  • It is characterized by the development of keratotic follicular papules, initially appearing on the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms, and subsequently spreading to the extensor surfaces of the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, back, buttocks, face, and posterior neck.
  • While originally reported in association with vitamin A deficiency, phrynoderma is a non-specific finding that can also be observed in deficiencies of B-complex vitamins, vitamin C, vitamin E, essential fatty acids (EFA deficiency), protein-energy malnutrition (PEM), and general states of malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Keratosis pilaris:

  • Description: Keratosis pilaris is a common, benign skin condition that manifests as tiny, rough-feeling bumps on the skin, often likened to "chicken skin." It frequently occurs on the upper arms, thighs, or cheeks.
  • It usually presents during puberty. Perifollicular erythema in addition to follicular plugging
  • Favors the upper outer arms and the thighs, but lacks discrete clusters. Treatment is purely reserved for cosmetic purposes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis:  While keratosis pilaris can appear on the upper arms close to the elbows, it's not specifically associated with night-blindness or vitamin A deficiency.

 

Option C. Darier disease:

  • Description: Darier disease is a rare, genetic skin disorder characterized by small, hard bumps on the skin, especially on the chest, back, and forehead. These may be yellowish in color and often have a foul odor.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis While Darier disease causes papules, it is not associated with night-blindness. Other features of Darier disease are also not mentioned in the question.

 

Option D. Follicular eczema:

  • Description: This is a variant of eczema (atopic dermatitis) that specifically affects the hair follicles, leading to itchy, inflamed skin.
  • Reasons it might not fit: Though follicular eczema can cause papules, the association with night-blindness is not seen. Eczema would typically be associated with itching and possibly a history of allergies or atopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical students preparing for residency, it is crucial to associate the findings of follicular hyperkeratotic papules, especially when coupled with systemic symptoms such as night-blindness, with phrynoderma, a condition related to vitamin A deficiency.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page no 63.8

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought to the hospital with multiple fractures of the humerus secondary to a fall from height. On examination, there is difficulty in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, and associated loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. Which nerve is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Musculocutaneous nerve

 

  • The clinical vignette presented in a patient with difficulty flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm, as well as loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm, is suggestive of musculocutaneous nerve injury.
  • One of the most common causes of humerus fractures is a fall from a great height on an outstretched hand.

 

Musculocutaneous Nerve:

 

It is a branch of the brachial plexus, it pierces the coracobrachialis muscle in the arm.

 

Muscles Innervated: Supplies the brachialis, biceps brachii, and coracobrachialis muscles.

 

Sensory Distribution: Sends sensory fibers as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm, providing sensation to the lateral (radial) aspect of the forearm.

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in flexion of the elbow and supination of the forearm due to affected biceps. Loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and enters the forearm between the two heads of the pronator teres.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Primarily supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and thenar muscles in the hand.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the lateral (radial) three and a half fingers and the corresponding palm area.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of flexion of the wrist, loss of flexion of lateral fingers, and loss of thumb opposition. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option B. Radial Nerve: It also originates from the brachial plexus and travels posteriorly in the arm.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the triceps brachii and the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the back of the arm, forearm, and dorsum of the hand on the radial side.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Wrist drop" due to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the brachial plexus and passes posterior to the medial epicondyle of the humerus (the "funny bone").

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies many of the small muscles of the hand and some flexors in the forearm.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the medial (ulnar) one and a half fingers and the corresponding area of the palm and dorsum.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: "Claw hand" deformity due to loss of function in the ulnar half of the hand. Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

 

AQl categories and the range are as follows:

questions.text: A person had a meal at 8 pm and records blood glucose at 7 am on the next day. What’s the source of glucose in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatic Glycogenolysis

 

  • Hepatic glycogenolysis involves the breakdown of glycogen stored in the liver into glucose. This process provides source of blood glucose for 12-18 hours, So By 7 am the next day, liver's glycogen stores is the main source of blood glucose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dietary Glucose: Dietary glucose from the previous evening's meal would have been absorbed and utilized or stored shortly after eating. By 7 am the next day, the influence of dietary glucose on blood glucose levels would have diminished significantly. It is unlikely to be the primary source of the elevated glucose.

 

Option B. Hepatic Gluconeogenesis: Hepatic gluconeogenesis is the process by which the liver produces glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors, such as amino acids and glycerol. During overnight fasting, the liver actively engages in gluconeogenesis to maintain blood glucose levels. It happens mainly only after 18 hours or more of fasting.

 

Option D. Muscle Glycogenolysis: Muscle glycogenolysis primarily supplies glucose for use within muscle tissue itself and is not a major contributor to blood glucose levels during fasting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The person is fasting for last 11 hours. First source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose that can provide glucose for upto 2 hours after meals (option a is excluded).  After that liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose for next 12-18 hours of fasting (option c is answer).

 

Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glycogen is exhausted i.e. only after 12 hours onwards (option b is wrong answer).

 

Muscle glycogen cannot maintain blood glucose as the end-product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6-phosphate due to absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle (option D is wrong answer). This enzyme is only present in liver cell’s ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/pg. 176

questions.text: The image of a drug is given below. It is used in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Subglottic stenosis

 

The given drug is Mitomycin-C. It is used topically in the management of subglottic stenosis.

 

Mitomycin is an antibiotic that is isolated from the broth of Streptomyces caespitosus. This drug has demonstrated antitumor activity. Mitomycin belongs to a group of alkylating agents that work by cross-linking the complementary strands found in DNA. It also has antifibrotic property which prevents tissue scarring.

 

Thus, it can used to inhibit post-surgical scar formation and as a chemotherapeutic agent.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Rhinocerebral mucormycosis - This fungal infection requires antifungal medications, not typically treated with Mitomycin-C.

 

Option C. Adenoidectomy - A surgical procedure to remove adenoids; does not involve the use of Mitomycin-C.

 

Option D. Tympanoplasty - Surgical repair of the eardrum, where Mitomycin-C is not routinely used.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Mitomycin-C is particularly effective in preventing the recurrence of subglottic stenosis after surgery due to its antifibrotic properties, making it a critical adjunct in surgical procedures involving the airway.

 

Ref - Scott Brown 8th edition, volume 3, Page No. 1088

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10g/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Distal intestinal obstruction

 

The child's presentation of recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea (bulky, greasy stools) is indicative of cystic fibrosis (CF). CF is a genetic disorder that affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to severe respiratory infections and malabsorption of nutrients.

 

In CF, thick mucus secretions can lead to blockages in various parts of the body. One of the common gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), where thickened stool causes obstruction in the distal part of the small intestine. This condition is seen more frequently in older children and adults with CF, especially after the introduction of pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT).

 

The treatment of choice for distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS), which primarily involves the use of laxatives like PEG (Polyethylene glycol) is effective because it works by osmotically drawing water into the intestine, which helps to soften the stool and promote bowel movements, thereby alleviating the obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protein losing enteropathy: This condition can occur in CF, but it is more common in the infantile period or up to 2 years of age due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency. It is not a primary concern in a 10-year-old child with CF presenting with the given symptoms.

 

Option C. Hypernatremia: Hypernatremia is not typically seen in CF. Instead, CF patients often exhibit hyponatremia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis due to excessive chloride loss through sweat. This electrolyte imbalance is characteristic of CF.

 

Option D. Rectal prolapse occurs after treatment: Rectal prolapse was historically a common manifestation of untreated CF in young children. However, with effective treatment, including pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy, rectal prolapse is now rare and does not usually occur after treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea are common, and one of the significant gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS). This condition should be considered in CF patients presenting with symptoms of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Putty kidney

 

  • The given image finding of a putty kidney is suggestive of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB).
  • Putty kidney is characterized by a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney.
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria and is always a secondary TB caused by dissemination through the bloodstream.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or acid-fast bacilli staining and culture of urine samples.
  • CT urography is the preferred imaging modality for visualizing renal calcifications and assessing the various stages of renal TB.
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs and surgical intervention may be necessary, such as partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis: Is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Staghorncalculus: Kidney stones are a type of large urinary calculus that takes up a large portion of the urinary collecting area in the kidney. They often present in only one kidney, but in up to 15% of cases, they form in both. They often form due to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: Refers to the calcification (formation of calcium deposits) in the psoas muscle, which is a large muscle in the lower back that plays a role in hip flexion and trunk stabilization. Psoas calcification is not directly related to kidney or urinary system conditions and may have other underlying causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney.
  •  This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography.
  •  Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A group of 20 friends kept partying till late at night. Two of them ate pastries from outside. They present with nausea and vomiting in the early morning. What is the most likely causative agent implicated? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterotoxin of Staphylococcus

 

The most likely causative agent in the given scenario is enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus. It causes food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption of the contaminated food.

 

The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Patients present with nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhea.

 

Food poisoning is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting center of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type A toxin is responsible for most cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Emetic toxin of B. cereus: Food poisoning after consumption of fried rice or chinese street food is strongly suggestive of Bacillus cereus (Serotypes 1, 3, 5). Two mechanisms of action have been described for the enterotoxin of B. cereus, one involving stimulation of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) system and the other independent of it. Food poisoning after eating food contaminated with Bacillus cereus is of two types, namely diarrheal type and emetic type, caused by an enterotoxin and an emetic toxin respectively.

 

Option C. Verocytotoxin from E. coli: Associated with a different set of symptoms primarily involving severe abdominal cramps and bloody diarrhea, not rapid-onset vomiting.

 

Option D. Shiga toxin from Shigella: Causes dysentery, which is characterized by fever, abdominal pain, and bloody diarrhea, not primarily vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enterotoxin of Staphylococcus aureus can cause rapid-onset food poisoning characterized by nausea and vomiting, typically within hours after consuming contaminated food such as pastries. Remembering the association between specific foods and pathogens can aid in prompt diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol (398 mg/dl) & LDL (220 mg/dl) were found to be raised. Statins were given to this patient. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Familial hypercholesterolemia

 

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is a genetic disorder characterized by significantly elevated levels of LDL cholesterol in the blood. Tendon xanthomas are a common feature of FH. Statins are commonly prescribed to lower LDL cholesterol levels in FH patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipoprotein lipase deficiency: Lipoprotein lipase deficiency is a different condition that affects the breakdown of triglycerides in lipoproteins, not cholesterol metabolism. It does not typically present with tendon xanthomas.

 

Option C. Tangier's disease: Tangier's disease is a rare genetic disorder that leads to very low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol. It does not typically present with elevated LDL cholesterol levels or tendon xanthomas.

 

Option D. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is a neurological disorder and is not related to cholesterol metabolism or tendon xanthomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All of the conditions i.e. tendon xanthomas, high serum cholesterol and LDL levels and statin therapy which is given to inhibit rate limiting enzyme HMG CoA reductase of cholesterol biosynthesis indicate that cholesterol is raised in this patient. So, the most probable diagnosis is Familial hypercholesterolemia aka Type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia that occur due to deficiency of LDL receptor on liver or Apo B100 mutation.

 

Lipoprotein lipase deficiency or Apo C- II defect cause familial hyperchylomicronemia or Type I hyperlipoproteinemia with raised plasma chylomicrons and TG levels.

 

In Tangier’s disease, there is defect in ABCA1 receptors causing low levels of plasma HDL.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 258

questions.text: A vagabond roaming in the forest eats some unknown fruits. After sometime he starts having symptoms of irritability, restlessness, dry hot skin, and was unable to pass urine and stools. Identify the poison and its appropriate antidote: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Datura, Physostigmine

 

Diagnostic features of Datura poisoning in the question

 

  • Datura has mainly neurotoxic (Irritability, restlessness) and anticholinergic features (Dry hot skin, unable to urinate and pass stool)
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice for Datura

 

Datura poisoning:

 

  • Common names - thorn apple, Jimson weed, and Devil's trumpet.
  • Active principle - Atropine, Scopolamine, and Hyoscyamine.
  • Features of Datura poisoning (D's of Datura): Dry hot skin, Dilatation of pupils, Diplopia, Dry mouth, Dysphagia, Dysarthria, Drunken gait, Delirium, Drowsiness, Death.
  • Datura causes constipation, not diarrhoea

 

Treatment of Datura Poisoning:

 

  • Datura is an anticholinergic plant poison and antidote is a cholinergic drug.
  • Physostigmine is the antidote of choice
  • Neostigmine isn’t preferred as it doesn’t cross blood brain barrier, and hence does not reverse atropine induced CNS toxicity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Datura, Pralidoxime: Pralidoxime is used for organophosphate poisoning, not for anticholinergic toxicity caused by Datura.

 

Option C. Yellow oleander, Digoxin: Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside and not an antidote. The treatment for yellow oleander poisoning includes atropine and antiarrhythmics, not digoxin.

 

Option D. Yellow oleander, Physostigmine: Physostigmine is not the antidote for yellow oleander poisoning, which primarily affects the heart rather than causing anticholinergic symptoms.

 

Additional Information

 

Oleander Plant

 

  • There are two oleander plants: Nerium odorum and Cerbera Thevetia
  • Both are cardiac poisons
  • Both have digoxin like toxicity:
    • Heart failure (Fall in BP, arrhythmias, weak pulse, circulatory collapse).
    • Similar to digitalis.
    •  Muscle spasm like that seen in strychnine poisoning.
  • Treatment of Both Oleander poisoning:
    • Atropine for sinus bradycardia and AV block
    • Antiarrhythmics: lignocaine
    • Digoxin-specific antibodies for severe arrhythmias

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Datura poisoning is characterized by neurotoxic and anticholinergic symptoms, and the appropriate antidote is Physostigmine, which can cross the blood-brain barrier and reverse CNS toxicity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with AIDS presented with fever and productive cough. On auscultation, bronchial breath sounds and crepitations were heard in the right infra-scapular region. Chest X-ray showed right lower lobe consolidation. The CD4 count was 55 cells/mm3. What is the most common causative organism for this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

In patients with AIDS, regardless of their CD4 count, the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia is Streptococcus pneumoniae. This organism is a leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised patients.

 

The clinical presentation of fever, productive cough, bronchial breath sounds, and right lower lobe consolidation on chest X-ray is consistent with bacterial pneumonia. While Pneumocystis jirovecii (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii) is a common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients with low CD4 counts, it typically presents with bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray and less commonly with lobar consolidation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumocystis jirovecii: Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP) is common in AIDS patients with CD4 counts below 200 cells/mm³. It usually presents with diffuse bilateral infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus can cause pneumonia, especially post-viral or in hospital-acquired cases, but it is not the most common cause of pneumonia in AIDS patients. It can also present with abscess formation and necrotizing pneumonia, which were not described here.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma: Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a common cause of atypical pneumonia, especially in younger patients, but it is less likely in this immunocompromised patient with typical lobar consolidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with AIDS, Streptococcus pneumoniae remains the most common cause of bacterial pneumonia, regardless of the CD4 count. This should be a primary consideration when evaluating pneumonia in this population.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological examination of the specimen showed Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retinoblastoma

 

The most likely diagnosis with a histopathological finding of Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen, which is highly characteristic of retinoblastoma.

 

 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children.
  • It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14.
  • It is a tumour of a group called small round blue cell tumours because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.
  • Most common presentation is leukocoria.
  • 2nd most common symptom is squint.
  • Clinical Features:

 

i). Quiescent stage:

  • Characterized by Leukocoria which is also known as Amaurotic cat’s eye appearance, convergent squint, defective vision and nystagmus (seen in bilateral cases).
  • Ophthalmoscopically, endophytic retinoblastoma gives “cottage cheese appearance” whereas exophytic tumor present as exudative retinal detachment.

 

ii). Glaucomatous stage:

  • Presents as severe pain, redness and watering. It may also result in hyphemia or pseudo hypopyon (contains tumor cells).

 

iii). Extraocular extension:

  • Globe burst through sclera near limbus and presents as marked proptosis.

 

iv). Distant metastasis:

  • Metastasis of retinoblastoma spread to
  • Optic nerve via direct extension
  • Pre-auricular lymph nodes via lymphatics
  • Cranial bones via blood
  • Microscopy – Flexner-Winter Steiner rosettes.
  • Treatment:
  • Enucleation
  • Chemotherapy→ intra-arterial chemo – melphalan in ophthalmic artery is very successful.
  • VEC is very successful:
  • V – Vincristine
  • E – Etoposide
  • C – Carboplatin

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: A malignant brain tumor located in the posterior fossa, not associated with intraocular findings or leukocoria.

 

Option C. Rhabdomyosarcoma: A soft tissue sarcoma affecting muscles, often presenting as a mass in the orbit but not causing leukocoria or associated with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Option D. Astrocytoma: A tumor of the central nervous system (glial origin), which does not occur intraocularly and is not linked with Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes are a hallmark of retinoblastoma, indicating a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells. This specific histopathological finding is crucial for diagnosing retinoblastoma, especially in children presenting with leukocoria.

 

Different rosettes seen in retinoblastoma:
 

1. True rosette -FLEXNER-WINTERSTEINER ROSETTE

  • This is specific for RB - hallmark of RB
  • It consists of tumor cells surrounding a central lumen that contains cytoplasmic extensions from the tumor cells, which have well-differentiated features suggestive of primitive photoreceptor cells.

 

2. HOMER-WRIGHT ROSETTE is a non-specific rosette seen in any of the primitive neuroectodermal tumors. Tumor cells surround a central region containing neutrophil.

 

3. FLUERETTE is pseudo rosette because the central structure is not a part of the tumor and it consists of tumor cells around a blood vessel.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presented with generalized weakness, which increased towards the evening and improved with 5-10 minutes of rest in between. On examination, he also had ptosis and some difficulty in swallowing. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Myasthenia Gravis

 

Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness and fatigability, which typically worsens with activity and improves with rest. The hallmark of MG is weakness that is more pronounced towards the end of the day or after prolonged activity, and this weakness improves after a period of rest.

 

Key features in this patient’s presentation include:

 

  • Generalized weakness that increases in the evening.
  • Improvement in weakness with short rest periods.
  • Presence of ptosis (drooping eyelids) and difficulty in swallowing, which are common manifestations of MG.

 

In MG, autoantibodies attack the acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. This leads to the characteristic symptoms of fluctuating weakness and fatigability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: Lambert Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS) is a paraneoplastic syndrome often associated with small cell lung cancer. It also involves muscle weakness but typically improves with exercise rather than worsening, which is opposite to the pattern seen in MG.

 

Option C. Peripheral Neuropathy: Peripheral neuropathy generally presents with sensory disturbances, weakness, and diminished reflexes in a stocking-glove distribution. It does not typically cause fluctuating weakness or specific muscle group involvement such as ptosis.

 

Option D. Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (DMD) is a genetic disorder that presents in early childhood with progressive muscle weakness, particularly in the proximal muscles. It is highly unlikely to present in a 76-year-old man as it typically leads to severe disability or death by early adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia Gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. Key clinical features include ptosis, difficulty swallowing, and generalized weakness with a diurnal variation.

 

Most sensitive diagnosis is supported by single fiber EMG and most specific investigation is antibody tests, such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and anti-muscle specific kinase antibodies.

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage for molar pregnancy 6 months ago presents with persistent symptoms of abdominal pain and distention. On further evaluation, the beta- hCG levels were persistently elevated and cannonball foci were found on the chest X-ray. What is the appropriate management in this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate with folinic acid

 

Explanation:

 

Methotrexate with folinic acid: This is a clear case of post-molar choriocarcinoma with lung metastases. Treatment is based on prognostication and staging. According to the given scoring system, the parameters such as the time interval since the antecedent pregnancy, beta-hCG levels, and the presence of lung metastases suggest a low-risk choriocarcinoma. For low-risk choriocarcinoma, the recommended treatment is multi-dose single-agent chemotherapy with methotrexate. Methotrexate is administered in a multi-dose regimen (Day 1, 3, 5, 7) alternating with folinic acid (Day 2, 4, 6, 8).

 

 

  • < 6: LOW RISK
  • > 7 HIGH RISK

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Methotrexate: Methotrexate alone might be considered for very low-risk cases. However, in this case, with persistent elevated beta-hCG levels and lung metastases, a multi-dose regimen along with folinic acid is preferred to enhance efficacy and reduce toxicity.

 

Option C. EMACO regimen: The EMACO regimen, which includes etoposide, methotrexate, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, and vincristine, is used for high-risk choriocarcinoma. This patient's score indicates a low-risk profile, making EMACO unnecessary and more toxic than needed.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for choriocarcinoma, especially in the context of low-risk metastatic disease. It may be considered in cases of heavy bleeding or when the disease is confined to the uterus and chemotherapy is not effective.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low-risk choriocarcinoma post-molar pregnancy with lung metastases is treated with a multi-dose regimen of methotrexate alternating with folinic acid

 

Ref: Page 789, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient visits you with inflammatory alopecia. This type of hair loss is commonly associated with which variant of tinea capitis infection? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Favus and Kerion

 

Favus and kerion are the inflammatory variants of tinea capitis.

 

Tinea capitis variants:

 

 

Kerion presents in Children with boggy swelling, easily pluckable hair, with regional lymphadenopathy. It is a severe inflammatory type of tinea capitis. The. In severe cases, there may be pus along with sinus formation.

 

Kerion:

 

 

  • Lesion: boggy indurated scalp swelling
  • Easily pluckable hair associated with regional lymphadenopathy
  • Most common causative organisms:  Zoophilic dermatophytes i.e., T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes.
  • Investigation: 10% KOH mount
  • Treatment: DOC overall and for Microsporum àGriseofulvin

 

Note: DOC for Trichophyton is Terbinafine.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Endothrix and Favus and Option D: Kerion and Endothrix Endothrix infections involve the growth of fungi within the hair shaft without external spore formation and typically present with less inflammation compared to Kerion and Favus.

 

Option B: Ectothrix and Endothrix Ectothrix infections, where the fungus grows on the outside of the hair shaft and breaks the hair off at the scalp surface, are typically associated with non-inflammatory forms of alopecia such as the 'grey patch' type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammatory alopecia is commonly associated with the favus and kerion variants of tinea capitis, which can cause scarring and permanent hair loss due to the significant inflammatory response.

 

 

Reference:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Page no 32.39-40, 89.35

choices.text: E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate Decarboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase
E1: Pyruvate carboxylase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase
E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

questions.text: This multienzyme complex converts Pyruvate to Acetyl CoA. Identify E1 and E2: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) E1: Pyruvate dehydrogenase E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase

 

Explanation:

 

The provided images depict the components and functioning of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, a key multienzyme complex in the metabolic pathway that converts pyruvate into acetyl-CoA, an essential step linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle. This complex requires vitamins B1, B2, B3, B5, and lipoic acid as cofactors.

 

Table: Components of PDH complex and their roles

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyruvate Decarboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as Pyruvate Decarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA in this context, and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase is the E3 component of the complex.

 

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase and Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase: Incorrect because Pyruvate carboxylase is involved in a different metabolic pathway (gluconeogenesis), not in the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA.

 

Option D. Pyruvate dehydrogenase and Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase: Incorrect as the second enzyme is E3 in this complex, not E2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 162

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is not compliant with spectacles for her myopic astigmatism. What would be the appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Spherical equivalent spectacles

 

The appropriate management for myopic astigmatism in a 15-year-old girl (<18 years) would be spherical equivalent spectacles.

 

The three components of prescription in astigmatism are:

 

  • Power of the spherical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre sphere (DS)
  • Power of the cylindrical component, indicated by a positive (+) or negative (-) dioptre cylinder (DC)
  • Axis or orientation of the cylinder.

 

The cylindrical power and axis are correcting the astigmatic part of the refractive error. If an astigmatic eye were to be corrected with a spherical lens alone, the result would be a blur circle on the retina, called the circle of least confusion.

 

The spherical lens power places the circle of least confusion on the retina and is called the spherical equivalent. It is defined as the spherical power whose focal point coincides with the circle of least confusion, where one would see minimal blurring in their vision.
 

 

For example, for spherical power is +2 and cylindrical power is +3,

Spherical equivalent = +2.00 +(+3.00 /2) = +3.50.

 

Spherical equivalent spectacles are given if one has to give less cylinder power than was measured.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. and C - LASIK and Femto LASIK: should be done in patients above 18 years of age.

 

Option D. Implantable Collamer lens: is indicated for patients 21-45 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical interventions like LASIK and Femto LASIK are not recommended for individuals under 18 years of age.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: The floods had an impact on Kerala's Pathanamthitta district, leading the government to provide doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis. What other chemical is set to be distributed in conjunction with this? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Zinc phosphide

 

Explanation - 

 

The government distributed doxycycline tablets for prophylaxis following floods in Kerala to prevent the spread of diseases such as leptospirosis, acute diarrheal diseases, and dengue.

  • Leptospirosis, which is caused by contaminated water with rodent urine, can be prevented by chemoprophylaxis with Doxycycline, using rubber shoes and gloves, anti-rodent measures, and establishing a proper drainage system.
  • Zinc phosphide is used for chemical control of rodents due to its good safety record, low cost and high effectiveness
  • Chlorine tablets and bleaching powder are used to disinfect household water supply. Insecticides and larvicides like abate are used for indoor residual sprays for drinking water.
  • General hygiene and sanitary measures must also be followed to control the spread of diseases during floods.

questions.text: A teacher demonstrated handwashing procedures to her students. Students repeated the activity later in the day and at home. What kind of learning is going on here? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychomotor

 

The scenario described involves the teacher demonstrating a physical skill (handwashing), which the students then practice and replicate. This type of learning pertains to the acquisition of motor skills and involves physical movement and coordination, making it psychomotor learning.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cognitive: It pertains to mental skills or acquiring knowledge. It involves understanding, reasoning, and thinking processes.

 

Option C. Affective: It relates to feelings, values, attitudes, motivations, and appreciations.

 

Option D. Affective and cognitive: It would involve both emotions/attitudes and mental processes, which is not the primary focus in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychomotor learning involves the acquisition and refinement of motor skills and requires physical movement and coordination. It is demonstrated in this scenario by students learning and practicing the handwashing procedure shown by their teacher.

 

Reference: Milde FK. The Function of Feedback in Psychomotor-Skill Learning. Western Journal of Nursing Research. 1988;10(4):425-434.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with a history of abdominal pain and fever for the past three days presents to the hospital. The physician orders a chest X-ray in the erect position which shows abnormal findings. Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis will be determined? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hollow viscus perforation

 

  • Air under the diaphragm is seen in the given erect radiograph, which is a characteristic finding of hollow viscus perforation.
  •  Perforation of a viscus can lead to peritonitis, which is inflammation of the peritoneum due to the spillage of fluids into the peritoneal cavity or secondary bacterial infection.
  • Clinical features of hollow viscus perforation include abdominal pain, distension, nausea, vomiting, tachycardia, tenderness, rebound tenderness, and guarding on palpation.
  •  Fever may also be present, and septic shock can occur in later stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric volvulus: Gastric volvulus refers to the twisting of the stomach on its axis. It can result in obstruction and ischemia. Symptoms include severe epigastric pain, vomiting, and difficulty in passing a nasogastric tube.
