On imaging, the stomach may be abnormally positioned, often with a characteristic appearance described as an "inverted stomach" or "upside-down stomach." While it can cause serious complications, air under the diaphragm on an erect chest radiograph is not typically associated with gastric volvulus.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is typically caused by bacterial or amoebic infection. Symptoms include fever, abdominal pain, jaundice, and weight loss. An erect chest radiograph isn't the primary modality to diagnose a liver abscess. Instead, an ultrasound or CT scan of the abdomen would be more appropriate to visualize an abscess within the liver.

 

Option D. Empyema thoracis: Empyema refers to the accumulation of pus in the pleural cavity (space between the lung and the chest wall). It's usually a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. Symptoms include fever, cough, chest pain, and breathlessness. On a chest radiograph, the empyema may appear as a fluid level or a white opacity, depending on its stage and the amount of fluid. An erect chest X-ray may be used to diagnose empyema, but it would not typically show free air under the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Air under the diaphragm seen on an erect chest radiograph is a hallmark finding of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a surgical emergency requiring immediate attention to prevent peritonitis and other severe complications.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male underwent surgery for rectal prolapse, and a postoperative image was obtained. Can you identify the procedure that was most likely performed on the patient from the given image below ? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thiersch stitch

 

  • The postoperative image suggests the use of Thiersch wiring for rectal prolapse.
  • Thiersch's wiring involves placing a steel wire or a silastic/nylon tape around the anal canal.
  • It is now rarely done due to postoperative problems such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stapled hemorrhoidopexy: A minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat internal hemorrhoids by repositioning prolapsed tissue back to its normal anatomical position with a circular stapling device. This procedure does not align with the provided image of Thiersch wiring.

 

Option B. Well's procedure: An abdominal procedure for rectal prolapse that involves repositioning and attaching the rectum to the sacrum using sutures, often reinforced with mesh. This technique does not correspond to the image provided, which clearly shows a perineal approach with wiring.

 

Option D. Altemeier repair: A perineal approach to resect and anastomose the prolapsed rectum. While Altemeier repair is a perineal procedure, it involves resection and anastomosis rather than the placement of a circumferential wire around the anus, as seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thiersch's procedure, involving the placement of a wire or tape around the anal canal, is used in managing rectal prolapse but is now infrequently performed due to associated complications such as chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defecation.

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest X-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Coarctation of aorta

 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital condition characterized by the narrowing of the aorta, which causes an obstruction to blood flow. This condition leads to high blood pressure in the arteries that are proximal to the narrowing (upper limbs) and lower blood pressure in the arteries distal to the narrowing (lower limbs).

 

The key findings in this scenario include:

 

  • Feeble femoral pulses: Due to reduced blood flow past the coarctation.
  • Upper limb hypertension: Caused by increased resistance proximal to the coarctation.
  • Chest X-ray showing enlarged intercostal arteries: These develop as collateral circulation to bypass the coarctation, which can cause rib notching seen on X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): An ASD is a hole in the septum between the heart's atria. It typically causes a left-to-right shunt and can lead to increased pulmonary blood flow and right heart overload. It does not cause differential blood pressure between limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option C. Bicuspid aortic valve: A bicuspid aortic valve is a congenital valve anomaly that can lead to aortic stenosis or regurgitation but does not typically cause differential blood pressure between the limbs or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Option D. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA is a persistent opening between the aorta and the pulmonary artery. It causes a continuous murmur and can lead to heart failure if significant but does not cause differential blood pressure or enlarged intercostal arteries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coarctation of the aorta should be suspected in patients with a significant difference in blood pressure between the upper and lower limbs, feeble femoral pulses, and chest X-ray findings of enlarged intercostal arteries, indicating collateral circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following Amino acid needs to be supplied in the diet of patients with Cystathionine beta synthase defect? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cysteine

 

Cysteine is not typically restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. In fact, cysteine supplementation may be necessary in some cases because CBS deficiency can lead to a decreased ability to convert homocysteine into cysteine. However, this decision is made on an individual basis after assessing the patient's specific needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methionine: Methionine is usually restricted in the diet of patients with CBS deficiency. Since methionine is metabolized to homocysteine, limiting dietary methionine intake can help reduce homocysteine levels in these patients.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine is not typically restricted in the diet of CBS-deficient patients. It is not directly related to homocysteine metabolism, so it does not require special dietary adjustments.

 

Option D. Homocysteine: Homocysteine is not supplied in the diet but rather accumulates in the body as a result of CBS deficiency. Managing and reducing elevated homocysteine levels is the primary goal of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) is involved in the synthesis of cysteine from dietary methionine. Cysteine synthesis require methionine, serine and vitamin B6. The reactions are summarized in the diagram:

 

 

So, in case of CBS deficiency there will be no formation of cystathionine and cysteine. so, cysteine becomes essential and needs to be taken in diet.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 291

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient is diagnosed with osteosarcoma and is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy as part of his treatment. Methotrexate is included in his chemotherapy regimen. What is the mechanism of action of methotrexate in the treatment of his osteosarcoma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Competitive inhibitor of DHFR.

 

Methotrexate has different mechanisms for anticancer activity and for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

 

Mechanism in Osteosarcoma (As anticancer drug): Methotrexate acts as a competitive inhibitor of the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). By inhibiting DHFR, methotrexate interferes with the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, an essential cofactor for DNA synthesis. This leads to a decrease in DNA and RNA synthesis, thereby arresting the cell cycle and inhibiting the growth of rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells in osteosarcoma.

 

Mechanism in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA): Methotrexate is used at much lower doses in Rheumatoid Arthritis. In this condition, the major mechanism involves the inhibition of an enzyme called AICAR transformylase, part of the purine synthesis pathway. When AICAR transformylase is inhibited, levels of AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) accumulate in the cell. This leads to an inhibition of another enzyme called adenosine deaminase, which is responsible for the degradation of adenosine. As a result, adenosine levels increase within the cell and in the extracellular environment. Adenosine is known to have anti-inflammatory properties. When adenosine interacts with its receptors, it can lead to various effects such as inhibition of inflammatory cell function, vasodilation, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine release. These actions contribute to the anti-inflammatory effects observed when methotrexate is used for treating RA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Analog of UMP: Methotrexate is not an analog of UMP (uridine monophosphate). It does not exert its effects through this mechanism.

 

Option C. Blocks purine synthesis: Methotrexate does not specifically block purine synthesis, although the inhibition of DHFR indirectly affects purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

 

Option D. Blocks pyrimidine synthesis: Similar to Option C, methotrexate does not specifically block pyrimidine synthesis but indirectly affects it through DHFR inhibition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate's primary mechanism of action in treating osteosarcoma is as a competitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR), which interferes with DNA synthesis and cell division in rapidly dividing cells.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Niacin

 

  • Niacin deficiency, specifically pellagra, is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis (skin changes), diarrhea (digestive symptoms), and dementia (neurological symptoms). The symptoms described in the patient match those of pellagra, making niacin deficiency the likely cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency, also known as beriberi, primarily manifests as neurological and cardiovascular symptoms. It is not associated with dermatitis and diarrhea, which are prominent features of pellagra.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, also known as ariboflavinosis, can lead to various symptoms, including sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, and inflammation and redness of the tongue (magenta tongue). While it shares some symptoms with pellagra, such as mucous membrane changes, it does not typically cause dementia and diarrhea.

 

Option D. Pyridoxine: Pyridoxine deficiency, also known as vitamin B6 deficiency, can lead to neurological symptoms but does not typically cause dermatitis or diarrhea. It is not the primary deficiency associated with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.

 

Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.

 

Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.

 

Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.

 

Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 534-535

questions.text: Which of the following is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) β-2 microglobulin

 

β-2 microglobulin is a poor prognostic marker of multiple myeloma.

 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell neoplasm commonly associated with lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and acquired immune abnormalities.

 

  • CRAB criteria for MM 
    • Hypercalcemia: serum calcium >11mg/dl
    • renal Insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dl or creatinine clearance <40 ml/min
    • Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dl
    • Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Poor prognostic factors for multiple myeloma:

 

  • Serum Beta 2-microglobulin - It is the single most powerful predictor
  • Deletion of 17 pITP53 sequences and the translocations t (14;16) and t(14;20)
  • Polyclonal serum Immunoglobulins
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase
  • High C-reactive protein
  • Increased plasma cell proliferative activity
  • High degree of bone marrow replacement
  • Presence of plasmablastic morphology
  • Elevated serum soluble receptor for IL6

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium levels: Elevated calcium levels are part of the CRAB criteria and indicate disease activity, but are not as strong a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Option C. Serum creatinine: Increased serum creatinine is also part of the CRAB criteria and indicates renal involvement, but it is not the single most powerful predictor.

 

Option D. Protein levels: Protein levels can be elevated due to monoclonal proteins produced by myeloma cells, but again, they are not as powerful a prognostic marker as β-2 microglobulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

β-2 microglobulin is the single most powerful predictor of poor prognosis in multiple myeloma, reflecting the tumor burden and the rate of disease progression.

questions.text:
Arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following findings:(NEET PG 2021)

  • pH: 7.52
  • HCO3: 30 mEq/L
  • PaCO2: 45 mmHg
  • Na: 123 mEq/L
  • K: 3.2 mEq/L
  • Cl: 67 mEq/L

What is the cause of her ABG findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Persistent vomiting

 

The ABG report indicates the patient has metabolic alkalosis, as evidenced by the elevated pH (7.52) and increased bicarbonate (HCO3) level (30 mEq/L). The slight increase in PaCO2 (45 mmHg) is a compensatory response to metabolic alkalosis, as the body attempts to retain CO2 to balance the pH.

 

Persistent vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (HCl), which results in metabolic alkalosis. The electrolyte disturbances seen here (hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and hyponatremia) are typical of persistent vomiting. Vomiting causes a loss of hydrogen ions (leading to increased bicarbonate), chloride (hypochloremia), and potassium (hypokalemia), along with fluid loss, which can dilute serum sodium levels, leading to hyponatremia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diabetic ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) typically presents with metabolic acidosis (low pH and low HCO3) rather than metabolic alkalosis. Additionally, DKA is usually associated with hyperkalemia rather than hypokalemia.

 

Option C. Septic shock: Septic shock usually causes metabolic acidosis due to lactic acidosis from poor tissue perfusion. It does not typically present with metabolic alkalosis and the specific electrolyte disturbances seen here.

 

Option D. Renal tubular acidosis: Renal tubular acidosis (RTA) is characterized by a defect in the kidneys' ability to acidify the urine, leading to metabolic acidosis. The ABG findings in RTA would show a low pH and low bicarbonate levels, which is opposite to what is observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Persistent vomiting can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia. This is due to the loss of gastric acid and electrolytes, and the characteristic ABG findings include elevated pH and bicarbonate levels. Treatment often involves fluid and electrolyte replacement, particularly with normal saline to correct chloride levels.

questions.text: A female patient presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and loss of smell. On examination, foul-smelling discharge and yellowish-green crusts are present in the nasal cavity. She is found to have merciful anosmia. Which of the following finding can also be seen during the examination of her nose? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Roomy nasal cavity

 

ATROPHIC RHINITIS:

 

Pathology - Ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous type. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterative endarteritis. The bone of turbinates undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers. Paranasal sinuses are small due to their arrested development.

 

Clinical Features

 

  1. Commonly seen in females and starts around puberty
  2. Foul smell from the nose though the patient himself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia) which accompanies these degenerative changes.
  3. Patients may complain of nasal obstruction due to large crusts filling the nose.
  4. Epistaxis may occur when the crusts are removed.

 

On examination shows

 

  1. Nasal cavity to be full of greenish or grayish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  2. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.
  3. Nasal mucosa appears pale. Septal perforation and dermatitis of nasal vestibule may be present. Nose may show a saddle deformity.
  4.  Atrophic changes may also be seen in the pharyngeal mucosa larynx.
  5. Hearing impairment may be noticed because of obstruction to the eustachian tube and middle ear effusion.
  6. Paranasal sinuses are usually small and underdeveloped with thick walls.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Nasal irrigation - using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium biborate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing chloromycetin, estradiol, and vitamin D2.
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.

 

Surgical management:

 

  • Young's operation: In this procedure, flaps are raised within the nasal vestibule and both the nostrils are completely closed and are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa may revert to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young's operation: In this procedure, the nostrils are partially closed and thereby avoiding the discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. The results are the same compared to Young's operation.
  • Narrowing of the nasal cavity can be done by submucosal injection of Teflon paste, or by insertion of fat, cartilage, or Teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nasal polyps: These are non-neoplastic masses of the edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. Nasal polyps can be antrochoanal polyps or ethmoidal polyps.

 

Option C. Inferior turbinate hypertrophy: It is associated with various mucosal diseases which include allergic rhinitis, infectious rhinitis, and vasomotor rhinitis. It can cause chronic nasal obstruction.

 

Option D. Foreign body nose: It is commonly seen in children and the child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrophic rhinitis leads to significant structural changes within the nasal cavity, most notably an enlargement of the space due to bone and soft tissue atrophy. Recognizing these changes is crucial for diagnosing and managing the condition effectively, with treatments often focusing on moisturizing the nasal cavity and addressing the underlying atrophic changes.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 172, 173

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presented with chest pain. In an angiogram, her left circumflex artery was found to be stenosed, and a stent was inserted. Her current medications include ASA 75mg OD, atenolol 50mg BID, lovastatin, and lisinopril. What should be done in this scenario? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add P2Y12 receptor inhibitor

 

After stent placement, it is crucial to prevent stent thrombosis, which can be life-threatening. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) is the standard of care in this scenario. DAPT includes aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor). These medications work synergistically to inhibit platelet aggregation and prevent thrombus formation within the stent.

 

The patient is already on aspirin 75 mg daily, so the addition of a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor is necessary to complete the DAPT regimen. This combination has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of stent thrombosis and other cardiovascular events after percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement.

 

Guidelines on the duration of dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) –

 

  • Drug-Eluting Stents (DES): A minimum of 6 months of DAPT is recommended. This therapy usually involves the use of aspirin combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, or prasugrel) to prevent clot formation around the new stent.
  • Bare Metal Stents (BMS): At least 1 month of DAPT is required. Although the duration is shorter than that for DES, it's crucial for preventing early stent thrombosis.
  • Stents Inserted for Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS): If a stent is inserted as part of treatment for ACS, the recommended minimum duration of DAPT extends to 12 months. This extended period helps manage the higher risk of thrombosis and other complications associated with ACS.
  • Current Patient Situation: Ongoing Medication: The patient is already on aspirin. A P2Y12 receptor inhibitor needs to be added to the regimen to complete the DAPT, ensuring optimal protection against clotting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase Aspirin dose: Increasing the aspirin dose does not provide additional benefit in preventing stent thrombosis and is not recommended as part of DAPT. The current dose of 75 mg is adequate when combined with a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor.

 

Option B. Increase atenolol dose: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is used for managing hypertension and angina but does not prevent stent thrombosis. Increasing its dose does not address the immediate need for antiplatelet therapy post-stent placement.

 

Option C. Add a Long-Acting Nitrate: Long-acting nitrates can help manage angina symptoms but do not prevent stent thrombosis. They are not part of the recommended therapy to prevent thrombotic complications after stent placement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After stent placement, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a P2Y12 receptor inhibitor (such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is essential to prevent stent thrombosis and ensure optimal patient outcomes.

questions.text: What is the SI unit used to measure the brightness of light from a point source among the options provided? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Candela

 

The candela is the SI unit used to measure the brightness (luminous intensity) of a light source emitting light in a specific direction. It quantifies the amount of light emitted from a point source within a solid angle of one steradian.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lux: Usage: Measures illumination or illuminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light reaching a surface. One lux is equal to one lumen per square meter.

 

Option C. Lambert: Usage: Measures brightness or luminance.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the amount of light emitted by a surface. One lambert is equal to the luminance of a surface emitting or reflecting one lumen per square centimeter.

 

Option D. Lumen: Usage: Measures luminous flux.

 

  • Definition: It quantifies the total amount of visible light emitted by a source. One lumen is the luminous flux emitted within a solid angle of one steradian by a point source with a luminous intensity of one candela.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 840 mEq

 

Explanation

 

The sodium deficit in the given scenario is 840 mEq.

 

Formula for calculating sodium deficit = 0.6 × body weight x (target plasma sodium concentration - starting plasma sodium concentration).

 

Substituting values as per the question,

 

Sodium deficit = 0.6 x 70 × (140 - 120) = 840 mEq.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Correcting sodium levels must be done cautiously, especially in cases of hyponatremia, to prevent complications like osmotic demyelination syndrome. Rapid changes in serum sodium can be dangerous, and adjustments should generally be made slowly, according to specific clinical guidelines.

choices.text: Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel
Shift to OT, start IV antibiotics, and pack the tonsillar fossa
Give anticoagulants, repeated gargling, and wait for 24 hours
Do blood transfusion and wait and watch

questions.text: A patient post-tonsillectomy in the recovery room starts bleeding from the operative site. On examination, blood clots are seen. What will be your immediate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shift to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel

 

The given clinical picture is suggestive of reactionary hemorrhage post-tonsillectomy and the immediate management is to shift the patient to OT, remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the bleeding vessel.

 

Hemorrhage is a common complication of tonsillectomy. It can be primary, reactionary, or secondary:

 

  • Primary hemorrhage occurs at the time of operation. It can be controlled by pressure, ligation, or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage occurs within 24 hours. It may be due to dislodgement of the clot, slippage of ligature, or blood pressure returning to normal. It is managed by removal of clot and application of pressure or vasoconstrictor. Ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels is done under anesthesia if the above measures fail.
  • Secondary hemorrhage is usually seen between the 5th to 10th postoperative day. It is due to sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Removal of the clot, topical application of dilute adrenaline or hydrogen peroxide with pressure usually suffice. IV antibiotics are given and the bleeding vessel is electro coagulated or ligated if bleeding continues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate return to the OT for direct intervention is essential in managing post-tonsillectomy bleeding. Ensuring the bleeding vessel is adequately addressed through cauterization or ligation can prevent further complications and promote healing.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 504, 505

questions.text: After a road traffic accident case has been admitted, there is a blood spillage on the hospital floor. Which type of disinfectant would you select for cleaning the floor? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sodium hypochlorite

 

If there is spillage of blood on the hospital floor, sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant for cleaning the floor.

 

Procedure to be followed in the event of blood/body fluid spillage:

 

  1. Wear a pair of non-sterile gloves
  2. Broken glass (if any) of the container is cleaned first using tongs or a pan and brush and discarded in the sharp container. Caution is taken to not use hands.
  3. Disposable paper towels are used to absorb as much as possible.
  4. Water and detergent are used to clean the surface until visibly clean.
  5. The area is saturated with 0.5% Sodium Hypochlorite. This is prepared by diluting 5.25% sodium hypochlorite bleach at a 1:10 ratio.
  6. The tongs, pan, and brush are washed under running water and left to dry
  7. The gloves are removed and discarded.
  8. Hands are washed with soap and water using proper technique and dried with a disposable towel.
  9. The spillage is recorded in an incident book.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl alcohol: Is not recommended for cleaning surfaces with blood spills as it is less effective against some microorganisms and may evaporate too quickly.

 

Option B. Chlorhexidine: is also less effective against blood-borne pathogens and is better suited for skin disinfection.

 

Option D. Formaldehyde: Is not commonly used as a disinfectant due to its potential health hazards.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective disinfection of surfaces contaminated with blood spills, sodium hypochlorite is the preferred choice due to its broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity and ability to neutralize blood-borne pathogens.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause side effects such as headache, flushing, and peripheral edema, but it is not typically associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. Its common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities, but it does not cause angioedema.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It can cause side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and rebound hypertension upon abrupt withdrawal, but it is not associated with angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-

 

  • Angioedema
  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with motor traffic accident with BP 90/60mm Hg. On examination, he was stable with GCS 15/15. The pupil was reactive to light. Tenderness and bruising over the left lower chest wall with petechia were seen. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. eFAST

 

Explanation:

 

The next step in the evaluation of a trauma patient with the given findings is the Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (eFAST). This non-invasive imaging technique is crucial for rapidly identifying free fluid and organ injuries in the abdomen, as well as potential pneumothorax or hemothorax, which are critical in trauma cases. eFAST is used to quickly assess both stable and unstable patients following blunt abdominal trauma, providing immediate information that can dictate further management steps.

 

Details:

 

eFAST Role: This ultrasound examination checks for free intraperitoneal or pericardial fluid and can evaluate the integrity of the pleural spaces.

 

Stability: Despite the patient's low blood pressure, he is neurologically intact (GCS 15/15) and responsive, which allows for an ultrasound examination before more invasive procedures are considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy: Generally reserved for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability after eFAST or when eFAST is positive for intra-abdominal injury needing surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Intubation: Might be necessary if respiratory status worsens or if advanced airway management is required, but the patient’s current stable neurological status does not immediately warrant this.

 

Option D. CECT (Contrast Enhanced CT Scan): Used after eFAST if the patient remains hemodynamically stable and further detailed evaluation of internal injuries is necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Supposititious child

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twins belonging to two different fathers. This case would be best described as? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfecundation

 

  • Similarities between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In both there is fertilization of 2 ova from 2 separate acts of coitus 
    • So twin pregnancy in both
    • Fathers can be different for the two babies in both Superfecundation and superfetation
  • Differences between Superfecundation and superfetation:
    • In Superfecundation the two acts of coitus occurred in same menstrual cycle, whereas in superfetation in two different cycles.
    • Hence, in Superfecundation both fetuses have similar development, and born at same time, whereas, in superfetation, the first fetus is more developed, and also, they may not be born at same time.

 

In the question, it is mentioned that “woman gave birth to twins”, which implies that both babies were born at same time. Hence superfecundation is a better choice than superfetation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: Fertilization of a second ovum during a different menstrual cycle while a pregnancy is already ongoing. The first fetus is more developed than the second, and they may not be born at the same time.

 

Option C. Supposititious children are fraudulent offspring. These arose when an heir was required and so a suitable baby might be procured and passed off as genuine.

 

Option D. Atavism: A modification of a biological structure whereby an ancestral genetic trait reappears after having been lost through evolutionary change in previous generations. E.g. tail in humans

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two ova from separate acts of coitus within the same menstrual cycle, resulting in the birth of twins that can have different fathers and are born at the same time.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) End-tidal CO2 concentration

 

Methods to confirm endotracheal intubation:

  • X-ray chest
  • Auscultation
  • End-tidal CO2 concentration
  • Chest rise

 

This is considered the best method to confirm ETT placement in real-time. Capnography measures the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the exhaled breath. When the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea, it will produce a waveform with a consistent and relatively high end-tidal CO2 concentration. In contrast, if the ETT is in the esophagus or there is an airway obstruction, the end-tidal CO2 concentration will be lower or absent, providing immediate feedback to the anesthesiologist.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. X-ray chest: While a chest X-ray can confirm the placement of the ETT, it is not a practical or immediate method for confirming tube placement during intubation. X-rays are typically used for confirmation after intubation.

 

Option B. Auscultation: Auscultation involves listening to breath sounds over the chest and epigastrium to assess tube placement. While it can be a useful method, it may not always be reliable, especially in noisy clinical environments, and it may not detect esophageal intubation or partial airway obstruction.

 

Option D. Chest rise: Observing chest rise can be helpful, but it is not as reliable as capnography. In some cases, chest rise may be present even if the ETT is incorrectly placed in the esophagus, especially in cases of esophageal intubation with positive-pressure ventilation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gold standard for confirming ETT placement is indeed the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography.
  • It provides real-time feedback and is considered a more reliable method compared to other options, ensuring that the ETT is correctly placed in the trachea and the patient is being ventilated effectively.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation should be considered in cases where epistaxis is not controlled by trotters method or nasal packing.

 

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point.

 

Most common artery to be ligated for epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery followed by internal maxillary artery, External carotid artery, Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery: The external carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to numerous facial structures, including the scalp, face, jaw, and more. Ligation of this artery is generally considered a more drastic measure and is typically reserved for severe cases where other specific arterial sources of bleeding have been ruled out or are inaccessible. It is much less selective than targeting the sphenopalatine artery and can lead to significant complications due to reduced blood flow to essential tissues.

 

Option B. Ligation of internal carotid artery: This option is generally not considered for epistaxis management due to the critical nature of the internal carotid artery, which primarily supplies blood to the brain. Ligation of this artery would pose a high risk of serious neurological deficits or stroke. It is a major artery and not a contributor to nasal bleeding; thus, it is not targeted in the treatment of epistaxis.

 

Option D. Ligation of maxillary artery: The maxillary artery is a major artery within the face that branches off the external carotid artery and gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery. While ligation of the maxillary artery is an option for severe epistaxis, it is less specific than targeting the sphenopalatine artery. The maxillary artery supplies areas broader than just the nasal cavity, including the maxilla, mandible, teeth, and parts of the face. Therefore, ligation of this artery is considered more invasive and has a higher risk of complications compared to the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

choices.text: Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism
Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with tuberculosis and is about to begin antitubercular therapy (ATT) that includes rifampicin. She is currently taking oral contraceptives (OCP) for birth control. The clinician advises her to use an additional barrier method of contraception while undergoing treatment. What is the primary reason for this recommendation? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Because rifampicin can induce OCP metabolism and cause failure

 

Rifampicin is used as one of the first line drugs against tuberculosis. Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer, that induces the cytochrome P450 enzymes. Therefore, this leads to increased rate of metabolism of the OCPs, thereby leading to contraceptive failure. So, in a female receiving ATT, it is advised to use additional barrier methods of contraception apart from OCPs.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. To prevent teratogenic effects: Most of the antitubercular drugs including rifampicin, isoniazid and ethambutol are safe in pregnancy. Further she is already taking OCPs, so the examiner does not want to ask about teratogenic effect of antitubercular drugs.

 

Option B. To avoid failure of ATT: The interaction between ATT and OCP does not lead to the failure of antitubercular therapy; rather, it affects the efficacy of the oral contraceptive method.

 

Option C. Because rifampicin can decrease OCP metabolism: This is incorrect because rifampicin actually induces, rather than decreases, the metabolism of oral contraceptives. This can lead to reduced levels of contraceptive hormones in the blood, thereby potentially leading to contraceptive failure.

 

Educational Objective

 

Rifampicin is known to induce hepatic enzymes that speed up the metabolism of various drugs, including oral contraceptives. This can lead to lower blood levels of the hormones in OCPs, thereby reducing their efficacy and increasing the risk of contraceptive failure. Hence, it is advised for patients on both medications to use an additional barrier method of contraception.

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

 

Explanation:

 

 Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:

 

  • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta.
  • The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not an appropriate management for a uterine septum in a woman desiring fertility. This would completely eliminate her ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty: While laparoscopy can be used to visualize the external uterine anatomy, metroplasty (surgical correction of the uterus) is better performed via hysteroscopy for a uterine septum. Laparoscopy is more invasive and not the first-line approach for this condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty: Laparotomy is an open surgical procedure that involves a larger incision in the abdomen. This approach is unnecessarily invasive for the correction of a uterine septum, which can be effectively managed with a less invasive hysteroscopic approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a uterine septum, especially in a woman seeking fertility, is hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty), which involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum and improve reproductive outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Soft tissue calcification in the neck

questions.text: A toddler was found playing alone and was brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in swallowing for the past few hours. An X-ray was performed, and the image revealed as shown in AP view. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Foreign body in the esophagus

 

  • A child presenting with difficulty in swallowing and the given X-ray suggest a foreign body lodged in the esophagus, most likely a coin or disc battery.
  • Anteroposterior (AP) and lateral views of the chest and neck X-rays were taken, and the flat surface of the coin in the esophagus is seen on the AP view, while the edge is seen on the lateral view.
  • Initial symptoms of esophageal foreign body ingestion include choking, gagging, and coughing, followed by excessive salivation, dysphagia, food refusal, vomiting, or pain in the neck and throat.
  • Respiratory symptoms such as stridor, wheezing, cyanosis, or dyspnea may also be seen.
  • Correct. If an object gets lodged in the esophagus, it can cause difficulty swallowing, pain, and drooling. The scenario presented indicates an X-ray showing a radiopaque foreign body (likely a coin or disc battery) in the esophagus, which is consistent with the child's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foreign body in the trachea: When a foreign body is stuck in the trachea, it is a life-threatening situation as it can block airflow. Symptoms would typically include coughing, choking, wheezing, and difficulty breathing. The flat surface would be better seen in the lateral view.

 

Option C. Artifact: An artifact in radiology refers to any distortion or error in the image that is not present in the patient. Artifacts can be due to the equipment, the patient's movement, or other factors.

 

Option D. Soft tissue calcification in the neck: This refers to the presence of calcified deposits in the soft tissues of the neck. These can be due to various reasons, such as long-standing inflammation, tumors, or other diseases. However, the presentation of acute difficulty in swallowing and the X-ray findings make this option unlikely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of pediatric ingestion of foreign bodies, the esophagus is a common site where objects can become lodged.
  • Radiographic evaluation typically shows a foreign body in the esophagus with a flat surface seen on the AP view and the edge on the lateral view.
  •  Immediate recognition and appropriate intervention are crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with normal bone mineral density. X-ray is given below. Identify the diagnosis: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scurvy

 

SCURVY

 

  • It is the deficiency of vitamin C, causing defect in the osteoid formation. 
  • The rosary found in this condition is sharp and tender. 
  • Radiological Features: 
    • Sclerosed Margins of Epiphysis
    • Osteopenia – ground glass appearance – 1st sign – thinning of cortex (pencil thin cortex).
    • Metaphysis maybe deformed or fractured.
    • Frankel’s line (zone of provisional calcification increases in width and opacity) due to failure of resorption of calcified cartilage and stands out compared to the severely osteopenic metaphysis.
    • Scurvy line or scorbutic zone (Trummerfeld’s zone) – radiolucent transverse band adjacent to the dense provisional zone.
    • Margins of the epiphysis appears sclerotic, termed as ringing of epiphyses or Wimberger’s sign (Ring sign).
    • Lateral metaphyseal spur (Pelkan spur) at ends of metaphysis is produced by outward projection of zone of provisional calcification and periosteal reaction.
    • Corner or angle sign is peripheral metaphyseal cleft.
    • Subperiosteal hemorrhage in lower end of femur and tibia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rickets. In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones. There is irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis, and thin and weak new trabeculae. On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped. The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance); and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

 

 

Option C. Osteopetrosis. Also called as marble bone disease, it is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen. 

 

 

 

Option D. Metaphyseal dysplasia. Also known as Pyle disease, it is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by flaring of the ends of long bones with relative constriction and sclerosis of the diaphysis and mild cranial sclerosis. The flared metaphyses are relatively lucent. The patients are often asymptomatic, although genu valgus deformity may be a feature. Patients present with short-limb dwarfism characterized by coxa vara, and spinal abnormalities. Radiographs reveals bulbous expansion of metaphysis. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given x-ray image in the question is suggestive of features due to vitamin C deficiency, scurvy. 
  • Following are the features seen in a patient with scurvy on a plain radiograph:

questions.text: Mrs. Johnson, a 54-year-old woman, underwent surgery for breast carcinoma last year. She now presents with painless swelling involving her left arm, which started 2 weeks ago. Upon examination, the affected arm appears swollen and feels heavy, with visible thickening of the skin. There is no warmth, redness, or tenderness. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lymphedema

 

  • Lymphedema is the most likely diagnosis given the patient's medical history and clinical presentation.
  •  Lymphedema is a common complication of breast cancer surgery, particularly when lymph nodes are removed or damaged during the procedure, leading to poor drainage of lymphatic fluid from the affected arm.
  • The swelling in lymphedema is usually painless, and the skin may feel tight or heavy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymphangiosarcoma:  Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare type of cancer that can develop in the lymphatic vessels, often years after radiation therapy or surgery for breast cancer. Symptoms may include pain, swelling, and skin changes in the affected area. However, it is a very uncommon complication compared to lymphedema.

 

Option C. Venous thrombosis: Venous thrombosis is a blood clot that develops in a vein, usually presenting with symptoms like swelling, pain, and warmth in the affected area. In this case, the swelling is painless and is more indicative of lymphatic fluid accumulation rather than a venous thrombosis.

 

Option D. Cellulitis: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection of the skin and soft tissues, presenting with symptoms such as redness, swelling, pain, and warmth. The absence of warmth, redness, and tenderness in the patient's presentation makes cellulitis an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lymphedema is a common postoperative complication of breast cancer surgery due to the removal or damage of lymph nodes, leading to poor lymphatic drainage.
  •  It presents as painless swelling, heaviness, and skin thickening in the affected limb.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of low-risk prostatic carcinoma. The most likely management for this patient would be active surveillance only.

  • Active surveillance is a management approach used for prostate cancer with specific criteria.
  • Criteria for active surveillance include Gleason score 6, early-stage disease (T1), small volume disease on biopsy, age > 70 years and low PSA (<10 ng/mL).
  • Active surveillance protocols include regular digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical prostatectomy: This surgical procedure involves removing the entire prostate gland. It is often considered for prostate cancer treatment, especially for younger, healthier patients or those with more aggressive forms of the disease.

 

Option B. External beam radiation: This treatment involves using targeted radiation beams to kill cancer cells. It can be considered for prostate cancer, particularly when surgery is not an option. The choice between radiation therapy and active surveillance depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the stage and aggressiveness of the cancer.

 

Option C. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy where radioactive seeds or sources are placed directly into or near the tumor. It's a localized treatment and can be used for low to intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Again, the decision to use brachytherapy depends on several factors, including the patient's overall health and the characteristics of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.

questions.text: In fetal circulation, which vessel carries deoxygenated blood back to the placenta? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Umbilical artery

 

The umbilical arteries are responsible for transporting deoxygenated blood from the fetal heart to the placenta during gestation. In general, arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, but the pulmonary and umbilical arteries are unique in that they carry deoxygenated blood.

 

 

Clinical significance:

 

  1. The medial umbilical ligament is the remnant of the umbilical artery. The umbilical artery has the following fate:
    • Proximal parts persist as the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal parts get obliterated and form the medial umbilical ligaments
  2. The normal umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. A single umbilical artery is the most common cord abnormality. The incidence is higher in twin deliveries. Thus, identifying this during the head-to-toe examination of the newborn becomes extremely important. Congenital anomalies are seen in 30% of cases with a single umbilical artery, trisomy 18 is a common association.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical Vein: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus.

 

Option C. Descending Aorta: In fetal circulation, the descending aorta distributes oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body and is not specifically involved in the transport of deoxygenated blood to the placenta.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary artery carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the lungs in postnatal circulation but does not play a role in fetal circulation in terms of transport to the placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In fetal circulation, the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

questions.text: A patient undergoing surgery is maintained on anesthesia with halothane. During the procedure, the patient suddenly developed hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Suxamethonium

 

The scenario described involves a patient undergoing surgery who suddenly develops hyperthermia and muscle rigidity. This is indicative of a condition called Malignant Hyperthermia (MH), which is a rare but potentially life-threatening reaction to certain medications used during anesthesia.

 

In this case, the most likely drug implicated in causing MH is:

 

Suxamethonium (also known as succinylcholine)

 

  • Suxamethonium is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent commonly used for muscle relaxation during surgery.
  • However, it is known to be associated with triggering malignant hyperthermia in susceptible individuals.
  • MH is a severe reaction that can cause a rapid increase in body temperature, muscle rigidity, and other complications.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Doxacurium: Doxacurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option C. Atracurium: Atracurium is another non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent used in anesthesia. It is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Rocuronium is also a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. Like atracurium and doxacurium, it is not typically associated with causing malignant hyperthermia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug most likely implicated in causing malignant hyperthermia in the given scenario is suxamethonium (succinylcholine) because it is known to trigger this condition in susceptible individuals.

 

Treatment - Dantrolene sodium and supportive management

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular rate. The medication charts reveal that he was taking digoxin, potassium chloride, clarithromycin, atenolol, and triamterene. Suspecting the symptoms to be due to digoxin overdose, plasma levels of digoxin were ordered. It was found that his blood levels of digoxin have increased significantly. Which of his medications is most likely responsible for this increase in digoxin levels? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clarithromycin.

 

  • Clarithromycin is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 system, which is involved in the metabolism of many drugs, including digoxin. By inhibiting the metabolism of digoxin, clarithromycin can lead to elevated levels of digoxin in the blood, increasing the risk for digoxin toxicity.
  • Clarithromycin also acts as an inhibitor of the P-glycoprotein and can precipitate Digoxin toxicity. P glycoproteins are drug efflux pumps in the intestine that lead to a decrease in the bioavailability of drugs. Digoxin is one of the drugs that utilizes this mechanism for its metabolism. Therefore, the drugs which inhibit the Pgp can lead to the increased plasma concentration of Digoxin and lead to its toxicity.
  • Other drugs that inhibit the Pgp include 
    • Amiodarone
    • Verapamil
    • Diltiazem
    • Itraconazole
    • Propafenone
    • Flecainide 
    • Quinidine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium chloride: This medication primarily affects potassium levels and has no significant interaction with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol, a beta-blocker, is not known to significantly interact with digoxin metabolism.

 

Option D. Triamterene: This diuretic medication primarily affects sodium and potassium levels and is not known to have a significant impact on digoxin metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clarithromycin can significantly increase plasma levels of digoxin by inhibiting its metabolism through the cytochrome P450 system and by inhibiting P-glycoprotein, leading to an increased risk of digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which entity is responsible for managing the school health programs? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Primary health center

 

  • In India, the School Health Committee recommended that school health services be integrated with general health services, which are managed by primary health centers (PHCs).
  • To ensure effective implementation, the committee proposed the formation of school health committees at various levels. PHCs are responsible for providing a range of school health services such as health assessments, vision and hearing tests, dental check-ups, treatment for common illnesses, immunization, micronutrient management, deworming, and provision of mid-day meals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Health Centers (PHCs) are responsible for managing school health programs in India, providing a range of health services to ensure the well-being of school children.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

choices.text: Premature ovarian failure
Delayed blood transfusion reaction

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient came with a history of fatiguability and constipation for the past 1 year. She has a history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery 4 years ago. She has had lactational failure and never regained her periods after the delivery. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sheehan syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Sheehan syndrome:

 

  • The most probable diagnosis in a woman with lactational failure and postpartum amenorrhea, now presenting with fatiguability and constipation, is Sheehan syndrome.
  • Sheehan syndrome refers to panhypopituitarism occurring as a result of pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage.
  • The history of multiple blood transfusions after delivery indicates significant blood loss, which resulted in pituitary ischemia leading to this condition.
  • Symptoms such as fatiguability and constipation can be attributed to secondary hypothyroidism resulting from pituitary dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypothyroidism: While hypothyroidism can cause fatiguability and constipation, the history of postpartum amenorrhea and lactational failure makes Sheehan syndrome more likely. In Sheehan syndrome, hypothyroidism is a secondary consequence of pituitary dysfunction.

 

Option C. Premature ovarian failure: Premature ovarian failure typically presents with symptoms of estrogen deficiency such as hot flashes and vaginal dryness, along with amenorrhea. However, it does not account for the history of significant postpartum hemorrhage and lactational failure seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Delayed blood transfusion reaction: Delayed blood transfusion reactions usually present with symptoms such as jaundice, fever, and anemia, but they do not explain the chronic symptoms of fatiguability, constipation, lactational failure, and amenorrhea in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sheehan syndrome is characterized by panhypopituitarism due to pituitary ischemia and necrosis following massive obstetrical hemorrhage, leading to symptoms such as lactational failure, amenorrhea, fatiguability, and constipation.

 

Ref: Page no 465, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A patient presented with weakness, anemia, bony pain & hepatosplenomegaly. A histological picture is shown with cells in bone marrow. Which of the following enzyme is deficient?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gluco-Cerebrosidase

 

The picture show macrophages with typical crumpled tissue paper appearance/ wrinkled appearance that is highly characteristic of Gaucher’s disease (most common lysosomal storage disease). Glucocerebrosides accumulate in reticuloendothelial system due to deficiency of enzyme β-Glucocerebrosidase. These patients have bony pain, pathological fractures, hepatosplenomegaly, but no mental retardation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: Deficiency of Glucose 6 phosphatase is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSD-I) or von Gierke disease. This disorder primarily affects glucose metabolism and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option C. Hexosaminidase A: Hexosaminidase A deficiency is associated with Tay-Sachs disease, which primarily affects the nervous system and does not typically present with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Option D. Beta-Galactosidase: Deficiency of Beta-Galactosidase is associated with GM1 gangliosidosis. This lysosomal storage disorder primarily affects the nervous system and is not typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly or bony pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gluco-Cerebrosidase, is associated with Gaucher's disease, a rare inherited metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of harmful quantities of glucosylceramide due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase. Gaucher's disease can lead to the symptoms described, including hepatosplenomegaly, anemia, and bony pain.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 235

choices.text: Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
Premature closure of the ductus venosus

questions.text: A 25-year primigravida is on indomethacin (25mg TDS) for polyhydramnios till 35 weeks. What abnormality can the fetus have if she goes into labor now? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

 

Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:

 

  • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications:
    • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid.
    • Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus.
  • Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, leading to complications such as:
    • Pulmonary hypertension
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy
    • Heart failure

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale: The foramen ovale normally closes soon after birth when the pressure in the left atrium exceeds the pressure in the right atrium. Indomethacin does not affect the closure of the foramen ovale.

 

Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a condition where the ductus arteriosus remains open after birth. Indomethacin is actually used to treat PDA by promoting its closure, not causing it.

 

Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus: The ductus venosus allows oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to bypass the liver and flow directly into the inferior vena cava. Indomethacin does not influence the closure of the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if used beyond 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. She is prescribed metronidazole as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following should she avoid consuming while on this medication? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol

 

  • Patients taking metronidazole are advised to avoid alcohol consumption. Metronidazole and alcohol can interact to cause a disulfiram-like reaction, leading to symptoms such as flushing, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and even more severe reactions in some cases. This interaction can occur not only with oral alcohol consumption but also with alcohol contained in mouthwashes and certain medications.
