  • Disulfiram is an aversive drug, that inhibits the aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body, which can lead to symptoms like throbbing headache, flushing, chest tightness, visual disturbances, nausea etc. Hence these symptoms prevent the patient from taking alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grapefruit juice: There is no known significant interaction between grapefruit juice and metronidazole.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepine: While caution may be advised when combining any medications that can have CNS effects, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between benzodiazepines and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Option D. SSRI: Similar to benzodiazepines, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between SSRIs and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs that can cause disulfiram like reaction include:

 

Cyclic:  Cefoperazone, Chlorpropamide

 

G:         Grieseofulvin

 

M:        Metronidazole

 

P:         Procarbazine

choices.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

 

The above image shows postmortem change of marbling.

 

Marbling:

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic colour change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of colour change in putrefaction:
    1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
    2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black colour.
  3. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  4. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  5. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen within 24 hours of death: While marbling starts within 24 hours, it becomes more prominent at around 36–48 hours.

 

Option C. Due to aseptic nonbacterial cause: Marbling is a result of bacterial activity and the decomposition process, not aseptic causes.

 

Option D. It is associated with a case of electrical burns: Marbling is not associated with electrical burns; it is a postmortem change due to putrefaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling, a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black lines on the skin, is due to the accumulation and formation of sulph-meth-hemoglobin during putrefaction.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Saline infusion sonography

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: This appears like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is an X-ray procedure used to delineate uterine anomalies, identify endometrial cavity lesions, and assess tubal patency in cases of infertility.

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

The clinical scenario of a child with resistant rickets and the following laboratory findings—normal serum calcium, normal parathyroid hormone, decreased serum phosphate, increased alkaline phosphatase, decreased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, increased urinary phosphate, decreased urinary calcium, and normal ABG and serum creatinine—is highly suggestive of hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Hypophosphatemic Rickets: This condition is characterized by low serum phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, leading to rickets despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D. It is often caused by mutations affecting phosphate-regulating genes like PHEX.
  • Laboratory Findings: The hallmark of this condition includes low serum phosphate, high alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D dependent rickets: This would typically show low calcium and elevated parathyroid hormone levels due to impaired vitamin D metabolism or action. Serum phosphate may also be low, but the distinguishing factor is the response to vitamin D therapy, which is absent in hypophosphatemic rickets.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition usually presents with low calcium and high phosphate levels due to insufficient parathyroid hormone. The given case has normal calcium and low phosphate, making hypoparathyroidism unlikely.

 

Option C. Chronic renal failure: This would typically show elevated serum creatinine along with abnormalities in calcium and phosphate metabolism. The normal creatinine level in this patient rules out chronic renal failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with fatigue and swelling in the legs. On auscultation, a mid-diastolic murmur is heard, and his jugular venous pulse shows prominent "a" waves. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tricuspid stenosis

 

The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur with prominent a-waves in the JVP points to tricuspid stenosis (TS). Mid-diastolic murmurs are due to obstruction at the level of the mitral or tricuspid valve, and TS is known for causing a giant a-wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) due to impaired right atrial emptying.

 

TS is often associated with mitral stenosis and is usually of rheumatic origin. The murmur is best heard at the left sternal border and intensifies during inspiration. An ECG would show right atrial enlargement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral stenosis: Mitral stenosis also causes a mid-diastolic murmur, but it does not produce a prominent a-wave in the JVP, which is characteristic of TS.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation causes a holosystolic murmur, not a mid-diastolic one, and is associated with conditions like rheumatic fever or myocardial infarction. The murmur radiates to the axilla.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: Tricuspid regurgitation results in a holosystolic murmur with prominent c-v waves in the JVP, unlike the a-waves seen in TS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tricuspid stenosis presents with a mid-diastolic murmur and prominent a-waves in the JVP, often associated with right atrial enlargement and is of rheumatic origin.

questions.text: Identify the gross specimen obtained from a cystoprostatectomy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bladder carcinoma

 

The image shows a large, fungating growth originating from the bladder wall and involving the entire bladder. The prostate lobes are spared, suggesting that the specimen is a classic representation of bladder carcinoma.

 

Clinical Features of Bladder Carcinoma:

 

  • Painless, gross hematuria is the most common symptom and may lead to clot formation, causing urinary retention.
  • Other symptoms include increased frequency and discomfort during urination.

 

Types of Bladder Carcinoma (Based on Depth of Invasion):

 

  1. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer – Accounts for 70% of cases, does not invade the detrusor muscle but can invade the lamina propria.
  2. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer – Involves the detrusor muscle.
  3. Carcinoma in situ (CIS) – A flat, non-invasive cancer.

 

Diagnosis and Staging:

 

  • Cystoscopy and tumor resection are essential for diagnosis.
  • Post-resection, a bimanual examination is recommended.
  • Complete urinary tract imaging (CT or MR urography) is necessary for staging.

 

Management:

 

  1. Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer:
    • Transurethral resection of the bladder tumor (TURBT) followed by intravesical chemotherapy (Mitomycin C or Epirubicin).
    • Immunotherapy via intravesical instillations of Bacille Calmette Guerin (BCG) for high-risk tumors.
  2. Muscle-invasive bladder cancer:
    • Radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection and possible urinary diversion procedures.
    • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is often considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition, often seen in immunocompromised patients. Its treatment involves systemic antibiotics, surgical excision, and reducing immunosuppression. The gross appearance is different from bladder carcinoma.

 

Option C. Prostate carcinoma: Prostate carcinoma involves radical prostatectomy rather than cystectomy. The bladder is typically unaffected. In the specimen, bladder involvement without prostate lobe involvement rules out prostate carcinoma.

 

Option D. Schistosomiasis of the bladder: Schistosomiasis of the bladder is caused by Schistosoma hematobium. Cystoscopy findings in this case may include nodules, pseudo-tubercles, ulceration, and sandy patches, often leading to squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder in advanced cases. However, the gross appearance is distinct from bladder carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder carcinoma presents with painless hematuria, and management depends on the depth of invasion (non-muscle invasive vs. muscle invasive), often requiring cystoscopy, resection, and possibly radical cystectomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with a history of anxiety presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest tightness and dizziness. She appears visibly anxious and is noted to be hyperventilating. Shortly after, she develops carpopedal spasms. What is the most likely cause of the carpopedal spasm in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory alkalosis

 

The patient’s carpopedal spasm is due to respiratory alkalosis, which results from hyperventilation. When a patient hyperventilates, excessive carbon dioxide (CO2) is exhaled, leading to hypocapnia (low CO2 levels in the blood). The reduction in CO2 causes an increase in blood pH (alkalosis). Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin, which decreases the amount of ionized (free) calcium in the blood, resulting in hypocalcemia.

 

Hypocalcemia is responsible for the neuromuscular irritability seen in the form of carpopedal spasm. This is a classic clinical feature of respiratory alkalosis secondary to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory acidosis: This condition occurs when there is hypoventilation, leading to an accumulation of CO2, causing a drop in pH (acidosis). It is not related to hyperventilation and would not cause carpopedal spasms.

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis: This results from an increase in acid production or loss of bicarbonate, not related to hyperventilation. It would not cause carpopedal spasms.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis: This occurs due to an increase in bicarbonate or loss of hydrogen ions, typically from vomiting or diuretic use. However, it is not related to hyperventilation and would not be the cause of carpopedal spasms in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory alkalosis caused by hyperventilation can lead to hypocalcemia and manifest as carpopedal spasms due to the decreased ionized calcium levels.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the cornea. What is the likely deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retinoic acid

 

The patient's symptoms of delayed adaptation to vision in dark places, gritty sensation in the eyes, dry eyes, and softening of the cornea point towards vitamin A deficiency, specifically retinoic acid.

 

Vitamin A plays a crucial role in vision, immune function, and tissue maintenance. There are three key forms of vitamin A:

 

  1. Retinal – essential for normal vision (involved in the visual pigment rhodopsin).
  2. Retinol – critical for reproductive function.
  3. Retinoic acid – important for regulating gene expression and tissue differentiation.

 

Ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency include:

 

  • Nyctalopia (night blindness): Difficulty seeing in low-light conditions.
  • Xerophthalmia: Includes dry eyes (conjunctival xerosis), Bitot's spots (white patches of keratinized epithelium on the sclera), and keratomalacia (softening of the cornea), leading to scarring and potential blindness.

 

Treatment involves vitamin A supplementation, with the WHO recommending 200,000 IU of vitamin A orally or 100,000 IU intramuscularly at diagnosis, repeated after 1 day and 14 days.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Deficiency causes angular cheilitis, glossitis, and corneal vascularization but does not cause the specific eye symptoms seen in this case.

 

Option C. Niacin: Deficiency results in pellagra, characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. It does not cause the described eye symptoms.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Deficiency is rare and typically associated with nonspecific symptoms like fatigue and irritability, not ocular issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency, particularly retinoic acid, can lead to significant ocular manifestations like night blindness, dry eyes, and corneal softening. Immediate supplementation is crucial to prevent progression to blindness.

choices.text: Surgical excision is the definitive treatment
Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension
Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Propranolol is given initially to manage hypertension

 

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor originating from the adrenal medulla. It can present with paroxysmal or sustained hypertension, headache, palpitations, and sweating. Catecholamines primarily stimulate alpha-adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

In pheochromocytoma, alpha-blockers (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) are used first to manage hypertension by blocking the alpha-adrenergic effects of catecholamines, preventing vasoconstriction. Once alpha blockade is achieved, beta-blockers such as propranolol can be given to control tachycardia. If beta-blockers are given first, it can lead to unopposed alpha-adrenergic stimulation, which can cause a hypertensive crisis due to excessive vasoconstriction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnosed by urine VMA & catecholamines: Correct. Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and catecholamines are breakdown products measured in urine to diagnose pheochromocytoma.

 

Option B. Surgical excision is the definitive treatment: Correct. Surgical removal of the tumor is the definitive cure for pheochromocytoma.

 

Option D. Can present as hypertension alone and sometimes with vomiting and pain abdomen: Correct. Pheochromocytoma can cause episodic hypertension, which may be accompanied by gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha-blockers must always be administered before beta-blockers in the treatment of hypertension in pheochromocytoma to prevent hypertensive crises due to unopposed alpha-receptor stimulation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of severe headache, jaw pain while chewing, and shoulder stiffness, particularly in the morning. She reports feeling fatigued and has experienced unintended weight loss. On examination, the left temporal artery is tender, nodular, and has reduced pulsation. Laboratory studies show an elevated ESR of 105 mm/hr and mild anemia. The patient is worried about her vision, as her friend recently went blind due to a similar condition. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroids

 

This patient has clinical features of giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, which is a condition characterized by inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels, most often affecting women aged over 50 years. Key symptoms include headaches, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica (manifesting as shoulder and hip stiffness), and constitutional symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and weight loss. Tenderness and nodularity of the temporal artery may also be seen, as in this case.

 

GCA is associated with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), anemia, and elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. The diagnosis can be confirmed via temporal artery biopsy, though the biopsy may yield false negatives due to patchy involvement of the vessels. The greatest concern in GCA is the potential for ischemic optic neuropathy, which can result in permanent blindness.

 

Steroids (prednisolone 40–60 mg/day) are the first-line treatment and should be initiated immediately to prevent irreversible complications such as vision loss. In patients with visual symptoms, high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone (1000 mg/day for 3 days) may be used. Treatment duration is long-term, often lasting for two years or more, and the dose is gradually tapered over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is sometimes used adjunctively in GCA to reduce the risk of ischemic complications, such as visual loss, but it is not the first-line treatment. Aspirin may help prevent platelet aggregation, but it cannot halt the underlying inflammatory process, which requires prompt corticosteroid therapy.

 

Option B. Tocilizumab: Tocilizumab, an IL-6 receptor inhibitor, is a newer treatment option for GCA and may be used adjunctively with steroids to reduce disease activity. However, it is not the first-line therapy and is generally reserved for patients who are refractory to steroids or those requiring steroid-sparing options.

 

Option D. Abatacept: Abatacept is a CTLA-4 Ig fusion protein that modulates T-cell activation and is another adjunctive therapy for GCA. Like tocilizumab, it may be used in patients who do not adequately respond to steroids. However, it is not first-line and is considered a second-line or adjunctive treatment in severe or refractory cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steroids are the first-line treatment for giant cell arteritis and should be started immediately to prevent complications such as permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a BIRADS-5 breast lesion on her recent mammogram, highly suspicious for malignancy. A biopsy is performed, and immunohistochemistry results show estrogen receptor (ER) positivity. Which of the following is considered a good prognostic factor in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ER positive

 

ER positivity is a good prognostic factor in breast cancer. Breast tumors that express estrogen receptors (ER) or progesterone receptors (PR) tend to have a more favorable prognosis and are more likely to respond to hormonal therapies such as tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors. The presence of ER/PR receptors is associated with a slower-growing, less aggressive tumor compared to hormone receptor-negative tumors.

 

Breast cancer is classified based on various markers like ER, PR, and HER2, and the presence of ER positivity is important for both prognosis and treatment. Patients with ER-positive tumors tend to have better overall survival and lower recurrence rates.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. BRCA-1 positive: Incorrect. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with a higher risk of developing breast and ovarian cancer. Breast cancers linked to BRCA1 mutations tend to be high-grade, hormone receptor-negative, and associated with a poorer prognosis due to their aggressive nature.

 

Option B. p53 positive: Incorrect. p53 is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene can lead to the development of various cancers, including breast cancer. p53 positivity is often associated with highly aggressive, malignant cancers, and its presence indicates a poor prognosis.

 

Option D. High Ki-67: Incorrect. Ki-67 is a marker used to assess the proliferative activity of a tumor. A high Ki-67 index indicates a highly proliferative tumor, which is associated with a worse prognosis. Tumors with a high Ki-67 index are generally more aggressive and have a higher likelihood of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ER positivity in breast cancer is a favorable prognostic factor and indicates a likely response to hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fever, confusion, and a seizure. He has had a headache for the past few days. On examination, he is febrile and disoriented. An MRI of the brain shows hyperintense signals in the bilateral temporal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Herpes simplex virus

 

This patient’s presentation, which includes fever, confusion, seizures, and MRI findings of temporal lobe involvement, is highly suggestive of Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis. HSV encephalitis typically affects the temporal lobes and presents with acute onset of fever, headache, altered mental status, and seizures. MRI typically shows hyperintense signals in the temporal lobes, which are often bilateral in HSV encephalitis. The gold standard for diagnosis is HSV DNA detection via PCR in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Immediate treatment with intravenous acyclovir is essential to reduce mortality and morbidity.

 

 

Herpes simplex encephalitis 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus: CMV encephalitis is more commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with AIDS. It often presents with periventricular calcifications or enlargement of the ventricles on imaging, which is not consistent with this patient's MRI findings involving the temporal lobes.

 

Option B. Toxoplasma gondii: Toxoplasmosis typically causes multiple ring-enhancing lesions on imaging and is primarily seen in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. These lesions are often found in the basal ganglia or corticomedullary junction, not the temporal lobes.

 

Option D. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Tuberculous meningitis or encephalopathy typically presents with basilar enhancement and hydrocephalus on imaging. It is most commonly seen in immunocompromised patients or young children and does not specifically affect the temporal lobes as seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus is the most common cause of viral encephalitis in adults and typically affects the temporal lobes. It presents with fever, altered mental status, and seizures. Early diagnosis and treatment with intravenous acyclovir are critical.
